vi_translation: I kept living like that for three days and nights. Nothing changed. Everything remained the same. The next day, I searched around where I lived and went down to the lower part of the island. I was the master of the island. The whole island was mine, so to speak, and I wanted to know everything about this island in detail. Actually, it was just to pass the time. I found a lot of ripe and delicious berries, and even green summer grapes; the rice fruits were also starting to sprout, and eventually, it would be time to harvest them all.
tr_translation: So, three days and three nights passed like this. There was nothing different; I was doing the same thing all the time. But the next day, I started to explore the island. One could say I was the master of the island; it all belonged to me; that's why I wanted to learn every inch of it; although what I really wanted was to find something to keep myself busy. I found plenty of strawberries, both ripe and delicious, then I found unripe grapes and raspberries, and also the blackberries had started to grow green and fleshy. In time, they would all become edible.
es_translation: And so three days and nights passed. No change: always the same. But the next day I went to explore the whole island. I was the master; everything was mine, so to speak, and I wanted to know it entirely, but above all, I wanted to pass the time. I found heaps of strawberries, ripe and wonderful, and green summer grapes and green blackberries, and the blackberries were just starting to come out. I thought everything would come in very handy in time.

en: Well, I went fooling along in the deep woods till I judged I warn’t far from the foot of the island. I had my gun along, but I hadn’t shot nothing; it was for protection; thought I would kill some game nigh home. About this time I mighty near stepped on a good-sized snake, and it went sliding off through the grass and flowers, and I after it, trying to get a shot at it. I clipped along, and all of a sudden I bounded right on to the ashes of a camp fire that was still smoking.
vi: Cứ như vậy, tôi đi lang thang mãi vào rừng sâu cho đến lúc tôi đoán chỗ này không còn xa đầu kia của hòn đảo là mấy nữa. Tôi có khẩu súng trên tay nhưng chưa bắn một phát nào. Súng chỉ là để hộ thân, và tôi cũng nghĩ sẽ bắn một con vật gì ở gần hang của nó. Vừa lúc đó, suýt nữa thì tôi dẫm phải một con rắn khá lớn, con rắn luồn vào đám cỏ hoa mà chạy. Tôi đuổi theo định bắn cho được con rắn. Tôi đang bám riết bỗng thế nào đâm ngay phải một đám tro của ngọn lửa trại nào còn đang âm ỉ cháy.
tr: Adanın ucuna çok uzak olmayan bir yere gelinceye dek sık ormanın içinde dolandım. Tüfeğim hep yanımdaydı, ama hiçbir şey vurmamıştım; tüfek kendimi korumak içindi; gerçi evin yakınlarında olsam bir şeyler avlardım. Bu arada epeyce büyük bir yılanın üzerine basayazdım, yılan otların ve çiçeklerin arasından kayıp gitti, ben de belki vurabilirim diye peşine düştüm. Hızla ilerlerken birden kendimi hâlâ dumanı tüten bir kamp ateşinin külleri üzerinde buldum.
es: Bueno, fui entreteniéndome por dentro del bosque hasta que me pareció que no estaba lejos de la punta de la isla. Había llevado mi escopeta, pero no había disparado contra nada; era para protegerme; pensé que ya encontraría algo que cazar cerca de casa. Entonces casi pisé una serpiente de buen tamaño, que se fue reptando entre la hierba y las flores, y yo detrás de ella, tratando de pegarle un tiro. Iba a buena marcha cuando de repente me encontré con las cenizas de una hoguera que todavía echaba humo.
vi_translation: Just like that, I wandered deeper into the forest until I guessed that this place wasn't far from the other end of the island anymore. I had a gun in my hand but hadn't fired a single shot. The gun was just for self-defense, and I also thought I would shoot an animal near its den. At that moment, I almost stepped on a rather large snake, which slithered into the grass and flowers to escape. I chased after it, determined to shoot the snake. While I was in hot pursuit, I suddenly stumbled upon a pile of ashes from a campfire that was still smoldering.
tr_translation: I wandered through the dense forest until I reached a place not too far from the edge of the island. My rifle was always by my side, but I hadn't shot anything; the rifle was for my protection; although if I were near the house, I would hunt something. Meanwhile, I almost stepped on a rather large snake, which slithered away through the grass and flowers, and I chased after it, thinking I might be able to shoot it. As I moved quickly, I suddenly found myself standing over the ashes of a campfire that was still smoking.
es_translation: Well, I was entertaining myself inside the forest until it seemed to me that I was not far from the tip of the island. I had taken my shotgun, but I hadn't shot at anything; it was for protection; I thought I would find something to hunt near home. Then I almost stepped on a good-sized snake, which went slithering through the grass and flowers, and I went after it, trying to shoot it. I was making good progress when suddenly I came across the ashes of a campfire that was still smoking.

en: My heart jumped up amongst my lungs. I never waited for to look further, but uncocked my gun and went sneaking back on my tiptoes as fast as ever I could. Every now and then I stopped a second amongst the thick leaves and listened, but my breath come so hard I couldn’t hear nothing else. I slunk along another piece further, then listened again; and so on, and so on. If I see a stump, I took it for a man; if I trod on a stick and broke it, it made me feel like a person had cut one of my breaths in two and I only got half, and the short half, too.
vi: Tim tôi như nhảy lên ở trong lồng ngực. Tôi không đợi nhìn xem có gì nữa, tôi từ từ hạ súng xuống và khe khẽ đi giật lùi bằng đầu ngón chân, lùi rất nhanh. Thỉnh thoảng dừng lại một giây trong đám cành lá um tùm và nghe ngóng; nhưng hơi thở của tôi phì phào mạnh quá nên tai tôi không còn nghe thấy gì. Tôi hít vào một hơi dài, rồi lại nghe; rồi lại hít hơi nữa. Thấy một thân cây gãy nằm ngang, tôi đã tưởng có người. Dẫm phải một cành cây khô gẵy rác một tiếng, tôi cũng tưởng như có ai cắt hơi thở của tôi làm hai và tôi chỉ còn giữ được một nửa hơi thở rất ngắn.
tr: Neye uğradığımı şaşırmıştım. Etrafı kolaçan etmek için oyalanmadım, tüfeğin horozunu kaldırdım ve parmak uçlarıma basarak olabildiğince çabuk geri döndüm. Zaman zaman sık dalların arasında durup etrafı dinliyordum, ama heyecandan öyle gürültülü soluk alıyordum ki başka bir şey duyamıyordum. Biraz gittikten sonra tekrar durup çevreyi dinledim, ardından bir daha, bir daha. Bir ağaç kütüğü görürsem adam sanıyordum, bir dala basıp kırarsam birisi soluğumu ikiye kesmiş de bana yarısı kalmış gibi oluyordum, hem de kısa yarısı kalıyordu adeta.
es: Me dio un salto el corazón entre los pulmones. No esperé a seguir mirando más allá, sino que armé la escopeta y fui en silencio de puntillas a toda la velocidad que pude. De vez en cuando me paraba un momento entre las hojas y escuchaba, pero respiraba tan fuerte que no podía oír nada más. Seguí avanzando algo y volví a escuchar, y así una vez después de otra. Si veía un tocón creía que era un hombre; si pisaba una ramita y la rompía, me sentía como si alguien me hubiera cortado el aliento en dos y no me quedase más que la mitad, y encima la más corta.
vi_translation: My heart seemed to leap in my chest. I didn't wait to see anything else, I slowly lowered my gun and quietly tiptoed backward, retreating very quickly. Occasionally stopping for a second in the thick foliage and listening; but my breath was so loud that my ears couldn't hear anything. I took a deep breath, then listened again; then took another breath. Seeing a fallen tree trunk, I thought there was someone. Stepping on a dry branch that snapped with a crack, I felt as if someone had cut my breath in half, and I could only hold onto a very short half-breath.
tr_translation: I was bewildered. I didn't linger to scout the surroundings, I cocked the rifle and tiptoed back as quickly as possible. From time to time, I would stop among the dense branches and listen around, but I was breathing so loudly from excitement that I couldn't hear anything else. After walking a bit, I stopped again to listen to the surroundings, then again, and again. If I saw a tree stump, I thought it was a man; if I stepped on a branch and it broke, it felt as if someone had cut my breath in half and left me with the shorter half.
es_translation: My heart jumped between my lungs. I didn't wait to keep looking further; instead, I assembled the shotgun and tiptoed as fast as I could in silence. From time to time, I would stop for a moment among the leaves and listen, but I was breathing so hard that I couldn't hear anything else. I kept moving forward a bit and listened again, and so on, over and over. If I saw a stump, I thought it was a man; if I stepped on a twig and broke it, I felt as if someone had cut my breath in two and I was left with only half, and the shorter half at that.

en: When I got to camp I warn’t feeling very brash, there warn’t much sand in my craw; but I says, this ain’t no time to be fooling around. So I got all my traps into my canoe again so as to have them out of sight, and I put out the fire and scattered the ashes around to look like an old last year’s camp, and then clumb a tree.
vi: Trở về chiếc lều, tôi thấy trong lòng không yên. Thấy mình không còn được mạnh bạo như trước nữa. Nhưng tôi tự bảo: thì giờ đâu mà đi quanh quẩn. Rồi lại đem tất cả đồ đạc dọn xuống xuồng để khỏi có ai trông thấy. Tôi tắt ngọn lửa, xoa xoa đống tro ra chung quanh để trông có vẻ như ngọn lửa cũ đốt từ năm ngoái, rồi tôi trèo lên cây ngồi.
tr: Kampa vardığımda artık ne canlılığım kalmıştı ne de atılganlığım; eski kararlılığımı biraz yitirmiştim, ama şimdi oyalanmanın, düşüncelere dalmanın vakti değil, dedim kendi kendime. Bu yüzden bütün eşyalarımı tekrar kanoma doldurup gözlerden sakladım, ateşi söndürüp külleri etrafa saçarak eski bir kamp yeri görünümü yarattıktan sonra bir ağaca çıktım.
es: Cuando llegué al campamento no me sentía muy tranquilo ni muy valiente, pero voy y digo: «No es momento para hacer el tonto». Así que volví a meter todas mis trampas en la canoa para que nadie las pudiera ver, apagué la hoguera y esparcí las cenizas por ahí para que pareciese un campamento antiguo, del año pasado, y después me subí a un árbol.
vi_translation: Returning to the tent, I felt uneasy. I felt that I was no longer as bold as before. But I told myself: there is no time to wander around. Then I moved all the belongings down to the boat so that no one would see them. I extinguished the fire, scattered the ashes around to make it look like an old fire from last year, then I climbed up a tree and sat.
tr_translation: When I arrived at the camp, I had neither my vitality nor my boldness left; I had somewhat lost my former determination, but now is not the time to dawdle or get lost in thoughts, I told myself. Therefore, after packing all my belongings back into my canoe and hiding it from sight, extinguishing the fire and scattering the ashes to create the appearance of an old campsite, I climbed up a tree.
es_translation: When I arrived at the camp, I didn't feel very calm or very brave, but I went and said: "This is no time to fool around." So I put all my traps back in the canoe so no one could see them, put out the campfire and scattered the ashes around to make it look like an old camp from last year, and then I climbed up a tree.

en: I reckon I was up in the tree two hours; but I didn’t see nothing, I didn’t hear nothing—I only thought I heard and seen as much as a thousand things. Well, I couldn’t stay up there forever; so at last I got down, but I kept in the thick woods and on the lookout all the time. All I could get to eat was berries and what was left over from breakfast.
vi: Tôi đoán chừng ngồi trên cây đã đến vài tiếng đồng hồ, chẳng thấy gì, cũng không nghe thấy gì khác. Nhưng trong bụng thì tưởng như đã nghe thấy, nhìn thấy hàng ngàn thứ. Thôi, tôi không thể nào ở mãi trên cây như vậy được. Sau đó, tôi tụt xuống những chiếc vẫn đứng trong đám cây rậm rạp mắt luôn luôn ngó nhìn ra ngoài. Tôi chỉ mới ăn vài cái quả trên cây với một ít thức ăn còn để lại từ bữa sáng.
tr: Ağacın tepesinde iki saat kadar kaldım herhalde; ama hiçbir şey görmedim, hiçbir şey duymadım – sadece binlerce şey duyduğumu ya da gördüğümü sandım. Ağaç tepesinde sonsuza dek kalamazdım; bu yüzden en sonunda aşağı indim, ama sık ağaçlar arasında kaldım ve sürekli etrafı gözledim. Yiyecek olarak sadece biraz yemiş ve kahvaltıdan artakalanlar vardı.
es: Creo que pasaría dos horas en el árbol, pero no vi nada. No oí nada; sólo me parecía haber oído y visto por lo menos mil cosas. Bueno, tampoco me podía quedar allí eternamente, así que por fin me bajé, pero seguí en el centro del bosque y alerta todo el tiempo. No podía comer más que moras y lo que quedaba del desayuno.
vi_translation: I guess I've been sitting on the tree for several hours, seeing nothing and hearing nothing else. But in my mind, it felt like I had seen and heard thousands of things. Well, I couldn't stay on the tree like that forever. After that, I slid down and remained among the dense trees, always keeping an eye out. I had only eaten a few fruits from the tree and some leftover food from breakfast.
tr_translation: I probably stayed at the top of the tree for about two hours; but I saw nothing, I heard nothing – I only thought I saw or heard thousands of things. I couldn't stay at the top of the tree forever; so finally, I came down, but I was stuck among the dense trees and constantly watched my surroundings. There was only a bit of fruit and leftovers from breakfast as food.
es_translation: I think I spent two hours in the tree, but I didn't see anything. I didn't hear anything; it just seemed to me that I had heard and seen at least a thousand things. Well, I couldn't stay there forever either, so I finally got down, but I remained in the center of the forest and alert the whole time. I couldn't eat anything but blackberries and what was left of breakfast.

en: By the time it was night I was pretty hungry. So when it was good and dark I slid out from shore before moonrise and paddled over to the Illinois bank—about a quarter of a mile. I went out in the woods and cooked a supper, and I had about made up my mind I would stay there all night when I hear a plunkety-plunk, plunkety-plunk, and says to myself, horses coming; and next I hear people’s voices. I got everything into the canoe as quick as I could, and then went creeping through the woods to see what I could find out. I hadn’t got far when I hear a man say:
vi: Lúc đó đã đến đêm rồi. Bụng tôi đói mềm. Chờ đến lúc thật tối mịt, tôi mới thò ra khỏi bờ, trước lúc trăng lên, và đẩy xuồng về phía bờ Illinois, khoảng non nửa dặm. Tôi đi vào rừng nấu bữa ăn chiều và tính sẽ ở lại đây suốt đêm. Bỗng tôi nghe tiếng lộc cộc, lộc cộc. Tôi tự bảo: có ngựa đến. Sau đó, có tiếng người. Tôi lại vội vàng bê tất cả xuống xuồng, rồi lại bỏ vào rừng xem có thấy gì không. Bò chưa được mấy bước, nghe có tiếng người nói:
tr: Akşam olduğunda karnım çok acıkmıştı. Bu yüzden en karanlık anı kollayıp ayın yükselmesinden önce kıyıdan ayrılıp çeyrek mil uzaktaki Illinois sahiline doğru kürek çektim. Ormanın içine girip yemek pişirdim ve artık bütün gece orada kalmaya karar vermiştim ki takıtık tukuduk, takıdık tukuduk seslerini duyunca atların yaklaştığını anladım; zaten sonra da insan sesleri duydum. Her şeyi aceleyle kanoya yükledikten sonra ormanın içinden sürünerek neler olduğuna bakmaya gittim. Daha fazla ilerleyemeden bir adamın sesini duydum:
es: Cuando se hizo bien de noche tenía bastante hambre, así que cuando estaba oscuro del todo me metí en silencio en el agua antes de que saliera la luna y fui a remo a la ribera de Illinois: aproximadamente un cuarto de milla. Salí al bosque, me cociné algo que cenar y prácticamente me había decidido a pasar allí toda la noche cuando oí un clip clop y me dije que venían caballos; y después oí voces de gente. Metí todo en la canoa lo más rápido que pude y me arrastré por el bosque a ver si me enteraba de algo. No había avanzado mucho cuando oigo decir a alguien:
vi_translation: It was already night by then. My stomach was growling with hunger. Waiting until it was completely dark, I slipped out from the shore, before the moon rose, and pushed the boat towards the Illinois shore, about half a mile away. I went into the forest to cook dinner and planned to stay there all night. Suddenly, I heard a clattering sound. I told myself: there are horses coming. Then, there were voices. I quickly loaded everything back onto the boat, then went back into the forest to see if I could spot anything. After crawling a few steps, I heard someone speak:
tr_translation: In the evening, I was very hungry. So, I waited for the darkest moment and rowed away from the shore towards the Illinois coast, a quarter mile away, before the moon rose. I went into the forest, cooked some food, and had decided to stay there all night when I heard the clattering sounds of horses approaching; soon after, I also heard human voices. After hurriedly loading everything onto the canoe, I crawled through the forest to see what was happening. Before I could go any further, I heard a man's voice:
es_translation: When it got really dark, I was quite hungry, so when it was completely dark, I silently slipped into the water before the moon came out and paddled to the Illinois shore: about a quarter of a mile. I went into the woods, cooked myself something for dinner, and had practically decided to spend the whole night there when I heard a clip-clop and thought that horses were coming; and then I heard people's voices. I put everything in the canoe as quickly as I could and crawled through the woods to see if I could find out anything. I hadn't gone far when I heard someone say:

en: “We better camp here if we can find a good place; the horses is about beat out. Let’s look around.”
vi: - Nếu đi tìm được một chỗ nào tốt thì ta nên dừng lại đây hơn, ngựa đã mệt lắm rồi. Để coi chung quanh đây nào.
tr: “İyi bir yer bulursak burada kamp yapalım; atlar çok yoruldu. Çevreyi bir araştıralım.
es: —Más nos vale acampar aquí si encontramos un buen sitio; los caballos están muy cansados. Vamos a mirar.
vi_translation: - If we can find a good spot, we should stop here; the horses are very tired. Let's look around here.
tr_translation: “If we find a good spot, let's camp here; the horses are very tired. Let's explore the surroundings.”
es_translation: —We better camp here if we find a good spot; the horses are very tired. Let's take a look.

en: I didn’t wait, but shoved out and paddled away easy. I tied up in the old place, and reckoned I would sleep in the canoe.
vi: Tôi không chờ đợi gì nữa, tuồn trờ lùi và đẩy xuồng đi ngay. Tôi lại buộc xuồng vào chỗ cũ và định ngủ dưới xuồng.
tr: Hiç beklemedim, hemen açıldım ve kürek çekerek rahatça uzaklaştım. Eski yerime dönüp kanoyu bağladım ve en iyisinin de içinde uyumak olduğuna karar verdim.
es: No esperé, sino que me aparté y comencé a alejarme en silencio. Volví a amarrar en el sitio de antes y calculé que dormiría en la canoa.
vi_translation: I no longer waited for anything, the sky receded and I immediately pushed the boat away. I tied the boat back to its old spot and intended to sleep under the boat.
tr_translation: I didn't wait at all, I immediately set off and rowed away comfortably. I returned to my old spot, tied up the canoe, and decided that the best thing to do was to sleep inside it.
es_translation: I didn't wait, but moved away and began to leave silently. I went back to tie up at the previous spot and figured I would sleep in the canoe.

en: I didn’t sleep much. I couldn’t, somehow, for thinking. And every time I waked up I thought somebody had me by the neck. So the sleep didn’t do me no good. By-and-by I says to myself, I can’t live this way; I’m a-going to find out who it is that’s here on the island with me; I’ll find it out or bust. Well, I felt better right off.
vi: Tôi không ngủ đựơc nhiều. Vả chăng cũng không thể ngủ vì phải nghĩ ngợi. Mỗi lúc chợt tỉnh dậy tôi tưởng như có người nào đến túm lấy cổ tôi. Thành ra ngủ cũng chẳng có ích gì. Dần dần, tôi tự bảo mình không thể sống như thế này được, phải đi tìm xem ai cái người đến sống trên hòn đảo này với tôi như vậy. Tôi sẽ tìm cho ra, nếu không thì phải chuồn đi. Tôi nghĩ nên làm ngay là hay hơn cả.
tr: Pek fazla uyuyamadım. Düşünceler bana huzur vermiyordu. Üstelik her uyandığımda birinin enseme yapıştığını zannediyordum. Bu yüzden uykumu alabildiğim pek söylenemez. Artık böyle yaşayamayacağımı yavaş yavaş anlamaya başlamıştım, adada benden başka kimin olduğunu bulmalıydım; ya bulacaktım ya meraktan patlayacaktım. Bu kesin kararla içime biraz su serpildi.
es: No dormí mucho. No sé por qué, pero no podía, porque estaba pensando. Y cada vez que me despertaba creía que alguien me tenía agarrado por el cuello. Así que el sueño no me valió de nada. Al cabo de un rato voy y me digo: «No puedo seguir viviendo así; voy a enterarme de quién está en la isla conmigo; o me entero o me muero». Bueno, inmediatamente me sentí mejor.
vi_translation: I couldn't sleep much. Moreover, I couldn't sleep because I had to think. Every time I suddenly woke up, I felt as if someone was coming to grab my neck. So sleeping was of no use. Gradually, I told myself that I couldn't live like this, I had to find out who the person coming to live on this island with me was. I would find out, otherwise, I had to escape. I thought it would be better to do it right away.
tr_translation: I couldn't sleep much. My thoughts were not giving me peace. Moreover, every time I woke up, I thought someone was grabbing my neck. Therefore, it can't really be said that I got enough sleep. I had slowly started to understand that I couldn't live like this anymore; I had to find out who else was on the island besides me; either I would find out or I would burst from curiosity. This firm decision brought me some relief.
es_translation: I didn't sleep much. I don't know why, but I couldn't, because I was thinking. And every time I woke up, I thought someone was grabbing me by the neck. So the sleep was of no use to me. After a while, I go and tell myself: "I can't keep living like this; I'm going to find out who is on the island with me; either I find out or I die." Well, I immediately felt better.

en: So I took my paddle and slid out from shore just a step or two, and then let the canoe drop along down amongst the shadows. The moon was shining, and outside of the shadows it made it most as light as day. I poked along well on to an hour, everything still as rocks and sound asleep. Well, by this time I was most down to the foot of the island. A little ripply, cool breeze begun to blow, and that was as good as saying the night was about done. I give her a turn with the paddle and brung her nose to shore; then I got my gun and slipped out and into the edge of the woods. I sat down there on a log, and looked out through the leaves. I see the moon go off watch, and the darkness begin to blanket the river. But in a little while I see a pale streak over the treetops, and knowed the day was coming. So I took my gun and slipped off towards where I had run across that camp fire, stopping every minute or two to listen. But I hadn’t no luck somehow; I couldn’t seem to find the place. But by-and-by, sure enough, I catched a glimpse of fire away through the trees. I went for it, cautious and slow. By-and-by I was close enough to have a look, and there laid a man on the ground. It most give me the fan-tods. He had a blanket around his head, and his head was nearly in the fire. I set there behind a clump of bushes, in about six foot of him, and kept my eyes on him steady. It was getting gray daylight now. Pretty soon he gapped and stretched himself and hove off the blanket, and it was Miss Watson’s Jim! I bet I was glad to see him. I says:
vi: Rồi tôi lại đẩy xuồng lướt ra khỏi bờ một quãng, và cứ để cho xuồng trôi xuống phía dưới. Trăng vòi vọi. Trừ những chỗ có bóng tối ra, ánh trăng soi sáng như ban ngày. Tôi đánh xuồng đi như thế đến như đến một giờ đồng hồ; mọi vật đều im lặng và ngủ say như những tảng đá. Lần này tôi đã đến tận đầu kia hòn đảo. Một làn gió hiu hiu mát lạnh bắt đầu thổi tới. Nói như vậy nghĩa là sắp hết đêm rồi. Tôi lấy chân đập nước, quay ngoắt mũi xuống và đi đến ven rừng. Tôi ngồi xuống một thân cây đổ, nhìn qua đám lá cây. Trăng đã chạy đi đâu rồi, và màn đen lại phủ trên sông. Nhưng lát sau, nhìn lên qua ngọn cây thấy một vệt sang sáng, tôi biết lại sắp đến ban ngày. Tôi cầm súng lén đi đến chỗ gặp cái lửa trại hồi sớm. Đi được một hai phút lại dừng bước nghe ngóng. Nhưng rủi thay là không tìm thấy có ánh lửa. Tôi từ từ, rất cẩn thận, bước đến chỗ đó. Tới nơi, nhìn vào thấy trên mặt đất có người nằm. Tôi đã tưởng ma. Người nằm đó quấn một mảnh chăn lên đầu và gối đầu ngay gần kề đống lửa, Tôi đứng im lặng đằng sau bụi rậm, cách chỗ người đó nằm chừng hơn một thước, và nhìn chằm chặp. Trời đã mờ mờ sáng. Lát sau, người đó ngáp, vươn vai rồi tung chăn ra, ồ hoá ra Jim, anh da đen làm việc cho cô Watson. Tôi thật rất mừng được thấy Jim ở đây. Tôi lên tiếng:
tr: Böylece küreği alıp kıyıdan birkaç adım uzaklaştım, sonra kano zaten akıntıya kapılıp gölgelerin arasından ilerlemeye başladı. Ay parlıyordu ve gölgelerin dışında her yer gündüz gibi aydınlanmıştı. Bir saat boyunca sürüklenip durdum, ama her şey kaya gibi hareketsiz ve tam anlamıyla uyku halindeydi. Bu arada adanın en ucuna kadar gelmiştim. Sakin ve serin bir rüzgâr esmeye başladı, demek ki gece sona ermek üzereydi. Küreği kullanarak kanoyu çevirdim ve burnunu kıyıya dayadım; sonra da kanodan inerek, tüfeğimi alıp ormana daldım. Bir kütüğün üzerine oturup yaprakların arasından göğe baktım. Ayın artık nöbetini bitirdiğini ve karanlığın nehri bir battaniye gibi örtmeye başladığını gördüm. Ama çok geçmeden ağaçların tepesinde beliren solgun çizgi günün geldiğini gösteriyordu. O yüzden tüfeğimi alıp kamp ateşini gördüğüm yere doğru sessizce ilerledim, iki dakikada bir durup etrafı dinliyordum. Ama şansım pek yaver gitmemişti, ateşin olduğu yeri bir türlü bulamıyordum. Derken bir süre sonra ağaçların arasında yanan bir ateş gözüme çarptı. Büyük bir dikkatle ve yavaşça oraya yaklaştım. Sonunda bir göz atacak kadar yakına geldim ve yerde yatan bir adam gördüm. Korkudan zangır zangır titremeye başladım. Battaniyeyi başına kadar çekmişti ve başı neredeyse ateşin içindeydi. Bir buçuk iki metre ötesindeki çalıların arkasına sindim ve hiç gözlerimi ayırmadan ona bakmaya başladım. Hava biraz grileşmişti ve giderek aydınlanıyordu. Az sonra adam esnedi, gerindi ve battaniyeyi açtı, Bayan Watson’ın zenci kölesi Jim karşımdaydı! Onu gördüğüme hiç bu kadar sevinmemiştim. Hemen çalıların arasından çıkıp, “N’aber, Jim!” dedim.
es: Así que agarré el remo y bajé a sólo uno o dos pasos de la ribera, y después dejé que la canoa se metiera sola entre las sombras. Brillaba la luna, y donde no había sombra casi era como la luz del día. Estuve buscando casi una hora, en medio de un silencio como una tumba, mientras todo dormía. Bueno, para entonces ya había llegado casi a la punta de la isla. Empezó a soplar una brisa suave, rizada y fresca, que era como decir que estaba a punto de terminar la noche. Di un golpe de remo y acerqué la canoa a la ribera; después saqué la escopeta y fui deslizándome hasta el borde del bosque. Allí me quedé sentado en un tronco, mirando entre las hojas. Vi que la luna terminaba su turno y que el río empezaba a ponerse oscuro. Pero al cabo de un rato vi una franja pálida por encima de los árboles y supe que llegaba el día. Así que saqué la escopeta y avanzé hacia donde me había encontrado con aquella hoguera, parándome a escuchar cada minuto o dos minutos. Pero no sé por qué no tuve suerte; era como si no pudiera encontrar el sitio. Pero al cabo de un rato, por fin, vi un resto del resplandor del fuego entre los árboles. Fui hacia él, con mucho cuidado y calma. Poco después ya estaba lo bastante cerca para echar un vistazo, y allí había un hombre tumbado en el suelo. Casi me da un telele. Tenía la cabeza envuelta en una manta, justo al lado del fuego. Me quedé sentado junto a unos matojos a unos seis pies de él sin parar de mirarlo. Ya estaba empezando a verse una luz gris del día. Poco después bostezó, se estiró y se quitó la manta, ¡y era Jim, el de la señorita Watson! ¡Vaya si me alegré de verle! Voy y digo:
vi_translation: Then I pushed the boat away from the shore a bit, and just let it drift downstream. The moon was shining brightly. Except for the places with shadows, the moonlight illuminated everything as if it were daytime. I paddled the boat for about an hour; everything was silent and asleep like stones. This time, I had reached the other end of the island. A gentle, cool breeze began to blow. This meant that the night was almost over. I kicked the water with my foot, turned the boat around, and headed towards the edge of the forest. I sat down on a fallen tree trunk, looking through the leaves. The moon had disappeared, and darkness once again covered the river. But after a while, looking up through the treetops and seeing a faint light, I knew that dawn was approaching. I took my gun and quietly approached the spot where I had seen the campfire earlier. Every minute or two, I stopped to listen. But unfortunately, I couldn't find any sign of the fire. I slowly and carefully walked to that spot. When I arrived, I saw someone lying on the ground. I thought it was a ghost. The person lying there had wrapped a piece of blanket around their head and was resting right next to the fire. I stood silently behind the bushes, about a meter away from where that person was lying, and stared intently. The sky was getting light. A moment later, the person yawned, stretched, and threw off the blanket. Oh, it turned out to be Jim, the black man who worked for Miss Watson. I was really glad to see Jim here. I spoke up:
tr_translation: So I took the paddle and moved a few steps away from the shore, then the canoe already got caught in the current and started moving through the shadows. The moon was shining and everywhere outside the shadows was lit up like daytime. I drifted for an hour, but everything was as still as a rock and in a state of complete sleep. Meanwhile, I had reached the far end of the island. A calm and cool breeze started to blow, indicating that the night was about to end. I used the paddle to turn the canoe and pressed its nose against the shore; then I got out of the canoe, took my rifle, and plunged into the forest. I sat on a log and looked at the sky through the leaves. I saw that the moon had finished its watch and the darkness was starting to cover the river like a blanket. But soon a pale line appearing at the tops of the trees indicated that the day was coming. So I took my rifle and quietly moved towards the place where I saw the campfire, stopping every two minutes to listen around. But my luck wasn't very good, I couldn't find the place where the fire was. Then, after a while, a fire burning among the trees caught my eye. I approached there very carefully and slowly. Finally, I got close enough to take a look and saw a man lying on the ground. I started trembling with fear. He had pulled the blanket over his head and his head was almost in the fire. I crouched behind the bushes about one and a half to two meters away and started watching him without taking my eyes off. The air had turned a bit gray and was gradually getting lighter. Soon the man yawned, stretched, and pulled off the blanket, it was Miss Watson's black slave Jim in front of me! I had never been so happy to see him. Jumping out from the bushes, I said, "What's up, Jim!"
es_translation: So I grabbed the paddle and went down just one or two steps from the shore, and then let the canoe drift into the shadows on its own. The moon was shining, and where there was no shadow it was almost like daylight. I was searching for almost an hour, in a silence like a tomb, while everything slept. Well, by then I had almost reached the tip of the island. A gentle, rippling, and fresh breeze started to blow, which meant that the night was about to end. I gave a stroke of the paddle and brought the canoe to the shore; then I took out the shotgun and slipped to the edge of the forest. There I sat on a log, looking through the leaves. I saw that the moon was finishing its shift and that the river was starting to get dark. But after a while, I saw a pale strip above the trees and knew that day was coming. So I took out the shotgun and advanced to where I had found that campfire, stopping to listen every minute or two. But I don't know why I wasn't lucky; it was as if I couldn't find the place. But after a while, finally, I saw a remnant of the fire's glow among the trees. I went towards it, very carefully and calmly. Soon after, I was close enough to take a look, and there was a man lying on the ground. It almost gave me a fit. He had his head wrapped in a blanket, right next to the fire. I sat next to some bushes about six feet from him, staring at him. It was already starting to get light with the gray of dawn. Soon after, he yawned, stretched, and took off the blanket, and it was Jim, Miss Watson's Jim! Boy, was I glad to see him! I go and say:

en: “Hello, Jim!” and skipped out.
vi: - Chào Jim! Rồi nhảy vụt ra.
tr: Hemen çalıların arasından çıkıp, “N’aber, Jim!” dedim.
es: —¡Hola, Jim! —y salí de un salto.
vi_translation: - Hello Jim! Then jumped out suddenly.
tr_translation: Jumping out from the bushes, I said, "What's up, Jim!"
es_translation: —Hi, Jim! —and I jumped out.

en: He bounced up and stared at me wild. Then he drops down on his knees, and puts his hands together and says:
vi: Jim giật mình nhảy chổm lên và nhìn tôi kinh hãi. Rồi hắn quỳ xuống, chắp hai tay nói:
tr: Aniden irkildi ve dehşet içinde bana baktı. Sonra dizlerinin üzerine çöktü, ellerini birleştirerek yalvarmaya başladı:
es: Él se levantó de golpe y me miró con los ojos desorbitados. Después se dejó caer de rodillas, juntó las manos y dijo:
vi_translation: Jim started and jumped up, looking at me in horror. Then he knelt down, clasped his hands, and said:
tr_translation: Suddenly, he flinched and looked at me in horror. Then he dropped to his knees, clasped his hands together, and began to plead:
es_translation: He stood up abruptly and looked at me with wide eyes. Then he dropped to his knees, clasped his hands, and said:

en: Well, I warn’t long making him understand I warn’t dead. I was ever so glad to see Jim. I warn’t lonesome now. I told him I warn’t afraid of him telling the people where I was. I talked along, but he only set there and looked at me; never said nothing. Then I says:
vi: Tôi cũng chẳng phải mất nhiều thì giờ để nói cho hắn hiểu là không phải tôi đã chết. Tôi gặp Jim ở đây mừng quá. Bây giờ tôi không còn cô đơn nữa. Tôi bảo hắn là nếu hắn có đi mách với mọi người rằng tôi ở đây thì tôi cũng không sợ. Tôi cứ nói mãi mà hắn vẫn ngồi đó nhìn tôi chẳng hé miệng. Rồi tôi bảo.
tr: Onu ölü olmadığıma inandırmam pek uzun sürmedi. Ayrıca Jim’i gördüğüme öyle seviniyordum ki içim içime sığmıyordu. Artık kendimi yalnız hissetmiyordum. Nerede olduğumu insanlara onun söylemesinden zerre kadar korkmadığımı söyledim. Ben anlattıkça anlatıyordum, ama o sadece oturmuş beni seyrediyordu; tek kelime etmedi. Bunun üzerine konuyu değiştirdim:
es: Bueno, no tardé en hacerle comprender que no estaba muerto. Estaba muy contento de ver a Jim. Ya no me sentía solo. Le dije que no me daba miedo que él dijese a la gente dónde me había visto. Yo seguía hablando, pero él continuaba allí sentado, mirándome, sin decir ni una sola palabra. Entonces voy y digo:
vi_translation: I also didn't have to spend much time explaining to him that I wasn't dead. I was so happy to meet Jim here. Now I am no longer lonely. I told him that if he went and told everyone that I was here, I wouldn't be afraid. I kept talking, but he just sat there looking at me without saying a word. Then I told him.
tr_translation: It didn't take me long to convince him that I wasn't dead. Besides, I was so happy to see Jim that I could hardly contain myself. I no longer felt alone. I told him that I wasn't the least bit afraid of him telling people where I was. I kept talking and talking, but he just sat there watching me; he didn't say a word. So I changed the subject:
es_translation: Well, it didn't take long for me to make him understand that I wasn't dead. He was very happy to see Jim. I no longer felt alone. I told him that I wasn't afraid of him telling people where he had seen me. I kept talking, but he continued sitting there, looking at me, without saying a single word. Then I go and say:

en: “It’s good daylight. Le’s get breakfast. Make up your camp fire good.”
vi: - Trời sáng rồi. Ta hãy ăn lót dạ thôi. Anh thổi lửa lên đi. - Nhóm lửa lên làm gì.
tr: “Ortalık iyice aydınlandı. Haydi kahvaltı edelim. Şu ateşi biraz canlandır.
es: —Ya es de día. Vamos a buscar el desayuno. Atiza bien la hoguera.
vi_translation: - It's morning already. Let's have a light meal. Light the fire. - Why start a fire?
tr_translation: "It's getting quite bright." "Let's have breakfast." "Stoke the fire a bit.""
es_translation: —It's already daytime. Let's go look for breakfast. Stoke the fire well.

en: “What’s de use er makin’ up de camp fire to cook strawbries en sich truck? But you got a gun, hain’t you? Den we kin git sumfn better den strawbries.”
vi: Để mà nướng dâu với mấy cái rau dại ở đây à? Nhưng mà cậu có khẩu súng đấy phải không? Có thể kiếm cái gì mà ăn hơn là quả dâu cậu ạ!
tr: “Ateşi hağlasam n’olcak ki, pişiğmek için çilek ve ottan başka şey yok. Senin tüfeğin vağ, di mi? Çilekten daha iyi biğ şey yiyebiliğiz.
es: —¿De qué vale atizar la hoguera para cocinar fresas y cosas así? Pero tú tienes una escopeta, ¿no? Así podemos comer algo mejor que fresas.
vi_translation: To roast some strawberries and wild herbs here? But you have a gun, don't you? We can find something better to eat than strawberries, my friend!
tr_translation: “What good is it to light a fire when there's nothing but strawberries and grass to cook? You have a gun, right? We can eat something better than strawberries.”
es_translation: —What good is it to stoke the fire to cook strawberries and things like that? But you have a shotgun, don't you? That way we can eat something better than strawberries.

en: “Strawberries and such truck,” I says. “Is that what you live on?”
vi: Có thể kiếm cái gì mà ăn hơn là quả dâu cậu ạ! - Dậu với rau dại, ô thế anh sống bằng những thứ đó à
tr: “Çilek ve ot mu?” dedim. “Sen sadece bunları mı yiyordun?
es: —Fresas y cosas así —voy y digo yo—. ¿Estás viviendo de eso?
vi_translation: We can find something better to eat than strawberries, my friend! - Dậu with wild vegetables, oh so you live on those things?
tr_translation: “Strawberries and grass?” I said. “Were you only eating these?”
es_translation: —Strawberries and things like that —I go and say—. Are you living off that?

en: “I couldn’ git nuffn else,” he says.
vi: - Tôi chả kiếm được cái gì khác
tr: “Başka hiçbiğ şey bulamadım,” dedi.
es: —Es lo único que encuentro —dice él.
vi_translation: - I couldn't find anything else
tr_translation: "I couldn't find anything else," he said.
es_translation: —It's the only thing I can find —he says.

en: “Why, how long you been on the island, Jim?”
vi: - ồ, thế anh ở hòn đảo này bao nhiêu lâu rồi?
tr: “Niye, ne zamandır adadasın, Jim?
es: —Pero, ¿cuánto tiempo llevas en la isla, Jim?
vi_translation: - Oh, so how long have you been on this island?
tr_translation: “Why, how long have you been on the island, Jim?”
es_translation: —But, how long have you been on the island, Jim?

en: “I come heah de night arter you’s killed.”
vi: - Tôi đến đây ngay sau cái đêm cậu bị giết đấy!
tr: “Senin öldüğün gece geldim buğaya.
es: —Vine la noche después que te mataran.
vi_translation: - I came here right after the night you were killed!
tr_translation: “I came to the bull the night you died.”
es_translation: —The night comes after they killed you.

en: “What, all that time?”
vi: - Sao, suốt từ hôm ấy đến nay à
tr: “Ne, o zamandan beri mi?
es: —¿Cómo, tanto tiempo?
vi_translation: - Really, since that day until now?
tr_translation: “What, since then?”
es_translation: —How, so long?

en: “And ain’t you had nothing but that kind of rubbage to eat?”
vi: - Thế thì chắc anh gần chết đói rồi đấy nhỉ?
tr: “O günden bu yana da sadece ot ve yemişle mi beslendin?
es: —¿Y no has comido más que cosas de ésas?
vi_translation: - So, you must be starving to death, right?
tr_translation: “Since that day, have you only been eating grass and berries?”
es_translation: —And you haven't eaten anything other than those things?

en: “No, sah—nuffn else.”
vi: - Thế thì chắc anh gần chết đói rồi đấy nhỉ?
tr: “Yok ki, sahip… başka hiçbiğ şey yok.
es: —No, señor; nada más.
vi_translation: - So, you must be starving to death, right?
tr_translation: “There isn't, master… there's nothing else.”
es_translation: —No, sir; nothing else.

en: “Well, you must be most starved, ain’t you?”
vi: - Thế thì chắc anh gần chết đói rồi đấy nhỉ?
tr: “O halde açlıktan ölüyorsundur şimdi, haksız mıyım?
es: —Bueno, debes estar muriéndote de hambre, ¿no?
vi_translation: - So, you must be starving to death, right?
tr_translation: "So, you must be starving now, am I wrong?""
es_translation: —Well, you must be starving, right?

en: “I reck’n I could eat a hoss. I think I could. How long you ben on de islan’?”
vi: - Tối tính bây giờ nếu có thì tôi ăn được nhiều lắm. Được, cậu ạ. Thế cậu ở trên hòn đảo này bao nhiêu lâu rồi?
tr: “Valla, biğ atı bilem yiyebiliğim. O kadağ açım. Sen ne zamandığ adadasın?
es: —Calculo que me podría zampar un caballo. De verdad que sí. ¿Cuánto tiempo llevas tú en la isla?
vi_translation: - If I think about it now, I can eat a lot. Alright, buddy. So, how long have you been on this island?
tr_translation: “Honestly, I could even eat a horse. I'm that hungry. How long have you been on the island?”
es_translation: —I reckon I could devour a horse. Really, I could. How long have you been on the island?

en: “Since the night I got killed.”
vi: - Từ cái đêm tôi bị giết ấy
tr: “Öldürüldüğüm geceden beri.
es: —Desde la noche que me mataron.
vi_translation: - From the night I was killed
tr_translation: "Since the night I was killed.""
es_translation: —Since the night they killed me.

en: “No! W’y, what has you lived on? But you got a gun. Oh, yes, you got a gun. Dat’s good. Now you kill sumfn en I’ll make up de fire.”
vi: - ồ, sao thế nhỉ? Thế cậu sống bằng gì? à, nhưng mà cậu có khẩu súng. Phải, cậu có súng. Thế thì tốt lắm. Bây giờ cậu đi bắn con gì đi, rồi tôi ở đây nhóm lửa lên.
tr: “Vay canına! Peki sen ne yedin? Geğçi sende tüfek vağ. Tüfekle başka, ya. Ne güzel. Haydi sen biğ şeyleğ vuğ, ben de ateşi yakacağım.
es: —¡No! y, ¿de qué has vivido? Pero tienes una escopeta. Ah, sí, tienes una escopeta. Está muy bien. Ahora tú matas algo y yo hago una hoguera.
vi_translation: - Oh, why is that? Then what do you live on? Ah, but you have a gun. Yes, you have a gun. That's very good. Now you go shoot something, and I'll stay here and start a fire.
tr_translation: “Wow! So, what did you eat? Burp, you have a gun. It's different with a gun, yeah. How nice. Come on, you shoot something, and I'll light the fire.”
es_translation: —No! And, what have you lived on? But you have a shotgun. Ah, yes, you have a shotgun. That's very good. Now you kill something and I'll make a fire.

en: So we went over to where the canoe was, and while he built a fire in a grassy open place amongst the trees, I fetched meal and bacon and coffee, and coffee-pot and frying-pan, and sugar and tin cups, and the nigger was set back considerable, because he reckoned it was all done with witchcraft. I catched a good big catfish, too, and Jim cleaned him with his knife, and fried him.
vi: Cả hai chúng tôi ra chỗ giấu xuồng. Rồi trong khi Jim nhóm bếp trên một đám cỏ giữa chỗ cây cối quanh đãng thì tôi đi lấy bánh mỡ và cà phê, lấy ấm pha cà phê; lấy cái xoong, rồi đường, rồi cốc sắt. Anh da đen rất hoảng sợ vì anh ta nghĩ rằng tất cả những thứ này đều do có phép phù thuỷ ra cả. Tôi kiếm được con cá to, Jim lấy con dao nhíp của hắn mổ cá rồi đem rán.
tr: Böylece kanonun olduğu yere gittik ve o ağaçların arasındaki çimenlik bir alanda ateş yakarken ben de bir çırpıda mısır unu, pastırma, kahve, kahve demliği, tava, şeker ve teneke maşrapa çıkardım. Jim hayret etmişti, çünkü hepsini büyüyle yaptığımı düşünmüştü. Kocaman bir de yayınbalığı tuttum ve Jim bıçağıyla içini temizleyip balığı kızarttı.
es: Así que fuimos adonde estaba la canoa y mientras él organizaba la hoguera en un claro de la hierba entre los árboles, yo fui a buscar harina y tocino y café, y cafetera y sartén y azúcar y unas tazas de hojalata, y el negro se quedó muy asombrado, porque pensó que todo lo hacía por brujería. También atrapé un buen pez gato y Jim lo limpió con su navaja y lo frió.
vi_translation: Both of us went to the place where the canoe was hidden. Then, while Jim started a fire on a patch of grass among the surrounding trees, I went to get the bacon and coffee, the coffee pot; the pan, then the sugar, and the tin cups. The black man was very frightened because he thought that all these things were the result of some witchcraft. I caught a big fish, and Jim used his pocket knife to clean it and then fried it.
tr_translation: So we went to where the cannon was, and while we were lighting a fire in a grassy area among those trees, I quickly took out cornmeal, bacon, coffee, a coffee pot, a pan, sugar, and a tin cup. Jim was astonished because he thought I had done it all by magic. I also caught a big catfish, and Jim cleaned it with his knife and fried the fish.
es_translation: So we went to where the canoe was, and while he was setting up the bonfire in a clearing in the grass among the trees, I went to get flour and bacon and coffee, and a coffee pot and a pan and sugar and some tin cups, and the black man was very astonished, because he thought I did everything by witchcraft. I also caught a good catfish and Jim cleaned it with his knife and fried it.

en: When breakfast was ready we lolled on the grass and eat it smoking hot. Jim laid it in with all his might, for he was most about starved. Then when we had got pretty well stuffed, we laid off and lazied. By-and-by Jim says:
vi: Làm xong, chúng tôi cứ nằm trên cỏ mà ăn bữa sáng nóng sốt. Jim ăn cật lực, vì hắn đã qúa đói. No nê rồi, chúng tôi nằm dài ra không buồn làm gì nữa. Rồi Jim nói:
tr: Kahvaltı hazır olunca çimenlerin üzerine kurulup sıcak sıcak mideye indirdik. Jim ne varsa ağzına tıkıyordu, çünkü açlıktan ölmek üzereydi. Karınlarımızı iyice doldurunca da uzanıp keyif çattık. Biraz sonra Jim sordu:
es: Cuando el desayuno estuvo listo nos tumbamos en la hierba y lo comimos mientras estaba calentito. Jim se puso a comer con mucha gana, pues estaba medio muerto de hambre. Cuando nos quedamos bien llenos, descansamos y nos tumbamos. Poco después va Jim y dice:
vi_translation: After finishing, we just lay on the grass and ate a hot breakfast. Jim ate vigorously because he was extremely hungry. Once full, we sprawled out, not wanting to do anything else. Then Jim said:
tr_translation: When breakfast was ready, we settled on the grass and ate it hot. Jim was stuffing everything into his mouth because he was about to die of hunger. After filling our stomachs well, we lay down and relaxed. A little later, Jim asked:
es_translation: When breakfast was ready, we lay down on the grass and ate it while it was still warm. Jim started eating with great appetite, as he was half dead from hunger. When we were full, we rested and lay down. Shortly after, Jim goes and says:

en: “But looky here, Huck, who wuz it dat ’uz killed in dat shanty ef it warn’t you?”
vi: - Nhưng này, cậu Huck, thế ra không phải là cậu thì ai bị giết trong cái nhà ấy?
tr: “O kulübede öldüğülen sen diilsen, kimdi peki, Huck?”
es: —Pero, oye, Huck, ¿a quién mataron en la cabaña si no fue a ti?
vi_translation: - But hey, Huck, if it wasn't you, then who was killed in that house?
tr_translation: "If you weren't the one who died in that cabin, then who was it, Huck?"
es_translation: —But, hey, Huck, who did they kill in the cabin if it wasn't you?

en: Then I told him the whole thing, and he said it was smart. He said Tom Sawyer couldn’t get up no better plan than what I had. Then I says:
vi: Lúc đó tôi mới kể lại đầu đuôi câu chuyện cho hắn nghe; hắn bảo thật là tài tình. Hắn nói rằng ngay Tom Sawyer cũng không thể có mẹo nào hay hơn cái của tôi được. Tôi hỏi:
tr: Ona her şeyi anlattım, akıllıca olduğunu söyledi. Tom Sawyer bile benimkinden daha iyi bir plan yapamazmış. Sonra da ben sordum:
es: Entonces le conté toda la historia y me dijo que había sido muy astuto. Dijo que Tom Sawyer no podía inventarse un plan mejor que el mío. Después voy yo y digo:
vi_translation: At that moment, I recounted the whole story to him; he said it was truly ingenious. He said that even Tom Sawyer couldn't come up with a trick better than mine. I asked:
tr_translation: I told her everything, she said it was clever. Even Tom Sawyer couldn't come up with a better plan than mine. Then I asked:
es_translation: Then I told him the whole story and he said that I had been very clever. He said that Tom Sawyer couldn't come up with a better plan than mine. Then I go and say:

en: “How do you come to be here, Jim, and how’d you get here?”
vi: - Jim, thế anh làm sao mà lại đến chỗ này, và làm thế nào mà đến đựơc?
tr: “Peki sen niye buraya geldin, Jim, ayrıca nasıl geldin?
es: —Y, ¿cómo es que estás tú aquí, Jim, cómo has llegado?
vi_translation: - Jim, how did you end up here, and how did you get here?
tr_translation: “So why did you come here, Jim, and how did you get here?”
es_translation: —And how is it that you're here, Jim, how did you get here?

en: He looked pretty uneasy, and didn’t say nothing for a minute. Then he says:
vi: Hắn có vẻ lúng túng đến một phút không nói gì, rồi mới trả lời:
tr: Önce bir keyfi kaçtı, ne diyeceğini bilemedi. Sonra konuştu:
es: Pareció ponerse nervioso y no dijo nada durante un minuto. Después va y dice:
vi_translation: He seemed puzzled for a minute, saying nothing, then he replied:
tr_translation: First, he lost his composure and didn't know what to say. Then he spoke:
es_translation: He seemed to get nervous and didn't say anything for a minute. Then he goes and says:

en: “Maybe I better not tell.”
vi: - Có lẽ tôi không nên nói thì hơn, cậu ạ
tr: “Belki söylemesem daha iyi.
es: —A lo mejor más vale que no te lo cuente.
vi_translation: - Perhaps I shouldn't say anything, my friend
tr_translation: "Maybe it's better if I don't say it.""
es_translation: —Maybe it's better if I don't tell you.

en: “Why, Jim?”
vi: - Sao thế Jim?
tr: “Niye ki, Jim?”
es: —¿Por qué, Jim?
vi_translation: - What's wrong, Jim?
tr_translation: "Why, Jim?"
es_translation: —Why, Jim?

en: “Well, dey’s reasons. But you wouldn’ tell on me ef I uz to tell you, would you, Huck?”
vi: - Vì nhiều lẽ. Nhưng nếu tôi nói với cậu thì cậu đừng nói lại với ai nhé, cậu Huck!
tr: “Şey, sebepleğ vağ çünkü. Ama eğeğ hiç kimseye söylemezsen, sana söyleğim, oluğ mu?
es: —Bueno, hay motivos. Pero tú no te chivarías si te lo contara, ¿verdad, Huck?
vi_translation: - For many reasons. But if I tell you, you mustn't tell anyone else, Huck!
tr_translation: "Well, it's because of the reason." "But if you don't tell anyone, I'll tell you, okay?""
es_translation: —Well, there are reasons. But you wouldn't snitch if I told you, would you, Huck?

en: “Blamed if I would, Jim.”
vi: - Jim, tôi thề không nói với ai cả
tr: “Söylersem iki gözüm önüme aksın.
es: —Por éstas que no, Jim.
vi_translation: - Jim, I swear I won't tell anyone
tr_translation: “If I'm lying, may I lose my eyesight.””
es_translation: —Not by these, Jim.

en: “Well, I b’lieve you, Huck. I—I run off.”
vi: - Được, tôi tin ở cậu. Tôi... tôi trốn đi đấy.
tr: “Tımam, sana inanıyoğum, Huck. Ben… kaçtım.
es: —Bueno, te creo, Huck. Me... me he escapado.
vi_translation: - Alright, I trust you. I... I'm going to run away.
tr_translation: “Alright, I believe you, Huck. I… ran away.”
es_translation: —Well, I believe you, Huck. I... I have escaped.

en: “Jim!”
vi: - Jim!
tr: “Jim!
es: —¡Jim!
vi_translation: - Jim!
tr_translation: “Jim!””
es_translation: —Jim!

en: “But mind, you said you wouldn’ tell—you know you said you wouldn’ tell, Huck.”
vi: - Đấy, cậu đã bảo là không nói mà. Cậu nhớ là cậu hứa rằng không nói lại với ai đấy, cậu Huck.
tr: “Unutma, kimseye söylemiycem dedin… biliyoğsun, kimseye söylemiycektin, Huck.
es: —Pero acuérdate que dijiste que no lo dirías... sabes que dijiste que no lo dirías, Huck.
vi_translation: - See, you said you wouldn't tell. You remember you promised not to tell anyone, Huck.
tr_translation: “Remember, you said you wouldn't tell anyone... you know, you weren't supposed to tell anyone, Huck.”
es_translation: —But remember you said you wouldn't tell... you know you said you wouldn't tell, Huck.

en: “Well, I did. I said I wouldn’t, and I’ll stick to it. Honest injun, I will. People would call me a low-down Abolitionist and despise me for keeping mum—but that don’t make no difference. I ain’t a-going to tell, and I ain’t a-going back there, anyways. So, now, le’s know all about it.”
vi: - Ừ, tôi đã nói thế rồi mà lại. Tôi bảo không nói là không nói. Tôi sẽ giữ lời hứa. Dù cho người ta có bảo tôi là tên hèn mạt, thuộc phe chống áp bức người da đen, và cho người ta khinh tôi vì đã giữ miệng thì cũng được, chẳng sao cả. Tôi sẽ không nói. Mà tôi cũng không trở về chỗ đó nữa cơ mà. Thôi, bây giờ anh kể lại tất cả đi.
tr: “Tamam, dedim. Kimseye söylemem dedim ve söylemeyeceğim. Gerçekten, asla dönmem. Herkes benim alçak bir kölelik karşıtı olduğumu söyleyecek, sessiz kaldığım için benden nefret edecek… ama hiç fark etmez. Kimseye bir şey söylemem, zaten oraya bir daha da geri dönmeyeceğim. Evet, şimdi her şeyi başından anlat bakalım.
es: —Bueno, es verdad. Dije que no y lo mantengo. De verdad de la buena. La gente me llamará maldito abolicionista y me despreciará por no decir nada, pero no me importa. No voy a acusarte y de todos modos nunca voy a volver allí. Así que ahora cuéntamelo todo.
vi_translation: - Yes, I already said that. I said I wouldn't talk, and I won't talk. I will keep my promise. Even if people call me a coward, an anti-Black oppression sympathizer, and despise me for keeping my mouth shut, it's fine, it doesn't matter. I will not speak. And I won't go back there either. Now, you tell me everything.
tr_translation: “Alright, I said. I won't tell anyone, I said, and I won't. Really, I will never go back. Everyone will say that I am a lowly anti-slavery person, they will hate me for staying silent… but it doesn't matter at all. I won't tell anyone anything, and I won't go back there anyway. Yes, now tell me everything from the beginning.”
es_translation: —Well, it's true. I said no and I stand by it. Really, truly. People will call me a damn abolitionist and despise me for not saying anything, but I don't care. I'm not going to accuse you and anyway, I'm never going back there. So now tell me everything.

en: “Well, you see, it ’uz dis way. Ole missus—dat’s Miss Watson—she pecks on me all de time, en treats me pooty rough, but she awluz said she wouldn’ sell me down to Orleans. But I noticed dey wuz a nigger trader roun’ de place considable lately, en I begin to git oneasy. Well, one night I creeps to de do’ pooty late, en de do’ warn’t quite shet, en I hear old missus tell de widder she gwyne to sell me down to Orleans, but she didn’ want to, but she could git eight hund’d dollars for me, en it ’uz sich a big stack o’ money she couldn’ resis’. De widder she try to git her to say she wouldn’ do it, but I never waited to hear de res’. I lit out mighty quick, I tell you.
vi: Đây, thế này cậu ạ. Bà cô, tức là bà Watson ấy, suốt ngày cứ dằn vặt tôi và đối đãi với tôi tệ quá lắm. Thế nhưng bà ấy vẫn bảo rằng sẽ không đem tôi xuống Orleans để bán tôi đi đâu. Mà tôi thì thấy quanh vùng gần đây có một người buôn nô lệ da đen mới tối, tôi bắt đầu sờ sợ. Thế rồi có một đêm khuya, tôi bò đến bên cửa, cửa không khép kín, tôi nghe bà ấy nói với bà goá rằng sẽ đem tôi đi Orleans bán, nhưng chưa muốn bán ngay, là vì còn có thể nèo thêm được tám trăm đồng đô la về tôi nữa. Với số tiền lớn như vậy thì chắc bà ấy không thể dừng được. Bà goá thì muốn bảo bà ấy đừng làm thế. Nhưng lúc đó tôi không chờ để nghe xem về sau thế nào. Tôi trốn đi thật nhanh. Tôi nói thật với cậu như vậy đấy.
tr: “Tamam, işte şööle oldu. Benim sahip, yani Bayan Watson, beni süğekli azağlıyoğdu ve bana kötü davğanıyoğdu, ama heğ zaman, ‘seni Oğleans’takileğe satmam’ diyoğdu. Fakat son günleğde bizim oğalağda biğ esiğ tüccağının dolaştığını fağk ettim, işkillenmeye başladım. Neyse, biğ gece geç vakit ağalık kalmış biğ kapının önünden geçeğken, bizim yaşlı sahibin dul bayana beni Oğleans’takileğe satacağını söylediğini duydum; aslında satmak istemiyoğdu, ama bana kağşılık sekiz yüz dolağ alabiliğmiş, kağşı koyamayacağı kadağ çok para. Dul bayan onu vazgeçiğmeye çalıştı, ama ben duğup daha fazla dinlemedim. Hemen kiğişi kığdım, aynen böyle işte.
es: —Bueno, mira, pasó así. La moza vieja, o sea, la señorita Watson, se pasa el tiempo metiéndose conmigo y me trata muy mal, pero siempre dijo que no me vendería en Orleans. Pero he visto que había un tratante de negros que pasaba mucho tiempo por casa y empecé a ponerme nervioso. Bueno, una noche me acerco a la puerta muy tarde y la puerta no estaba cerrada del todo y oigo a la moza vieja que dice a la viuda que me va a vender en Orleans, aunque no quería, pero que me podía sacar ochocientos dólares, y era tanto dinero que no podía resistirse. La viuda trató de hacer que prometiese que no, pero yo no esperé a oír el resto. Te aseguro que me marché a toda velocidad.
vi_translation: Here, like this, buddy. My aunt, that is Mrs. Watson, keeps tormenting me all day and treating me terribly. But she still says she won't take me down to Orleans to sell me. But I noticed that there was a new black slave trader around here last night, and I started to get scared. Then one late night, I crawled to the door, which wasn't fully closed, and I heard her telling the widow that she would take me to Orleans to sell, but she didn't want to sell me right away because she could still get eight hundred dollars more for me. With such a large amount of money, she probably couldn't resist. The widow wanted to tell her not to do that. But at that moment, I didn't wait to hear what happened next. I ran away quickly. I'm telling you the truth.
tr_translation: “Alright, here’s how it happened. My owner, that is, Miss Watson, was constantly scolding me and treating me badly, but she always said, ‘I won’t sell you to those folks in Orleans.’ But in recent days, I noticed a slave trader wandering around our place, and I started to get suspicious. Anyway, one night, late at night, as I was passing by a door left ajar, I heard our old master telling the widow that he was going to sell me to those folks in Orleans; he didn’t actually want to sell me, but he could get eight hundred dollars for me, which was too much money to resist. The widow tried to talk him out of it, but I didn’t stay to hear more. I ran away immediately, just like that.
es_translation: —Well, look, it happened like this. The old maid, that is, Miss Watson, spends her time picking on me and treats me very badly, but she always said she wouldn't sell me in Orleans. But I noticed that there was a slave trader who spent a lot of time around the house, and I started to get nervous. Well, one night I go up to the door very late, and the door wasn't completely closed, and I hear the old maid telling the widow that she's going to sell me in Orleans, even though she didn't want to, but that she could get eight hundred dollars for me, and it was so much money that she couldn't resist. The widow tried to make her promise not to, but I didn't wait to hear the rest. I assure you, I left as fast as I could.

en: “But I didn’ have no luck. When we ’uz mos’ down to de head er de islan’ a man begin to come aft wid de lantern, I see it warn’t no use fer to wait, so I slid overboard en struck out fer de islan’. Well, I had a notion I could lan’ mos’ anywhers, but I couldn’t—bank too bluff. I ’uz mos’ to de foot er de islan’ b’fo’ I found’ a good place. I went into de woods en jedged I wouldn’ fool wid raffs no mo’, long as dey move de lantern roun’ so. I had my pipe en a plug er dog-leg, en some matches in my cap, en dey warn’t wet, so I ’uz all right.”
vi: Nhưng thật tôi chẳng may. Lúc tôi vừa đến đầu hòn đảo thì có một người cầm đèn đi sau. Thấy không thể chậm trễ được, tôi lập tức nhoài người xuống nước rời hòn đảo bơi đi chỗ khác. Gớm thật, tôi tưởng chỗ nào cũng có thể lên bờ được, ấy thế mà không đâu, bờ sông chỗ nào cũng dựng đứng lên cả. Khi bơi gần đến đầu đằng kia thì hòn đảo thì tìm ra được một chỗ tốt. Tôi đi vào rừng, nghĩ bụng không thể tiếp tục dùng bè mảng được nữa, vì bè trôi như vậy thì thế nào cũng gặp ánh đèn. Tôi có cái điếu và cái bao đựng thuốc đã rách với mấy que diêm ở trong áo mà không bị dính ướt, thế là yên trí rồi.
tr: Ama şansım yaveğ gitmedi. Bu adanın neğedeyse baş tağafına geldiğimizde, adamlağdan biği feneği alıp benim oğaya doğğu yaklaştı; beklemenin hiç faydası yoktu, o yüzden sessizce suya kaydım ve adaya doğğu yüzmeye başladım. Aslında adanın heğhangi biğ yeğinden kağaya çıkağım sanmıştım, ama yok, kıyı çok sağp kayalıktı. İyi biğ yeğ bulcam diye ta adanın ucuna kadağ geldim. Hemen oğmanın içine giğmeye ve biğ daha sallağa hiç bulaşmamaya kağağ veğdim, hele içinde elleğinde feneğle adamlağ vağsa, yanına bilem yaklaşmayacaktım. Yanımda pipo ve biğaz tütün vağdı, şapkamın içinde kuğu kalmış biğaz kibğit vağdı, duğumum fena diildi.
es: »Pero no tuve suerte. Cuando habíamos llegado casi a la punta de la isla un hombre empezó a venir a popa con el farol. Vi que no valía de nada esperar, así que me dejé caer y me eché a nadar hasta la isla. Bueno, creía que podía hacer pie casi en cualquier parte, pero no; la ribera estaba demasiado empinada. Tuve que llegar casi al final de la isla antes de encontrar un buen sitio. Me metí en el bosque y pensé que no volvería a subirme en más balsas mientras siguieran andando por ahí con el farol. Tenía la pipa y un poco de picadura en la gorra que no se habían mojado, así que no había problema.
vi_translation: But truly, I was unlucky. Just as I reached the edge of the island, there was a person holding a lantern behind me. Seeing that I couldn't delay, I immediately plunged into the water, leaving the island to swim elsewhere. It was terrifying; I thought I could get ashore anywhere, but no, the riverbank was steep everywhere. When I swam close to the other end of the island, I found a good spot. I went into the forest, thinking that I couldn't continue using the raft, because drifting like that, I would surely encounter the light. I had a pipe and a torn tobacco pouch with some matches in my shirt that hadn't gotten wet, so I felt reassured.
tr_translation: But my luck did not go well. When we came to almost the other side of the island, the men took a boat and approached my side; there was no point in waiting, so I quietly slipped into the water and started swimming towards the island. Actually, I thought I could climb the rock from any part of the island, but no, the shore was very steep and rocky. I came all the way to the tip of the island to find a good place. I decided to go straight into the forest and not to get involved with any more boats, especially if there were men with guns in them, I wouldn't even approach them. I had a pipe and some tobacco with me, and there were a few matches left in my hat, my situation wasn't too bad."
es_translation: "But I wasn't lucky." "When we had almost reached the tip of the island, a man started coming aft with the lantern." "I saw that it was useless to wait, so I let myself fall and swam to the island." "Well, I thought I could touch the bottom almost anywhere, but no; the shore was too steep." "I had to go almost to the end of the island before finding a good spot." "I went into the forest and thought I wouldn't get on any more rafts while they kept walking around with the lantern." "I had the pipe and a bit of tobacco in my cap that hadn't gotten wet, so there was no problem."

en: “And so you ain’t had no meat nor bread to eat all this time? Why didn’t you get mud-turkles?”
vi: - Thế suốt từ bữa đó đến nay, anh không có thịt, có bánh gì ăn ư? Sao không kiếm củ ở dưới bùn mà ăn?
tr: “Yani o zamandan beri yiyecek etin ya da ekmeğin yok muydu? Niye kaplumbağa yakalamadın ki?
es: —¿Así que no has comido ni carne ni pan todo este tiempo? ¿Por qué no buscaste tortugas de río?
vi_translation: - So, from that day until now, you haven't had any meat or cake to eat? Why don't you find some roots in the mud to eat?
tr_translation: “So, you haven't had any meat or bread to eat since then? Why didn't you catch a turtle?”
es_translation: —So you haven't eaten either meat or bread all this time? Why didn't you look for river turtles?

en: “Well, that’s so. You’ve had to keep in the woods all the time, of course. Did you hear ’em shooting the cannon?”
vi: Đúng rồi. Thế anh có nghe thấy họ bắn súng đại bác không?
tr: “Demek öyle. Bütün vaktini ormanın içinde geçirmek zorundaydın elbette. Top seslerini duydun mu?
es: —Bueno, es verdad. Claro, has tenido que seguir en el bosque todo el tiempo. ¿Oíste cómo disparaban el cañón?
vi_translation: That's right. Did you hear them firing cannons?
tr_translation: “So that's how it is. Of course, you had to spend all your time in the forest. Did you hear the sound of the cannons?”
es_translation: —Well, it's true. Of course, you had to stay in the forest the whole time. Did you hear how they fired the cannon?

en: “Oh, yes. I knowed dey was arter you. I see um go by heah—watched um thoo de bushes.”
vi: - Có chứ. Tôi biết là họ đang tìm cậu. Tôi có trông thấy họ qua đây. Tôi nấp trong bụi nhìn ra.
tr: “Ah, evet. Seni ağadıklağını anladım. Nehiğden aşağı gidişleğini göğdüm… Çalılağın ağkasından takip ettim.
es: —Ah, sí. Sabía que te buscaban a ti. Los vi pasar por aquí... los miré entre los arbustos.
vi_translation: - Yes, I do. I know they are looking for you. I saw them passing by here. I hid in the bushes and watched.
tr_translation: “Ah, yes. I understood that you were the lord. I saw you going down the river... I followed you from behind the bushes.”
es_translation: —Ah, yes. I knew they were looking for you. I saw them pass by here... I watched them through the bushes.

en: Some young birds come along, flying a yard or two at a time and lighting. Jim said it was a sign it was going to rain. He said it was a sign when young chickens flew that way, and so he reckoned it was the same way when young birds done it. I was going to catch some of them, but Jim wouldn’t let me. He said it was death. He said his father laid mighty sick once, and some of them catched a bird, and his old granny said his father would die, and he did.
vi: Một vài con chim non ở đây bay tới, chỉ bay từng quãng ngắn một vài thước rồi lại đậu. Jim bảo đó là điềm mưa. Hắn bảo gà con bay vặt là sắp mưa nên thấy chim bay như thế cũng đoán là sắp mưa. Tôi định bắt vài con chim, nhưng Jim không cho. Hắn bảo làm thế chết đấy. Hắn nói rằng bố đẻ ra hắn trước kia có một lần ốm nặng, rồi có người khác bắt chim thì ông bảo hắn là làm như thế thì bố hắn sẽ chết. ấy thế mà chết thật.
tr: Çevrede yavru kuşlar peyda oldu, bir-iki metre uçup uçup dallara konuyorlardı. Jim bunun yağmur yağacağının alameti olduğunu söyledi. Civcivler böyle uçtuğunda bu anlama gelirmiş, o yüzden başka yavru kuşlarda da aynı anlama geleceğini tahmin ediyormuş. Birkaç tanesini yakalamak istedim, ama Jim izin vermedi. Bunun ölümle bir olduğunu söyledi. Babası bir keresinde çok kötü hastalanmış, birileri kuş yakalayınca da yaşlı ninesi babasının öleceğini söylemiş, gerçekten de ölmüş.
es: Pasaron unos pajaritos que volaban una yarda o dos cada vez y se volvían a posar. Jim dijo que era señal de que iba a llover. Dijo que eso significaba cuando lo hacían los pollitos, así que pensaba que era lo mismo cuando lo hacían los pajaritos. Yo iba a cazar algunos, pero Jim no me dejó. Dijo que traía la muerte. Dijo que su padre se puso muy enfermo una vez y alguien de su familia atrapó un pájaro y su abuelita dijo que su padre se moriría y eso fue lo que pasó.
vi_translation: A few young birds here flew over, only flying short distances of a few yards before perching again. Jim said it was a sign of rain. He said that when chicks fly erratically, it means rain is coming, so seeing birds fly like that also made him predict rain. I intended to catch a few birds, but Jim wouldn't let me. He said doing so would bring death. He said that his father once fell seriously ill, and when someone else caught birds, his father told him that doing so would cause his father to die. And indeed, he died.
tr_translation: Young birds appeared around, flying a meter or two and landing on branches. Jim said this was a sign that it would rain. When chicks flew like this, it meant rain, so he guessed it would mean the same for other young birds as well. I wanted to catch a few, but Jim didn't allow it. He said it was akin to death. Once, his father had gotten very sick, and when someone caught a bird, his old grandmother said his father would die, and indeed, he did.
es_translation: Some little birds passed by, flying a yard or two each time and then landing again. Jim said it was a sign that it was going to rain. He said that it meant the same thing when chicks did it, so he thought it was the same when little birds did it. I was going to hunt some, but Jim didn't let me. He said it brought death. He said that his father got very sick once and someone in his family caught a bird and his grandmother said that his father would die and that's what happened.

en: And Jim said you mustn’t count the things you are going to cook for dinner, because that would bring bad luck. The same if you shook the table-cloth after sundown. And he said if a man owned a beehive and that man died, the bees must be told about it before sun-up next morning, or else the bees would all weaken down and quit work and die. Jim said bees wouldn’t sting idiots; but I didn’t believe that, because I had tried them lots of times myself, and they wouldn’t sting me.
vi: Jim lại bảo là không nên tính trước mình sẽ nấu ăn bữa chiều bằng thứ gì, vì như vậy sẽ gặp điều không may. Rồi lúc mặt trời lặn mà đem rũ cái khăn trải bàn cũng thế. Hắn lại bảo người khi mặt trời mọc sáng hôm sau, những con ong ấy nó sẽ biết trước. Nếu khong thì đám ong cũng ốm liệt, không chịu làm gì nữa và cũng chết nốt, Jim bảo là giống ong không bao giờ đốt những anh ngốc. Nhưng tôi không tin như vậy, vì đã mấy lần thử rồi mà vẫn không thấy nó đốt.
tr: Ayrıca Jim akşam yiyeceğin şeyleri saymaman gerektiğini söyledi, çünkü uğursuzluk getirirmiş. Güneş battıktan sonra masa örtüsünü silkersen de aynı şey olurmuş. Bir de bir adamın arı kovanı varsa, o adam öldüğünde sonraki sabah güneş yükselmeden önce arılara haber vermek gerekirmiş, yoksa arıların hepsi zayıflar, çalışmayı bırakır ve ölürmüş. Jim arıların aptalları sokmadığını da söyledi, ama inanmadım, çünkü pek çok kez onlarla uğraşmıştım ve beni sokmamışlardı.
es: Y Jim dijo que no había que contar las cosas que iba uno a cocinar para la cena, porque traía mala suerte. Lo mismo que si se sacudía el mantel después de anochecer. Y dijo que si un hombre tenía una colmena y se moría ese hombre, había que decírselo a las abejas antes de que volviera a salir el sol a la mañana siguiente, porque si no las abejas se ponían enfermas y dejaban de trabajar y se morían. Jim dijo que las abejas no picaban a los idiotas, pero yo no me lo creí, porque me había metido con ellas docenas de veces y a mí nunca me picaban.
vi_translation: Jim also said that one should not plan ahead what to cook for dinner, as it would bring bad luck. And shaking out the tablecloth at sunset is the same. He also said that when the sun rises the next morning, the bees would already know. If not, the bees would fall ill, refuse to work, and eventually die. Jim said that bees never sting fools. But I don't believe that, because I've tried it several times and still haven't been stung.
tr_translation: Also, Jim said that you shouldn't count the things you eat in the evening, because it brings bad luck. The same thing happens if you shake the tablecloth after sunset. And if a man has a beehive, when that man dies, you need to inform the bees before the sun rises the next morning, otherwise all the bees will weaken, stop working, and die. Jim also said that bees don't sting fools, but I didn't believe it, because I had dealt with them many times and they hadn't stung me.
es_translation: And Jim said that one shouldn't talk about the things one was going to cook for dinner, because it brought bad luck. The same as if one shook the tablecloth after nightfall. And he said that if a man had a beehive and that man died, one had to tell the bees before the sun rose again the next morning, because if not, the bees would get sick and stop working and die. Jim said that bees didn't sting idiots, but I didn't believe it, because I had messed with them dozens of times and they never stung me.

en: I had heard about some of these things before, but not all of them. Jim knowed all kinds of signs. He said he knowed most everything. I said it looked to me like all the signs was about bad luck, and so I asked him if there warn’t any good-luck signs. He says:
vi: Trước đấy, tôi đã từng nghe nói những chuyện ấy nhưng không được nghe tất cả mọi thứ. Jim biết các thứ điềm báo hiệu. Hắn bảo hắn biết hầu hết. Tôi nói hình như tôi thấy tất cả mọi điềm báo hiệu đều là báo những chuyện chẳng may cả, nên tôi hỏi Jim xem có cái nào báo hiệu tốt không? Jim nói:
tr: Anlattıklarından bazılarını daha önce duymuştum, ama hepsini duymamıştım. Jim her türlü alameti tanıyordu. Hemen her şeyi bildiğini söyledi. Bunun üzerine anlaşıldığı kadarıyla bütün alametlerin uğursuzluk getirdiğini söyledim ve şans getiren alametler olup olmadığını sordum. Şöyle dedi:
es: Algunas de esas cosas ya las había oído yo decir antes, pero no todas ellas. Jim se sabía montones de señales de ésas. Dijo que se las sabía casi todas. Yo dije que me parecía que todas las señales traían mala suerte, así que le pregunté si había alguna señal de buena suerte. Y va y dice:
vi_translation: Before that, I had heard about those things but hadn't heard everything. Jim knew the omens. He said he knew most of them. I said it seemed to me that all the omens were bad, so I asked Jim if there were any good omens. Jim said:
tr_translation: Some of the things you told me I had heard before, but I hadn't heard all of them. Jim knew all kinds of signs. He said he knew almost everything. Upon this, I said that apparently all signs bring bad luck and asked if there were any signs that bring good luck. He said:
es_translation: Some of those things I had already heard before, but not all of them. Jim knew a bunch of those signs. He said he knew almost all of them. I said that it seemed to me that all the signs brought bad luck, so I asked him if there was any sign of good luck. And he goes and says:

en: “Mighty few—an’ dey ain’t no use to a body. What you want to know when good luck’s a-comin’ for? Want to keep it off?” And he said: “Ef you’s got hairy arms en a hairy breas’, it’s a sign dat you’s agwyne to be rich. Well, dey’s some use in a sign like dat, ’kase it’s so fur ahead. You see, maybe you’s got to be po’ a long time fust, en so you might git discourage’ en kill yo’sef ’f you didn’ know by de sign dat you gwyne to be rich bymeby.”
vi: Jim nói: - ít lắm. Và những cái đó cũng chẳng ích lợi gì cho ai cả. Cậu muốn biết để làm gì, muốn giữ lấy nó à? Rồi Jim lại nói: - Nếu ở cánh tay và ngực mình có nhiều lông thì đó là dấu hiệu sắp giầu to đấy. Điềm như thế thì còn có ích; vì càng có nhiều lông càng may mắn. Cậu thấy không, có thể là thời gian đầu mình nghèo khó. Nhưng nếu không biết trước rằng đó là điềm mình sẽ giầu thì có thể chán nản mà tự tử mất.
tr: “Çok az… onlağın da zaten kimseye faydası yok. Niye meğak ediyoğsun ki şans ne zaman yüzüne gülcek diye? Şansı kendinden uzak tutasın diye mi?” Ayrıca ekledi: “Kollağın ve göğsün kıllıysa eğeğ, o halde sen eğ ya da geç zengin oluğsun. İşte böyle biğ alamet şans getiğiğ, ama geğçi çok uzun zaman sonğa getiğebiliğ. Anladın sen? Belki de ilk başta uzun zaman beklemen geğeklidiğ, bu yüzden sen alameti tanımazsın ve zengin edecek alametleği bilmezsin, maazallah belki de hüsğana uğğayıp kendini bile öldüğebiliğsin.
es: —Muy pocas, y no le valen a nadie. ¿Para qué quieres saber cuándo viene la buena suerte? ¿Quieres que no llegue? —y añadió—: Si tienes los brazos peludos y el pecho peludo, es señal de que vas a ser rico. Bueno, eso vale de algo, porque siempre es para dentro de mucho tiempo. Sabes, a lo mejor tienes que ser pobre mucho tiempo antes, y entonces podrías desanimarte y matarte, si no supieras por esa señal que con el tiempo vas a ser rico.
vi_translation: - Very little. And those things are of no use to anyone. Why do you want to know, do you want to keep it? Then Jim said again: - If you have a lot of hair on your arms and chest, it's a sign that you're about to get rich. Such an omen can be useful; the more hair you have, the luckier you are. You see, at first, you might be poor. But if you don't know in advance that it's a sign you'll become rich, you might get discouraged and commit suicide.
tr_translation: “Very little… and even that is of no use to anyone. Why do you care so much about when luck will smile on you? Is it to keep luck away from yourself?” He also added: “If your arms and chest are hairy, then you will either soon or eventually become rich. This is such a sign that brings luck, but sometimes it can take a very long time to come. Do you understand? Maybe at first, you need to wait a long time, so you don't recognize the sign and don't know the signs that will make you rich, God forbid, you might even end up in despair and kill yourself.”
es_translation: —Very few, and they are of no use to anyone. Why do you want to know when good luck is coming? Do you want it not to come? —and he added—: If you have hairy arms and a hairy chest, it's a sign that you are going to be rich. Well, that is worth something, because it is always for a long time in the future. You know, maybe you have to be poor for a long time first, and then you might get discouraged and kill yourself, if you didn't know from that sign that in time you are going to be rich.

en: “Have you got hairy arms and a hairy breast, Jim?”
vi: - Thế anh có nhiều lông tay không, Jim?
tr: “Senin kolların ve göğsün kıllı mıdır; Jim?
es: —¿Tú tienes pelos en los brazos y en el pecho?
vi_translation: - Do you have a lot of arm hair, Jim?
tr_translation: “Are your arms and chest hairy, Jim?”
es_translation: —Do you have hair on your arms and chest?

en: “What’s de use to ax dat question? Don’t you see I has?”
vi: - Hỏi như vậy có ích gì, cậu không nhìn thấy tôi có đấy à
tr: “Bu da soğu mu yani? Öyle olduğunu göğmüyoğ musun?
es: —¿Y para qué me lo preguntas? ¿No ves que sí?
