Hace unos días estaba yo hablando con un par de viejos que viven al lado en la cabaña de troncos y dijeron que casi nadie va a esa isla de allá que llaman la isla de Jackson. «¿Y ahí no vive nadie?», pregunto yo. «No, nadie», dicen. Yo no dije más, pero he estado pensándolo. Estaba casi segura de que había visto humo por allí, hacia la punta de la isla, hacía un día o dos, así que me digo: «A lo mejor el negro está escondido ahí; en todo caso», digo yo, «merece la pena buscar en esa isla». Desde entonces no he visto más humo, así que a lo mejor se ha ido, si es que era él; pero mi marido va a ir a verlo, con otro. Tuvo que ir río arriba, pero volvió hoy y se lo dije en cuanto llegó hace dos horas.
vi_translation: - Oh, how naive you are, child. It's not every day that people can easily earn three hundred dollars. Some people think that the black man hasn't fled far from here. I think so too, but I haven't told anyone. A few days ago, I talked to an old couple in the wooden house next door, and they said that few people go to that distant island called Jackson Island. I asked if there was anyone on that island. They said: no, there's no one there at all. I didn't say anything more, but I kept thinking about it. Since I live nearby, I'm sure I saw smoke rising from that direction, from the head of that island, a few days ago. I wondered if the black man might be hiding on the island. I said that anyway, it would be worth the effort to go to that island and search it. Since that day, I haven't seen any more smoke, so I think if there was a black man, he must have left by now. But my husband will go up there to check, along with another person. He went upriver and just returned today. Two hours ago, as soon as he stepped into the house, I told him about it.
tr_translation: "Man, how naive you are! Do you think three hundred dollars are picked up from the roadside every day? Some people think the black man isn't very far from here. I'm one of them... but I haven't told anyone. A few days ago, I was talking to the old couple living in the wooden cabin next door, and they said almost no one goes to the island they call Jackson Island. I asked if no one lives there. No; no one lives there, they said. I didn't say anything else, but I started thinking. I'm almost sure I saw smoke there, it was rising from the head of the island a day or two ago. So, I said to myself, can't the black man be hiding there; in any case, it's worth going there to investigate. I haven't seen smoke since that day, maybe he's gone now, that is, if it was him: Though my husband will go and check, he'll take a man with him. He had gone up the river, but he returned today and as soon as he arrived two hours ago, I told him everything."
es_translation: —Well, you really are innocent! Do you think three hundred dollars grow on trees every day? Some believe the black man hasn't gone very far. And neither do I... But I haven't told anyone. A few days ago, I was talking with a couple of old folks who live next door in the log cabin, and they said that almost no one goes to that island over there called Jackson Island. “And no one lives there?” I asked. “No, no one,” they said. I didn't say anything more, but I've been thinking about it. I was almost sure I had seen smoke over there, towards the tip of the island, a day or two ago, so I said to myself: “Maybe the black man is hiding there; in any case,” I said, “it's worth searching that island.” Since then, I haven't seen any more smoke, so maybe he's gone, if it was him; but my husband is going to check it out, with another person. He had to go upriver, but he came back today, and I told him as soon as he arrived two hours ago.

en: I had got so uneasy I couldn’t set still. I had to do something with my hands; so I took up a needle off of the table and went to threading it. My hands shook, and I was making a bad job of it. When the woman stopped talking I looked up, and she was looking at me pretty curious and smiling a little. I put down the needle and thread, and let on to be interested—and I was, too—and says:
vi: Lúc này tôi thật bối rối vô cùng, không thể ngồi im được nữa. Tôi không cử động hai bàn tay một tí mới được, tôi nhặt chiếc kim khâu để trên bàn và xâu chỉ. Tay tôi run lẩy bẩy, không xâu được. Người đàn bà ngừng nói trông lên, và nhìn tôi với một vẻ hơi là lạ, rồi mỉm cười. Tôi bỏ kim chỉ xuống làm ra vẻ như chính mình cũng đang quan tâm đến chuyện ấy, tôi nói:
tr: Öyle diken üstündeydim ki yerimde duramıyordum artık. Ellerimle bir şeyler yapmam gerekiyordu; bu yüzden masanın üzerindeki dikiş iğnesini aldım ve ip geçirmeye çalıştım. Ellerim titriyordu ve ipi bir türlü delikten geçiremiyordum. Kadın konuşmayı kesti, başımı kaldırdığında bana merakla baktığını ve hafifçe gülümsediğini gördüm. İğneyle ipliği bırakıp ilgilenmiş gibi yaptım; aslında ilgilenmiştim de. Şöyle dedim:
es: Me había puesto tan nervioso que no podía estarme quieto. Tenía que hacer algo con las manos, así que saqué una aguja de la mesa y me puse a enhebrarla. Me temblaban las manos y lo hice muy mal. Cuando la mujer dejó de hablar levanté la mirada y me estaba mirando muy curiosa y sonriendo un poco. Dejé la aguja y el hilo y puse cara de interés —y la verdad es que estaba interesado— y voy y digo:
vi_translation: At this moment, I was extremely confused, unable to sit still any longer. I had to move my hands a bit, so I picked up the sewing needle on the table and threaded it. My hands were trembling, and I couldn't thread it. The woman stopped talking, looked up, and gazed at me with a somewhat strange expression, then smiled. I put the needle and thread down, pretending to be interested in the story as well, and said:
tr_translation: I was so on edge that I couldn't stay still anymore. I needed to do something with my hands; so I took the sewing needle on the table and tried to thread it. My hands were trembling and I couldn't get the thread through the hole. The woman stopped talking, and when I looked up, I saw that she was looking at me curiously and smiling slightly. I pretended to be interested in the needle and thread; in fact, I was interested. I said:
es_translation: I had gotten so nervous that I couldn't stay still. I had to do something with my hands, so I took a needle from the table and started threading it. My hands were shaking and I did it very poorly. When the woman stopped talking, I looked up and she was looking at me very curiously and smiling a little. I put down the needle and thread and put on an interested face —and the truth is, I was interested— and I go and say:

en: “Three hundred dollars is a power of money. I wish my mother could get it. Is your husband going over there to-night?”
vi: - Ba trăm đô la, món tiền ấy to lắm. Cháu cũng mong cho mẹ cháu có được số tiền như thế. Thế chồng bà đêm nay có đi hòn đảo ấy không?
tr: “Üç yüz dolar az para değil. Annem alsa ne iyi olurdu. Kocanız bu gece oraya gidecek mi?
es: —Trescientos dólares es un montón de dinero. Ojalá que lo tuviera mi madre. ¿Va a ir allí su marido esta noche?
vi_translation: - Three hundred dollars, that's a lot of money. I also hope my mother can get such an amount. Is your husband going to that island tonight?
tr_translation: “Three hundred dollars is not a small amount of money. It would be great if my mother took it. Will your husband go there tonight?”
es_translation: —Three hundred dollars is a lot of money. I wish my mother had it. Is her husband going there tonight?

en: “Oh, yes. He went up-town with the man I was telling you of, to get a boat and see if they could borrow another gun. They’ll go over after midnight.”
vi: - ồ, có chứ. Ông ấy đang lên phố với các người tôi vừa nói ban nãy để kiếm một cái xuồng và để xem có mượn được khẩu súng nữa không. Khoảng quá nửa đêm là các ông ấy sẽ đi đấy.
tr: “Evet, tabii. Bahsettiğim adamla birlikte kasabaya bir kayık bulmaya gitti, bir de fazladan tüfek ödünç almaya çalışacak. Gece yarısından sonra gidecekler.
es: —Ah, sí. Ha ido a la parte alta del pueblo con el hombre que te he dicho, a buscar un bote y ver si les prestan otra escopeta. Van a cruzar después de medianoche.
vi_translation: - Oh, yes. He is going to town with the people I just mentioned to get a boat and see if he can borrow a gun. Around midnight, they will leave.
tr_translation: “Yes, of course. He went to the town with the man I mentioned to find a boat, and he will also try to borrow an extra rifle. They will leave after midnight.”
es_translation: —Ah, yes. He has gone to the upper part of the town with the man I told you about, to look for a boat and see if they can borrow another shotgun. They are going to cross after midnight.

en: “Couldn’t they see better if they was to wait till daytime?”
vi: - Sao không đợi để đến ban ngày có nhìn rõ hơn không?
tr: “Günün ışımasını bekleseler daha iyi görmezler mi?
es: —¿No verían mejor si esperasen hasta que fuera de día?
vi_translation: - Why not wait until daytime when it's clearer to see?
tr_translation: “Wouldn't they see better if they waited for the daylight?”
es_translation: —Wouldn't they see better if they waited until it was daytime?

en: “Yes. And couldn’t the nigger see better, too? After midnight he’ll likely be asleep, and they can slip around through the woods and hunt up his camp fire all the better for the dark, if he’s got one.”
vi: - Phải, nhưng ban ngày tên da đen cũng lại nhìn mình dễ hơn. Qua nửa đêm tên da đen có thể ngủ say, như vậy các ông có thể đi luồn qua rừng và nếu như nó có dốt lửa trong đêm tối thì có thể dễ tìm hơn.
tr: “Evet. Ama o zaman zenci de daha iyi görmez mi? Gece yarısından sonra muhtemelen uyuyor olur, böylece ormanın içinden sessizce ilerleyip etrafı arayabilirler ve ateş yanıyorsa daha rahat bulurlar.
es: —Sí. Y, ¿no vería también mejor el negro? Después de medianoche lo más probable es que esté dormido, y se pueden meter por el bosque y buscar su hoguera mejor si está oscuro, si es que tiene una hoguera.
vi_translation: - Yes, but during the day the black man can also see us more easily. After midnight, the black man might be fast asleep, so you can sneak through the forest, and if he lights a fire in the dark, it will be easier to find him.
tr_translation: “Yes. But wouldn't the black man see better then? After midnight, he would probably be asleep, so they could quietly move through the forest and search the surroundings, and if there's a fire, they would find it more easily.”
es_translation: —Yes. And, wouldn't he also see better in the dark? After midnight, he is most likely asleep, and they can go through the forest and look for his campfire better if it's dark, if he has a campfire.

en: “I didn’t think of that.”
vi: - Không chắc chắn như vậy đâu.
tr: “Bu hiç aklıma gelmemişti.
es: —No se me había ocurrido.
vi_translation: - It's not that certain.
tr_translation: "This had never occurred to me.""
es_translation: —It hadn't occurred to me.

en: The woman kept looking at me pretty curious, and I didn’t feel a bit comfortable. Pretty soon she says,
vi: Người đàn bà nhìn tôi với vẻ nhóc mách, làm cho tôi càng ngồi chẳng yên. Ba ta hỏi:
tr: Kadın bana merakla bakmaya devam ediyordu ve ben de kendimi hiç rahat hissetmiyordum. Biraz sonra tekrar konuştu:
es: La mujer me seguía mirando muy curiosa y yo no me sentía nada cómodo. Y después de un momento va y pregunta:
vi_translation: The woman looked at me with a tattletale expression, making me even more uneasy. She asked:
tr_translation: The woman kept looking at me with curiosity, and I didn't feel comfortable at all. A little later, she spoke again:
es_translation: The woman kept looking at me very curiously and I didn't feel comfortable at all. And after a moment she goes and asks:

en: “What did you say your name was, honey?”
vi: - Lúc nãy, cháu nói tên là gì nhỉ?
tr: “Adım ne demiştin, şekerim?
es: —¿Cómo habías dicho que te llamabas, guapa?
vi_translation: - Earlier, what did you say your name was?
tr_translation: “What did you say my name was, sweetheart?”
es_translation: —How did you say your name was, beautiful?

en: Somehow it didn’t seem to me that I said it was Mary before, so I didn’t look up—seemed to me I said it was Sarah; so I felt sort of cornered, and was afeared maybe I was looking it, too. I wished the woman would say something more; the longer she set still the uneasier I was. But now she says:
vi: Quái, hình như lúc nãy không phải tôi nói là Mary hay sao ấy. Nghĩ thế nhưng tôi không nhìn lên. Hình như lũc nãy tôi nói là Sara thì phải. Tôi cảm thấy như đang bị dồn vào góc tường, đâm ra sợ không dám ngước lên nhìn nữa. Bà ta càng im lặng, tôi càng thấy bối rối. Nhưng rồi bà ta hỏi:
tr: İlk sorduğunda Mary demedim gibime gelmişti, o yüzden başımı kaldırıp bakamadım; galiba Sarah demiştim; o yüzden kendimi köşeye sıkışmış hissediyordum ve kadının bunu yüzümden okumasından korkuyordum. Kadının bir şeyler daha söylemesini diledim; ne kadar süre sessizce oturursak o kadar tedirgin oluyordum. Sonunda kadın konuştu:
es: No sé por qué pero no me parecía haber dicho que era Mary antes, así que no levanté la vista... Me parecía que había dicho que era Sarah, así que me sentí como acorralado y tenía miedo de que a lo mejor se me notara. Tenía ganas de que la mujer dijera algo más; cuanto más tiempo pasaba callada más incómodo me sentía. Pero entonces va y dice:
vi_translation: Strange, didn't I just say it was Mary? Thinking that, but I didn't look up. It seems like I said it was Sara earlier. I felt like I was being cornered, so scared that I didn't dare to look up anymore. The quieter she was, the more confused I felt. But then she asked:
tr_translation: When she first asked, I felt like I didn't say Mary, so I couldn't lift my head to look; I think I said Sarah; that's why I felt cornered and was afraid that the woman would read it from my face. I wished the woman would say something more; the longer we sat in silence, the more uneasy I became. Finally, the woman spoke:
es_translation: I don't know why, but it didn't seem to me that I had said it was Mary before, so I didn't look up... It seemed to me that I had said it was Sarah, so I felt cornered and was afraid that maybe it would show. I wanted the woman to say something else; the longer she stayed silent, the more uncomfortable I felt. But then she goes and says:

en: “Honey, I thought you said it was Sarah when you first come in?”
vi: - Tôi tưởng khi nãy mới vào cháu nói là Sara cơ mà?
tr: “İlk içeri girdiğinde adının Sarah olduğunu söyledin sanmıştım, şekerim, öyle değil mi?
es: —Guapa, creí que al llegar habías dicho que te llamabas Sarah.
vi_translation: - I thought you said it was Sara when you first came in?
tr_translation: “When you first came in, I thought you said your name was Sarah, honey, isn't that right?”
es_translation: —Beautiful, I thought you said your name was Sarah when you arrived.

en: “Oh, yes’m, I did. Sarah Mary Williams. Sarah’s my first name. Some calls me Sarah, some calls me Mary.”
vi: - Vâng, đúng thế đấy ạ. Sara Mary William, Sara là tên đầu của cháu. Có người gọi là Sara, có người gọi là Mary.
tr: “Evet, bayan, öyle dedim. Sarah Mary Williams. Sarah benim ilk adım. Kimileri Sarah der; kimileri Mary.
es: —Ay, sí, señora, es verdad. Sarah Mary Williams. Me llamó Sarah de primer nombre. Algunos me llaman Sarah y otros Mary.
vi_translation: - Yes, that's right. Sara Mary William, Sara is my first name. Some people call me Sara, some people call me Mary.
tr_translation: “Yes, ma'am, that's what I said. Sarah Mary Williams. Sarah is my first name. Some call me Sarah; some call me Mary.”
es_translation: —Oh, yes, ma'am, it's true. Sarah Mary Williams. They called me Sarah as a first name. Some call me Sarah and others Mary.

en: “Oh, that’s the way of it?”
vi: - à ra thế đấy?
tr: “Öyle mi?”
es: —Ah, ¿eso es lo que pasa?
vi_translation: - Oh, really?
tr_translation: "Is that so?"
es_translation: —Ah, is that what's happening?

en: I was feeling better then, but I wished I was out of there, anyway. I couldn’t look up yet.
vi: Nhưng tôi mong dù sao cũng không phải ngồi đó nữa. Tôi vẫn chưa nhìn lên được.
tr: Kendimi daha iyi hissediyordum, ama yine de bir an önce oradan çıkmak istiyordum. Hâlâ başımı kaldırıp kadına bakamamıştım.
es: Ya me estaba sintiendo mejor, pero con ganas de marcharme de allí de todas maneras. Todavía no me atrevía a levantar la mirada.
vi_translation: But I still hope I don't have to sit there anymore. I still can't look up.
tr_translation: I was feeling better, but I still wanted to get out of there as soon as possible. I still couldn't lift my head to look at the woman.
es_translation: I was already feeling better, but I still wanted to leave there anyway. I still didn't dare to lift my gaze.

en: Well, the woman fell to talking about how hard times was, and how poor they had to live, and how the rats was as free as if they owned the place, and so forth and so on, and then I got easy again. She was right about the rats. You’d see one stick his nose out of a hole in the corner every little while. She said she had to have things handy to throw at them when she was alone, or they wouldn’t give her no peace. She showed me a bar of lead twisted up into a knot, and said she was a good shot with it generly, but she’d wrenched her arm a day or two ago, and didn’t know whether she could throw true now. But she watched for a chance, and directly banged away at a rat; but she missed him wide, and said “Ouch!” it hurt her arm so. Then she told me to try for the next one. I wanted to be getting away before the old man got back, but of course I didn’t let on. I got the thing, and the first rat that showed his nose I let drive, and if he’d a stayed where he was he’d a been a tolerable sick rat. She said that was first-rate, and she reckoned I would hive the next one. She went and got the lump of lead and fetched it back, and brought along a hank of yarn which she wanted me to help her with. I held up my two hands and she put the hank over them, and went on talking about her and her husband’s matters. But she broke off to say:
vi: Nhưng rồi bà ta lại bắt sang chuyện nào là đời sống vất vả, nghèo khổ như thế nào, rồi nào là ở đây chuột chạy ra chạy vào tự do là chúng nó làm chủ cái nhà này ấy, vân vân... . Lúc đó tôi cũng dễ chịu hơn, Bà ta nói liền về chuyện chuột. Cứ chốc chốc lại thấy một con chuột thò mõm ra khỏi cái lỗ ở góc nhà. Bà ta bảo là phải luôn luôn cầm một cái gì trong tay để lúc nào ở nhà một mình thì ném chuột. Không thì lũ chuột chả để cho ba ra ngồi yên. Bà ta đưa cho tôi xem một thỏi chì đã vặn xoắn lại như cái nút, và bảo vẫn dùng cái đó để ném chuột rẩt tốt. Nhưng mới đây vài ngày bà ta bị sái tay vẫn để ý rình, rồi bất thình lình ném băng một cái, nhưng còn cách con chuột rất xa. Bà ta kêu ối một tiếng; thế là lại đau tay. Rồi bà ta bảo tôi ném thử con sau. Tôi muốn bỏ ra đi trước khi chồng bà ta về, nhưng rồi thế nào lại không đi được. Tôi vớ lấy thỏi chì, chờ lúc có một con chuột nữa thò mõm ra là tôi ném liều. Thỏi chì trúng con chuột nằm lăn ra đó, trúng một con chuột ốm. Bà ta bảo giỏi thật, và tưởng tôi sẽ ném con sau nữa. Bà ta đi nhặt thỏi chì lại, rồi đem đến một cuộn sợi và bảo tôi gỡ giúp. Tôi chìa hai tay ra, bà ta mắc cuộn sợi vào tay tôi và lại tiếp tục nói chuyện về vợ chồng bà ta nữa. Nhưng rồi bà ta im bật rồi nói:
tr: Bunun üzerine kadın geçinmenin güçlüğünden bahsetmeye koyuldu, nasıl yoksulluk içinde yaşadıklarını anlattı, fareler sanki ev kendilerininmiş gibi cirit atıyorlarmış, falan filan, ben de kendimi daha rahat hissetmeye başladım. Fareler konusunda haklıydı. Zaman zaman köşedeki delikten burunlarını çıkarıp baktıklarını görebiliyordunuz. Kadın tek başınayken yanında farelere fırlatmak için bir şeyler bulundurduğunu, aksi halde ona rahat vermediklerini anlattı. Bana büküle büküle top edilmiş kurşundan bir çubuk gösterdi ve genelde bu kurşunu çok isabetli fırlattığını, ama bir-iki gün önce kolunu incittiği için isabet ettirememekten korktuğunu söyledi. Yine de fırsatını kolladı ve gördüğü bir fareye doğru fırlattı, ama kurşun fareyi ıskalamıştı, ayrıca “Off!” diyerek kolunu tuttu. Bir sonraki fareyi benim vurmamı istedi. Yaşlı adam gelmeden önce oradan tüymek istiyordum, ama elbette paldır küldür çıkamazdım. Kurşun topunu elime aldım ve ilk gördüğüm fareye doğru fırlattım, şayet ilk durduğu yerde kalsaydı hali dumandı. Kadın atışımın bir numara olduğunu ve bir sonrakini indireceğimden kuşku duymadığını söyledi. Gidip kurşunu getirdi, sonra da bir yün çilesi çıkarıp yardım etmemi istedi. İki elimi uzattım ve çileyi geçirdi, sonra da kocasının işlerinden bahsetmeye devam etti. Ama bir ara durdu:
es: Bueno, la mujer se puso a hablar de lo difíciles que estaban los tiempos y lo pobres que eran y cómo corrían las ratas por todas partes, como si la casa fuera de ellas, y de esto y de aquello, y me empecé a sentir más tranquilo. Tenía razón en lo de las ratas. A cada rato se veía una que asomaba el hocico por un agujero en un rincón. Dijo que tenía que tener cosas a mano para tirárselas cuando estaba sola, porque si no, no la dejaban en paz. Me enseñó una barra de plomo retorcido en forma de nudo y dijo que en general tenía buena puntería, pero que hacía uno o dos días se había dislocado un brazo y no sabía si ahora podía apuntar bien. Esperó una oportunidad y en seguida le tiró la barra a una rata, pero le falló por mucho y dijo, «¡ay!», que le dolía mucho el brazo. Entonces me pidió que probara yo con la siguiente. Yo quería marcharme antes de que volviera su viejo, pero claro que no lo dije. Agarré la barra y a la primera rata que asomó el hocico se la tiré, y de haberse quedado donde estaba no se habría sentido nada bien. Dijo que yo tiraba de primera y que calculaba que a la siguiente le daría. Se levantó a buscar la barra y la trajo y también una madeja de lana con la que quería que la ayudara yo. Levanté las dos manos y ella me puso la madeja y siguió hablando de cosas suyas y de su marido. Pero se interrumpió para decir:
vi_translation: But then she started talking about how hard and poor life was, and how here the mice ran in and out freely as if they owned the house, and so on... At that moment, I felt more at ease, and she immediately started talking about the mice. Every now and then, a mouse would poke its snout out of a hole in the corner of the house. She said that one must always hold something in hand to throw at the mice whenever alone at home. Otherwise, the mice wouldn't let you sit still. She showed me a twisted piece of lead, like a knot, and said it was very good for throwing at mice. But just a few days ago, she sprained her hand while keeping an eye out, then suddenly threw it, but it was still far from the mouse. She cried out in pain; and her hand hurt again. Then she asked me to try throwing at the next mouse. I wanted to leave before her husband came home, but somehow I couldn't. I grabbed the piece of lead, waited for another mouse to poke its snout out, and threw it recklessly. The lead hit the mouse, and it fell over, hitting a thin mouse. She said I was really good, and thought I would throw at the next one too. She picked up the piece of lead, then brought a spool of thread and asked me to help untangle it. I held out my hands, she placed the spool of thread in them, and continued talking about her and her husband. But then she fell silent and said:
tr_translation: Upon this, the woman began to talk about the difficulty of making a living, how they lived in poverty, mice running around as if the house belonged to them, and so on, and I started to feel more at ease. She was right about the mice. From time to time, you could see them poking their noses out of the hole in the corner. She explained that when she was alone, she kept something to throw at the mice, otherwise they wouldn't leave her in peace. She showed me a rod made of twisted lead and said that she usually threw it very accurately, but she was afraid she might miss because she had injured her arm a couple of days ago. Still, she watched for an opportunity and threw it at a mouse she saw, but the lead missed the mouse, and she held her arm saying "Ouch!" She asked me to hit the next mouse. I wanted to leave before the old man came, but of course, I couldn't just rush out. I took the lead ball in my hand and threw it at the first mouse I saw; if it had stayed where it was, it would have been in trouble. The woman said my throw was top-notch and she had no doubt I would hit the next one. She went and fetched the lead, then took out a skein of yarn and asked for my help. I extended my hands and she looped the skein over them, then continued talking about her husband's work. But she paused at one point:
es_translation: Well, the woman started talking about how difficult times were and how poor they were and how rats were running everywhere, as if the house belonged to them, and about this and that, and I began to feel calmer. She was right about the rats. Every now and then you could see one poking its snout out of a hole in a corner. She said she had to have things on hand to throw at them when she was alone, because otherwise, they wouldn't leave her in peace. She showed me a twisted lead bar shaped like a knot and said that she generally had good aim, but that a day or two ago she had dislocated an arm and didn't know if she could aim well now. She waited for an opportunity and immediately threw the bar at a rat, but missed by a lot and said, "Oh!", that her arm hurt a lot. Then she asked me to try with the next one. I wanted to leave before her old man came back, but of course, I didn't say that. I grabbed the bar and threw it at the first rat that poked its snout out, and if it had stayed where it was, it wouldn't have felt very good. She said I threw very well and that she figured I would hit the next one. She got up to fetch the bar and brought it back along with a skein of yarn with which she wanted me to help her. I raised both hands and she placed the skein on them and continued talking about her things and her husband. But she interrupted herself to say:

en: “Keep your eye on the rats. You better have the lead in your lap, handy.”
vi: - Để ý nhìn chuột nhé. Cháu cứ cầm sẵn thỏi chì trong tay đi.
tr: “Farelere karşı tetikte ol. En iyisi kurşun senin kucağında dursun.
es: —Sigue atenta a las ratas. Más vale que tengas la barra a mano, en el regazo.
vi_translation: - Keep an eye on the mouse. Just hold the lead bar in your hand.
tr_translation: "Be on guard against the mice. It's best if the bullet stays in your lap."
es_translation: —Stay alert for the rats. You better keep the bar handy, on your lap.

en: So she dropped the lump into my lap just at that moment, and I clapped my legs together on it and she went on talking. But only about a minute. Then she took off the hank and looked me straight in the face, and very pleasant, and says:
vi: Bà ta thả thỏi chì vào vạt váy của tôi vừa lúc tôi khép hai chân lại để giữ lấy thỏi chì. Bà ta lại nói chuyện. Nhưng chỉ được một lúc. Rồi bà ta nhắc cuốn sợi ra nhìn thẳng vào mặt tôi vẻ vui đùa hỏi:
tr: Kurşun topu daha konuşurken kucağıma doğru fırlattı ve ben düşürmemek için bacaklarımı birleştirirken o konuşmaya devam etti. Ama sadece bir dakika konuştu. Nihayet çileyi elimden aldı, doğruca yüzüme baktı ve tatlı bir sesle sordu:
es: Así que me echó el trozo de plomo al regazo justo en aquel momento y yo apreté las piernas para acogerlo y ella siguió hablando. Pero sólo un minuto o así. Después me quitó la madeja y me miró a los ojos y me dijo muy amable:
vi_translation: She dropped the lead ingot into the hem of my skirt just as I closed my legs to hold the ingot in place. She started talking again. But only for a moment. Then she lifted the spool, looked straight at my face with a playful expression, and asked:
tr_translation: He threw the lead ball towards my lap while still talking, and as I clamped my legs together to avoid dropping it, he continued to speak. But he only spoke for a minute. Finally, he took the burden from my hands, looked straight into my face, and asked in a sweet voice:
es_translation: So she threw the piece of lead into my lap right at that moment and I squeezed my legs to catch it and she kept talking. But only for a minute or so. Then she took the skein from me and looked me in the eyes and said very kindly:

en: “Come, now, what’s your real name?”
vi: - Này, nói thật đi, tên cháu là gì?
tr: “Söyle bakalım… gerçek adın nedir?
es: —Vamos, ahora dime cómo te llamas de verdad.
vi_translation: - Hey, tell me the truth, what is your name?
tr_translation: “Tell me… what is your real name?”
es_translation: —Come on, now tell me what your real name is.

en: “Wh—what, mum?”
vi: - Bà nói sao?
tr: “Ne dediniz, bayan?
es: —¿Cooo? ¿Cómo, señora?
vi_translation: - What did you say?
tr_translation: "What did you say, ma'am?""
es_translation: —Whaaat? What, ma'am?

en: “What’s your real name? Is it Bill, or Tom, or Bob?—or what is it?”
vi: - Tên thật của cô là gì? Là Bin, là Tom hãy Bob? hay là gì?
tr: “Gerçek adın nedir? Bill mi, Tom mu, Bob mu?.. Nedir?
es: —¿Cómo te llamas de verdad? ¿Bill o Tom, o Bob? ¿Cómo te llamas?
vi_translation: - What is your real name? Is it Bin, Tom, or Bob? Or what is it?
tr_translation: “What is your real name? Is it Bill, Tom, or Bob?.. What is it?”
es_translation: —What is your real name? Is it Bill or Tom, or Bob? What is your name?

en: I reckon I shook like a leaf, and I didn’t know hardly what to do. But I says:
vi: Tôi tưởng mình run lên một chiếc lá, và thật cũng không biết làm thế nào. Nhưng tôi trả lời:
tr: O anda yaprak gibi titremeye başladım, ne yapacağımı bilemiyordum. “Ne olur zavallı bir kızcağızla dalga geçmeyin, bayan,” dedim.
es: Creo que me puse a temblar como una hoja, sin saber qué hacer. Pero dije:
vi_translation: I thought I was trembling like a leaf, and truly didn't know what to do. But I replied:
tr_translation: At that moment, I started trembling like a leaf, I didn't know what to do. “Please don't make fun of a poor girl, ma'am,” I said.
es_translation: I think I started trembling like a leaf, not knowing what to do. But I said:

en: “Please to don’t poke fun at a poor girl like me, mum. If I’m in the way here, I’ll—”
vi: - Xin bà đừng trêu ghẹo một cô gái khổ sở như cháu. Nếu cháu ngồi đây mà có làm phiền bà thì cháu xin...
tr: “Ne olur zavallı bir kızcağızla dalga geçmeyin, bayan,” dedim. “Size engel oluyorsam, ben hemen…
es: —Por favor, no se ría de una pobre chica como yo, señora. Si le molesto, me...
vi_translation: - Please don't tease a miserable girl like me. If my sitting here bothers you, then I apologize...
tr_translation: “Please don't make fun of a poor girl, ma'am,” I said. “If I am bothering you, I will immediately…””
es_translation: —Please, do not laugh at a poor girl like me, ma'am. If I bother you, I...

en: “No, you won’t. Set down and stay where you are. I ain’t going to hurt you, and I ain’t going to tell on you, nuther. You just tell me your secret, and trust me. I’ll keep it; and, what’s more, I’ll help you. So’ll my old man if you want him to. You see, you’re a runaway ’prentice, that’s all. It ain’t anything. There ain’t no harm in it. You’ve been treated bad, and you made up your mind to cut. Bless you, child, I wouldn’t tell on you. Tell me all about it now, that’s a good boy.”
vi: - Không, không, cháu đừng đi đâu. Hãy cứ ngồi yên đây. Tôi không làm hại gì cháu đâu, và cũng không đi nói cho ai biết về cháu đâu, cháu cứ tin ở tôi, cháu nói thật với tôi đi. Tôi sẽ giữ kín cho cháu nữa, tôi sẽ giúp đỡ cháu. Tôi sẽ bảo cả chồng tôi giữ kín cho cháu nữa, nếu cháu muốn. Cháu hiểu không, cháu chỉ là một con ngựa non khờ dại bỏ bày mà chạy đi thôi, chẳng có gì khác. Mà có sao đâu cơ chứ, Cháu bi đối đãi khổ sở rồi cháu quyết tâm là phải trốn đi chứ gì. Khổ, tội nghiệp quá, tôi sẽ không nói với ai về cháu đâu. Bây giờ thì hãy nói hết cả cho tôi nghe đi, nào cậu... con trai ngoan ngoãn.
tr: “Hayır, gitmiyorsun. Yerine otur ve hiçbir yere kıpırdama. Sana zararım dokunmaz, seni ele vermeyeceğimden de emin olabilirsin. Sadece sırrını aç, bana güvenebilirsin. Sır tutabilirim; üstelik sana yardımım da dokunabilir. Hatta istersen kocam da sana yardım eder. Sen kaçak bir çıraksın işte, besbelli. Ne olacak ki? Bunda kötü bir şey yok. Sana hoyrat davranmışlar ve sen de kaçmaya karar vermişsin. Ben senin iyiliğini düşünüyorum, evladım, seni niye ele vereyim ki? Haydi anlat bakalım… uslu bir çocuk ol.
es: —No, nada de eso. Siéntate y quédate donde estás. No voy a hacerte nada ni voy a delatarte. Me cuentas tu secreto y confías en mí. Yo te lo guardo, y lo que es más, te ayudo. Mi hombre, lo mismo, si tú quieres. Ya entiendo que eres un aprendiz y te has escapado y nada más. No es nada. No tiene nada de malo. Te han tratado mal y has decidido escaparte. Hijo mío, yo no te delataría. Ahora cuéntamelo todo, sé buen chico.
vi_translation: - No, no, don't go anywhere. Just sit still here. I won't harm you, and I won't tell anyone about you, trust me, tell me the truth. I will keep it a secret for you, I will help you. I will even tell my husband to keep it a secret for you, if you want. Do you understand, you are just a naive young horse that ran away from the herd, nothing more. But it's okay, you were treated harshly so you decided to run away, right? It's so pitiful, I won't tell anyone about you. Now tell me everything, come on, good boy.
tr_translation: “No, you are not going. Sit down and don't move anywhere. I won't harm you, and you can be sure that I won't betray you. Just reveal your secret, you can trust me. I can keep a secret; moreover, I might be able to help you. If you want, even my husband can help you. It's clear that you are a runaway apprentice. So what? There's nothing wrong with that. They treated you harshly, and you decided to run away. I'm thinking of your well-being, my child, why would I betray you? Come on, tell me… be a good child.”
es_translation: —No, nothing like that. Sit down and stay where you are. I'm not going to do anything to you nor will I betray you. You tell me your secret and trust me. I'll keep it, and what's more, I'll help you. My man, the same, if you want. I understand that you are an apprentice and you have run away and nothing more. It's nothing. There's nothing wrong with it. They have treated you badly and you have decided to run away. My son, I wouldn't betray you. Now tell me everything, be a good boy.

en: So I said it wouldn’t be no use to try to play it any longer, and I would just make a clean breast and tell her everything, but she musn’t go back on her promise. Then I told her my father and mother was dead, and the law had bound me out to a mean old farmer in the country thirty mile back from the river, and he treated me so bad I couldn’t stand it no longer; he went away to be gone a couple of days, and so I took my chance and stole some of his daughter’s old clothes and cleared out, and I had been three nights coming the thirty miles. I traveled nights, and hid daytimes and slept, and the bag of bread and meat I carried from home lasted me all the way, and I had a-plenty. I said I believed my uncle Abner Moore would take care of me, and so that was why I struck out for this town of Goshen.
vi: Tôi nghĩ bụng cứ đóng kịch mãi thì cũng chẳng ăn thua gì, tôi sẽ thú thật với bà ta và nói hết cả ra, nhưng bà ta phải không nuốt lời hứa mới được. Thế rồi tôi nói với bà ta rằng bố mẹ tôi đã chết cả, rồi pháp luật đã trói buộc tôi phải ở với một người chủ điền vừa già vừa độc ác ở vùng cách xa con sống đến ba mươi dặm. Người ta cư xử với tôi tệ quá nên không thể ở đấy được nữa. Nhân lúc lão chủ điền kia vắng nhà vài ngày, tôi mới thừa cơ bỏ trốn và ăn cắp mấy cái quần áo của con gái lão ta, đi ròng rã ba đêm nay bây giờ tôi mới tới đây. Đêm thì đi, ngày thì nấp vào một nơi ngủ. Cái bọc bánh với thịt mang theo chỉ đủ ăn dọc đường. Tôi lại nói là tôi tin rằng ông bác tôi là Abner Moore sẽ nuôi tôi, vì vậy tôi mới lần mò đến vùng Goshen này.
tr: Bunun üzerine ben de artık rol yapmamın anlamı kalmadığını söyledim, tamamen dürüst davranacak ve ona her şeyi anlatacaktım, ama sözünden dönmemeliydi. Ardından ona babam ve annemin öldüğünü, beni nehirden otuz mil uzakta adi bir ihtiyar çiftçinin yanına verdiklerini anlattım, bana o kadar kötü davranmıştı ki artık dayanamayacak hale gelmiştim; birkaç günlüğüne seyahate çıkmıştı, ben de fırsatı değerlendirip kızının eski kıyafetlerinden bazılarını yürütmüş, oradan kaçmıştım; üç gecedir yollardaydım ve otuz mil gelmiştim; geceleri seyahat ediyordum, gündüzleri saklanıyor ve uyuyordum; evden bir çanta dolusu et ve ekmek almıştım, azığım daha uzun süre yeterdi. Dayım Abner Moore’un beni evine alacağım düşünüyordum, bu yüzden Goshen kasabasına gelmiştim.
es: Así que dije que no servía de nada seguir fingiendo y que me dejaría de mentiras y se lo contaría todo, pero que tenía que cumplir su promesa. Después le dije que mi padre y mi madre habían muerto y que la ley me había asignado a un campesino viejo y mezquino que vivía por lo menos a treinta millas del río y que me trataba tan mal que no lo pude seguir aguantando; se había ido un par de días y yo aproveché la oportunidad para robar un vestido viejo de su hija y largarme, y había tardado tres noches en recorrer las treinta millas. Viajaba de noche y me escondía a dormir de día, y la bolsa de pan y de carne que me había llevado me había durado todo el camino, y todavía me quedaba. Dije que creía que mi tío Abner Moore se haría cargo de mí y que por eso había venido a este pueblo de Goshen.
vi_translation: I thought to myself that continuing to act would be futile, so I decided to confess to her and tell her everything, but she must keep her promise. Then I told her that both my parents had died, and the law had forced me to live with an old and cruel landlord in a place thirty miles away from the river. They treated me so badly that I couldn't stay there any longer. Taking advantage of the landlord's absence for a few days, I seized the opportunity to escape and stole some clothes from his daughter, traveling for three nights straight until I arrived here. I traveled by night and hid somewhere to sleep during the day. The bundle of bread and meat I brought was just enough to eat along the way. I also said that I believed my uncle, Abner Moore, would take care of me, which is why I made my way to this Goshen area.
tr_translation: Then I said that there was no point in pretending anymore, I would act completely honestly and tell him everything, but he must not go back on his word. Then I told him that my father and mother had died, that they had given me to a mean old farmer thirty miles away from the river, and that he had treated me so badly that I could no longer bear it; he had gone on a trip for a few days, so I took the opportunity to steal some of his daughter's old clothes and ran away; I had been on the road for three nights and had come thirty miles; I was traveling at night, hiding and sleeping during the day; I had taken a bag full of meat and bread from the house, and my provisions would last longer. I thought my Uncle Abner Moore would take me in, so I had come to the town of Goshen.
es_translation: So I said that there was no point in continuing to pretend and that I would stop lying and tell him everything, but he had to keep his promise. Then I told him that my father and mother had died and that the law had assigned me to an old and mean farmer who lived at least thirty miles from the river and treated me so badly that I couldn't stand it anymore; he had gone away for a couple of days and I took the opportunity to steal an old dress from his daughter and run away, and it had taken me three nights to cover the thirty miles. I traveled at night and hid to sleep during the day, and the bag of bread and meat I had taken with me had lasted the whole way, and I still had some left. I said that I believed my uncle Abner Moore would take care of me and that was why I had come to this town of Goshen.

en: “Goshen, child? This ain’t Goshen. This is St. Petersburg. Goshen’s ten mile further up the river. Who told you this was Goshen?”
vi: - Goshen đâu, cậu bé ơi! Đây không phải là Goshen, đây là Peterburg. Goshen ở mãi mười dặm đi ngược lên trên sông nữa cơ mà. Ai bảo với cậu đây là Goshen?
tr: “Goshen mi, yavrum? Burası Goshen değil ki. Burası St. Petersburg. Goshen nehrin on mil yukarısında. Burasının Goshen olduğunu da kim söyledi sana?
es: Dije que creía que mi tío Abner Moore se haría cargo de mí y que por eso había venido a este pueblo de Goshen. —¿Goshen, chico? Esto no es Goshen. Esto es Saint Petersburg. Goshen está diez millas río arriba. ¿Quién te dijo que esto era Goshen?
vi_translation: - Goshen, where are you, boy! This is not Goshen, this is Petersburg. Goshen is still ten miles up the river. Who told you this was Goshen? - Really?
tr_translation: “Is this Goshen, my dear? This isn't Goshen. This is St. Petersburg. Goshen is ten miles up the river. Who told you this was Goshen?”
es_translation: —Goshen, kid? This is not Goshen. This is Saint Petersburg. Goshen is ten miles upriver. Who told you this was Goshen?

en: “Why, a man I met at daybreak this morning, just as I was going to turn into the woods for my regular sleep. He told me when the roads forked I must take the right hand, and five mile would fetch me to Goshen.”
vi: - Vậy ư? Thế mà có một người cháu gặp lúc còn tờ mờ sáng hôm nay, lúc cháu định rẽ vào rừng để ngủ, bảo cháu đến ngã ba thì rẽ bên phải, rồi đi năm dặm nữa thì đến Goshen.
tr: “Bu sabah gün ağarırken, uyumak için ağaçların arasına gitmeden önce bir adamla karşılaştım. Bana yol ayrımına geldiğimde sağa dönmemi söyledi, beş mil gittikten sonra Goshen’e çıkarmışım.
es: —Bueno, un hombre con el que me encontré al amanecer esta mañana, justo cuando iba a meterme en el bosque para dormir, como siempre. Me dijo que los caminos se dividían y que debía seguir el de la derecha y al cabo de cinco millas estaría en Goshen.
vi_translation: But there was a person I met at dawn today, when I was about to turn into the forest to sleep, who told me to turn right at the fork, then go five more miles to reach Goshen.
tr_translation: "This morning at dawn, before going to sleep among the trees, I met a man. He told me to turn right when I reached the fork in the road, and after five miles, I would reach Goshen."
es_translation: —Well, a man I met at dawn this morning, just as I was about to go into the forest to sleep, as always. He told me that the roads split and that I should follow the one on the right and after five miles I would be in Goshen.

en: “He was drunk, I reckon. He told you just exactly wrong.”
vi: - Chắc hắn ta say rượu. Hắn nói thế là hoàn toàn sai rồi.
tr: “Sarhoştu herhalde. Sana yolu tam ters tarif etmiş.
es: —Debía de estar borracho. Te dijo exactamente lo contrario de lo que es.
vi_translation: - He must be drunk. What he said is completely wrong.
tr_translation: “He was probably drunk. He gave you the directions completely wrong.”
es_translation: —He must have been drunk. He told you exactly the opposite of what it is.

en: “Well, he did act like he was drunk, but it ain’t no matter now. I got to be moving along. I’ll fetch Goshen before daylight.”
vi: - Vâng, trông hắn ta đúng là say rượu. Nhưng thôi thì bây giờ làm thế nào được. Cháu lại phải đi quãng đường nữa. Cháu sẽ tìm đến Goshen trước khi trời sáng.
tr: “Tevekkeli değil, sallanıp duruyordu, ama bunun bir faydası yok şimdi. Yola devam etmeliyim. Şafak sökmeden önce Goshen’e varırım.
es: —Bueno, sí que parecía que estuviera borracho, pero ya no importa. Tengo que seguir. Llegaré a Goshen antes de que amanezca.
vi_translation: - Yes, he does look drunk. But well, there's nothing we can do about it now. I have to travel a bit further. I'll reach Goshen before dawn.
tr_translation: “No wonder, it was swaying back and forth, but that’s of no use now. I must continue on my way. I will reach Goshen before dawn breaks.”
es_translation: —Well, he did seem drunk, but it doesn't matter anymore. I have to keep going. I'll reach Goshen before dawn.

en: “Hold on a minute. I’ll put you up a snack to eat. You might want it.”
vi: - Khoan đã, hãy chờ một lát, để tôi lấy cái gì cho cậu ăn qua loa đã. Hẳn là cậu phải đói rồi.
tr: “Bir dakika bekle. Yanına yiyecek bir şeyler katayım. Giderken yersin.
es: —Espera un momento. Voy a darte algo de comer. A lo mejor te hace falta.
vi_translation: - Wait a moment, let me get you something to eat quickly. You must be hungry.
tr_translation: “Wait a minute. Let me pack you something to eat. You can eat it on the way.”
es_translation: —Wait a moment. I'm going to give you something to eat. Maybe you need it.

en: So she put me up a snack, and says:
vi: Bà ta đem cho tôi ăn rồi lại hỏi:
tr: Elime biraz yiyecek tutuşturduktan sonra devam etti:
es: Así que me preparó algo de comer y dijo:
vi_translation: She gave me food and then asked:
tr_translation: After stuffing some food into my hand, he continued:
es_translation: So he prepared something for me to eat and said:

en: “Say, when a cow’s laying down, which end of her gets up first? Answer up prompt now—don’t stop to study over it. Which end gets up first?”
vi: - Này cậu, khi một con bò đang nằm dưới đất mà nó đứng đằng nào lên trước? Trả lời ngay, không được nghĩ. Đằng nào đứng lên trước?
tr: “Söyle bakalım… yatan bir inek ilk önce ne tarafından kalkar? Çabuk cevap ver ama… üzerinde düşünme. Hangi tarafı önce kalkar?
es: —Oye, cuando una vaca se echa, ¿por qué parte se levanta? Responde rápido, vamos; no te pares a pensarlo. ¿Por qué lado se levanta?
vi_translation: - Hey, when a cow is lying on the ground, which end does it stand up from first? Answer immediately, no thinking allowed. Which end stands up first?
tr_translation: “Tell me... when a cow is lying down, which part of it gets up first? Answer quickly, don't think about it. Which part gets up first?”
es_translation: —Hey, when a cow lies down, which part does it get up from? Answer quickly, come on; don't stop to think about it. Which side does it get up from?

en: “The hind end, mum.”
vi: - Đằng đuôi
tr: “Arka tarafı, bayan.
es: —Por el de atrás, señora.
vi_translation: - The tail end
tr_translation: "The back side, ma'am."
es_translation: —Through the back, ma'am.

en: “The for’rard end, mum.”
vi: - Đằng đuôi
tr: “Ön tarafı kalkar, bayan.
es: —Por el de delante, señora.
vi_translation: - The tail end
tr_translation: "The front will lift, ma'am."
es_translation: —Through the front one, ma'am.

en: “Which side of a tree does the moss grow on?”
vi: - Thế rêu mọc trên thân cây thì mọc ở phía nào?
tr: “Ağacın hangi tarafında yosun olur?
es: —¿De qué lado de un árbol crece el musgo?
vi_translation: - So, which side of the tree does moss grow on?
tr_translation: “On which side of the tree does moss grow?”
es_translation: —On which side of a tree does moss grow?

en: “If fifteen cows is browsing on a hillside, how many of them eats with their heads pointed the same direction?”
vi: - Nếu mười lăm con bò ăn cỏ trên đồi thì bao nhiêu con châu đầu về một phía?
tr: “Bir yamaçta on beş inek otluyorsa kaç tanesinin başı aynı yöne dönüktür?
es: —Si hay quince vacas pastando en una cuesta, ¿cuántas de ellas comen con las cabezas mirando en la misma dirección?
vi_translation: - If fifteen cows graze on the hill, how many face the same direction?
tr_translation: “If fifteen cows are grazing on a hillside, how many of them have their heads turned in the same direction?”
es_translation: —If there are fifteen cows grazing on a slope, how many of them eat with their heads facing the same direction?

en: “The whole fifteen, mum.”
vi: - Cả mười lăm con
tr: “Hepsinin, bayan.
es: —Las quince, señora.
vi_translation: - All fifteen of them
tr_translation: "All of them, ma'am."
es_translation: —Three o'clock, ma'am.

en: “Well, I reckon you have lived in the country. I thought maybe you was trying to hocus me again. What’s your real name, now?”
vi: - Được, như thế là tôi biết cậu đã ở nông thôn. Tôi tưởng cậu lại định bịp tôi nữa. Thế bây giờ tên thật của cậu là gì?
tr: “Pekâlâ, çiftlik hayatını bildiğin belli oluyor. Belki beni yine kandırıyorsundur diye korktum. Gerçek adın ne bakalım?
es: —Bueno, supongo que es cierto que has vivido en el campo. Creí que a lo mejor pensabas engañarme otra vez. ¿Y cómo te llamas de verdad?
vi_translation: - Alright, so I know you were in the countryside. I thought you were going to trick me again. So what's your real name now?
tr_translation: “Alright, it’s clear that you know farm life. I was afraid that you might be deceiving me again. What is your real name, let’s see?”
es_translation: —Well, I suppose it's true that you've lived in the countryside. I thought maybe you were trying to deceive me again. And what's your real name?

en: “George Peters, mum.”
vi: - George Peter bà ạ.
tr: “George Peters, bayan.
es: —George Peters, señora.
vi_translation: - George Peter is old.
tr_translation: "George Peters, ma'am.""
es_translation: —George Peters, ma'am.

en: “Well, try to remember it, George. Don’t forget and tell me it’s Elexander before you go, and then get out by saying it’s George Elexander when I catch you. And don’t go about women in that old calico. You do a girl tolerable poor, but you might fool men, maybe. Bless you, child, when you set out to thread a needle don’t hold the thread still and fetch the needle up to it; hold the needle still and poke the thread at it; that’s the way a woman most always does, but a man always does t’other way. And when you throw at a rat or anything, hitch yourself up a tiptoe and fetch your hand up over your head as awkward as you can, and miss your rat about six or seven foot. Throw stiff-armed from the shoulder, like there was a pivot there for it to turn on, like a girl; not from the wrist and elbow, with your arm out to one side, like a boy. And, mind you, when a girl tries to catch anything in her lap she throws her knees apart; she don’t clap them together, the way you did when you catched the lump of lead. Why, I spotted you for a boy when you was threading the needle; and I contrived the other things just to make certain. Now trot along to your uncle, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, and if you get into trouble you send word to Mrs. Judith Loftus, which is me, and I’ll do what I can to get you out of it. Keep the river road all the way, and next time you tramp take shoes and socks with you. The river road’s a rocky one, and your feet’ll be in a condition when you get to Goshen, I reckon.”
vi: - Được, cậu nhớ đây nhé, George. Trước khi đi cậu hãy nhớ nói với tôi rằng cậu là Alexander rồi đến ngoài đường thì nói rằng tôi bắt gặp được cậu thì cậu chính là tên George Alexander. Mà đừng có mặc cái đồ vải cũ ấy đi đến chỗ nào có đàn bà. Cậu đóng giả cô gái nghèo thì được đấy nhưng đàn ông người ta vẫn để ý. Thật tội nghiệp cho cậu, lúc nào xỏ chỉ vào lỗ kim thì đừng có giữ cho im cái kim rồi hãy xỏ chỉ vào lỗ kim; đàn bà bao giờ người ta cũng làm thế, còn đàn ông thì khác. Rồi khi nào ném chuột hay ném vật gì khác thì hãy nhớ kiễng chân lên một tí, rồi giơ tay lên qua đầu làm ra vẻ hết sức ngựơng nghịu, và ném cách xa con chuột chừng một vài thước. Phải ném thế nào trông nó có vẻ cứng nhắc suốt từ bả vai xuống, y như có một cái chốt ở vai mà xoay cánh tay đi, như vậy nó mới ra con gái, chứ không phải nếm bằng cổ tay hay khuỷu tay và giang rộng cánh tay sang một phía như con trai. Rồi lại còn nhớ rằng khi một cô gái cũng nhích hai đâu gối ra chứ không kẹp vào nhau như cậu làm khi nãy để giữ thỏi chì. Lạ gì đâu, ngay từ cậu xỏ chỉ vào lỗ kim, tôi đã biết rằng cậu là con trai, cho nên tôi mới thử lại cái đó để biết chắc chắn. Thôi, bây giờ đi tìm bác cậu đi, Sara Mary William Georgo Alexander Peter. Nếu có gặp chuyện gì lôi thôi thì nhắn về cho tôi, tức là bà Judith Loftus. Tôi có thể làm gì đựơc tôi sẽ làm để giúp đỡ cậu. Cứ theo con đường ven sông, và lần sau có đi bộ xa thế thì phải đi giầy đi tất vào, Đường ven sông có nhiều sỏi đá; tôi tính đến được Goshen thì chân cậu sẽ đau lắm đấy.
tr: “Pekâlâ, bunu unutmamaya çalış, George. Unutma ve gitmeden önce bana adının Elexander olduğunu söyleme, hele foyan ortaya çıkınca adının George-Elexander olduğu yalanını hiç uydurma. Ayrıca bu eski püskü basma elbiseyle kadınların yanına yaklaşma. Kız taklidin epeyce kötü, ama belki erkekleri kandırabilirsin. Aşk olsun be yavrum, bir daha ipi iğneye geçirmen gerektiğinde ipi sabit tutup iğnenin deliğini geçirmeye çalışma; iğneyi sabit tut ve ipi delikten geçir… Kadınlar daima böyle yapar, ama erkekler her zaman tersini yapar. Ayrıca fareye filan bir şey fırlatacaksan parmak uçlarına kadar yüksel, elini olabildiğince biçimsizce başının üstüne kaldır, sonra da farenin iki-üç metre uzağına at. Doğrudan omzunu kullanarak fırlat, sanki kolun omuzdan hareket ediyormuş gibi… Kızlar nasıl yapıyorsa öyle; bileğini ve dirseğini kırarak, kolunu yana doğru açarak erkek gibi atma. Bir de unutma, bir kız kucağına düşen bir şeyi yakalamak için dizlerini iki yana ayırır; kurşun topunu yakalarken senin yaptığın gibi dizlerini birleştirmez. İlk başta ipi iğneden geçirmeye çalıştığında erkek olduğunu anladım; sonra da emin olmak için diğerlerini yaptırdım. Haydi şimdi dayına git bakalım Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, başın belaya girerse de Bayan Judith Loftus’a, yani bana haber gönder, elimden bir şey gelirse yaparım. Nehir yolu boyunca devam et ve bir daha dışarı çıktığında yanına ayakkabı ve çorap almayı unutma. Nehir yolu taşlıdır ve Goshen’e vardığında ayakların pek iyi durumda olmayacaktır.
es: —Bueno, George, trata de recordarlo. No te vayas a olvidar y a decirme que es Elexander antes de irte y luego quieras arreglarlo diciendo que es George Elexander cuando te pesque. Y no te acerques a mujeres con ese vestido viejo. Haces bastante mal de chica, pero quizá puedas engañar a los hombres. Y recuerda, hijo, que cuando te pongas a enhebrar una aguja no tienes que sostener el hilo quieto y llevar la aguja hacia él: ten quieta la aguja y pasa el hilo por ella; así es como lo hacen prácticamente todas las mujeres, pero los hombres siempre lo hacen al revés. Y cuando le tires algo a una rata o algo así, recuerda que te tienes que poner de puntillas y levantar la mano por encima de la cabeza lo más torpe que puedas y fallarle a la rata por seis o siete pies. Tira con el brazo tieso a partir del hombro, como si tuvieras un eje, como las chicas, y no con la muñeca y el codo con el brazo a un lado, como hacen los chicos. Y recuerda que cuando una chica trata de recoger algo en el regazo separa las rodillas, no las junta como hiciste tú cuando te tiré la barra de plomo. Pero hombre, si me di cuenta de que eras un chico en cuanto te pusiste a enhebrar la aguja, y las demás cosas las hice para estar segura. Ahora, vete corriendo con tu tío, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, y si te metes en algún lío manda un recado a la señora Judith Loftus, que soy yo, y haré lo que pueda por sacarte de él. Sigue siempre por el camino del río, y la próxima vez que te eches a andar lleva zapatos y calcetines. La carretera del río tiene muchas piedras y calculo que vas a tener los pies hechos polvo cuando llegues a Goshen.
vi_translation: - Alright, remember this, George. Before you go, make sure to tell me that you are Alexander, and then when you are outside, say that I caught you and that you are George Alexander. And don't wear those old clothes when you go to places with women. You can pretend to be a poor girl, but men will still notice. Poor you, whenever you thread a needle, don't hold the needle still and then thread it; women always do that, but men do it differently. And whenever you throw a mouse or anything else, remember to stand on tiptoe a bit, raise your hand over your head to look very awkward, and throw it a few feet away from the mouse. You have to throw in a way that looks stiff all the way from the shoulder down, as if there's a pin in your shoulder that rotates your arm, so it looks like a girl, not throwing with your wrist or elbow and spreading your arm out to one side like a boy. And also remember that when a girl moves, she spreads her knees apart, not keeping them together like you did earlier to hold the lead piece. It's no wonder, from the moment you threaded the needle, I knew you were a boy, so I tested that to be sure. Now, go find your uncle, Sara Mary William George Alexander Peter. If you run into any trouble, send word to me, Mrs. Judith Loftus. I'll do whatever I can to help you. Follow the river path, and next time you walk such a long distance, wear shoes and socks. The river path is full of pebbles; by the time you get to Goshen, your feet will hurt a lot.
tr_translation: “Alright, try not to forget this, George. Don't forget and don't tell me your name is Elexander before you leave, and especially don't make up the lie that your name is George-Elexander when your cover is blown. Also, don't approach women in that shabby calico dress. Your imitation of a girl is quite bad, but maybe you can fool the men. For heaven's sake, child, the next time you need to thread a needle, don't try to push the needle's eye through the thread; keep the needle steady and pass the thread through the eye... Women always do it this way, but men always do the opposite. Also, if you're going to throw something at a mouse or whatever, rise up on your toes, lift your hand as awkwardly as possible over your head, and then throw it two or three meters away from the mouse. Throw directly using your shoulder, as if your arm is moving from the shoulder... Do it like girls do; don't throw like a man by bending your wrist and elbow and opening your arm to the side. And remember, a girl spreads her knees apart to catch something that falls into her lap; she doesn't keep her knees together like you did when catching the lead ball. I realized you were a boy when you first tried to thread the needle; then I had you do the others to be sure. Now go to your uncle, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, and if you get into trouble, send word to Mrs. Judith Loftus, that is, to me, and I'll do what I can to help. Continue along the river path and don't forget to take shoes and socks with you the next time you go out. The river path is rocky, and your feet won't be in good shape by the time you reach Goshen.”
es_translation: —Well, George, try to remember it. Don't forget and tell me it's Elexander before you leave and then try to fix it by saying it's George Elexander when I catch you. And don't go near women with that old dress. You do a pretty bad job as a girl, but maybe you can fool the men. And remember, son, when you start threading a needle, you don't have to hold the thread still and bring the needle to it: keep the needle still and pass the thread through it; that's how practically all women do it, but men always do it the other way around. And when you throw something at a rat or something like that, remember that you have to stand on tiptoe and raise your hand above your head as clumsily as you can and miss the rat by six or seven feet. Throw with a stiff arm from the shoulder, as if you had an axis, like girls do, and not with the wrist and elbow with the arm to the side, like boys do. And remember that when a girl tries to pick something up in her lap, she spreads her knees apart, not together like you did when I threw the lead bar at you. But man, I knew you were a boy as soon as you started threading the needle, and the other things I did to be sure. Now, run along to your uncle, Sarah Mary Williams George Elexander Peters, and if you get into any trouble, send a message to Mrs. Judith Loftus, who is me, and I'll do what I can to get you out of it. Always follow the river road, and next time you set out, wear shoes and socks. The river road has a lot of stones, and I figure your feet will be worn out by the time you get to Goshen.

en: I went up the bank about fifty yards, and then I doubled on my tracks and slipped back to where my canoe was, a good piece below the house. I jumped in, and was off in a hurry. I went up-stream far enough to make the head of the island, and then started across. I took off the sun-bonnet, for I didn’t want no blinders on then. When I was about the middle I heard the clock begin to strike, so I stops and listens; the sound come faint over the water but clear—eleven. When I struck the head of the island I never waited to blow, though I was most winded, but I shoved right into the timber where my old camp used to be, and started a good fire there on a high and dry spot.
vi: Tôi đi ngược lên phía trên sông độ dăm chục thước rồi quay lộn lại, vụt chạy đến chỗ để xuồng, ở dưới căn nhà đó một quãng. Tôi nhảy vào xuồng, vội vã chèo đi. Tôi đi ngược lên khá xa, đến tận đầu hòn đảo, rồi tạt ngang. Tôi cởi mở chiếc mũ ra, vì bây giờ cũng chẳng cần phải cải trang làm gì nữa. Khi nãy đi đến giữa chừng thấy tiếng chuông vang đi, nhoà trên mặt nước nhưng nghe còn rõ, đã mười một giờ. Đến đầu hòn đảo, mặc dầu gió đang thổi mạnh tôi cũng không cần lánh xuống nữa mà cứ nhằm đâm thẳng vào chỗ có khúc gỗ mà tôi đã nấp hồi mới tới và đã từng đốt lửa ở một nơi cao ráo.
tr: Nehir boyunca elli metre yukarı çıktım, sonra kendi ayak izlerime basarak geri dönüp kanomun bulunduğu, evin aşağısındaki gizli yere geçtim. Hemen kanoya atlayıp aceleyle uzaklaştım. Adanın baş tarafının hizasına gelene kadar kıyıdan akıntıya karşı kürek çektikten sonra nehri geçmeye koyuldum. Şapkayı çıkardım, çünkü görüşüme engel olmasını istemiyordum. Nehrin ortasına vardığımda saatin çaldığını duydum; durup dinledim; ses suyun üzerinde zayıflayarak geliyordu ama açıkça duymuştum – on bir. Adanın baş tarafına vardığımda çok yorulmuş olmama rağmen soluklanmak için bile beklemedim, hemen eski kampımın bulunduğu yere biraz odun taşıdım, orada yüksek ve kuru bir yerde kocaman bir ateş yaktım.
es: Fui por la ribera unas cincuenta yardas y deshice el camino para volver donde estaba mi canoa, bastante lejos por debajo de la casa. Me metí de un salto y salí corriendo. Fui río arriba lo bastante lejos para llegar a la punta de la isla, y después empecé a cruzar. Me quité el bonete, porque no quería ir como con orejeras. Cuando estaba hacia la mitad del camino oí que el reloj empezaba a dar las horas, así que me paré a escuchar; el ruido se oía débil por encima del agua, pero con claridad: las once. Cuando llegué a la punta de la isla no me paré a descansar, aunque estaba sin aliento, sino que me metí directamente donde estaba mi antiguo campamento y encendí una buena hoguera, en un sitio alto y seco.
vi_translation: I walked upstream about fifty meters and then turned back, rushing to the place where the boat was, a distance below that house. I jumped into the boat, hurriedly rowing away. I went quite far upstream, all the way to the head of the island, then veered across. I took off my hat, as there was no need to disguise anymore. Earlier, when I was halfway there, I heard the bell ringing, faintly over the water but still clear, it was eleven o'clock. At the head of the island, even though the wind was blowing strong, I didn't need to take cover anymore but headed straight for the spot with the log where I had hidden when I first arrived and had once lit a fire in a dry place.
tr_translation: I went fifty meters up along the river, then walked back on my own footprints and moved to the hidden spot below the house where my canoe was. I immediately jumped into the canoe and hurriedly moved away. After rowing against the current along the shore until I reached the head of the island, I began to cross the river. I took off the hat because I didn't want it to obstruct my view. When I reached the middle of the river, I heard the clock chime; I stopped and listened; the sound was faintly coming over the water but I heard it clearly – eleven. When I reached the head of the island, even though I was very tired, I didn't wait to catch my breath; I immediately carried some wood to the place where my old camp was and built a huge fire in a high and dry spot.
es_translation: I went along the riverbank for about fifty yards and then retraced my steps to return to where my canoe was, quite far below the house. I jumped in and started running. I went upstream far enough to reach the tip of the island, and then I started to cross. I took off my bonnet, because I didn't want to go as if with earmuffs. When I was about halfway across, I heard the clock start to chime, so I stopped to listen; the sound was faint over the water, but clear: eleven o'clock. When I reached the tip of the island, I didn't stop to rest, even though I was out of breath; instead, I went straight to where my old camp was and lit a good fire, in a high and dry place.

en: Then I jumped in the canoe and dug out for our place, a mile and a half below, as hard as I could go. I landed, and slopped through the timber and up the ridge and into the cavern. There Jim laid, sound asleep on the ground. I roused him out and says:
vi: Tôi chèo riết đến chỗ chúng tôi ở, hơn một dặm về phía dưới. Rồi lên bờ, nhảy vọt qua khúc gỗ, trèo lên đỉnh gò vào chạy xộc vào hang. Jim nằm đó, đang ngủ say trên mặt đất. Tôi lay hắn dạy và nói:
tr: Ardından tekrar kanoya atlayıp bir buçuk mil kadar aşağıdaki asıl yerimize gitmek için küreklere asıldım. Karaya çıktım, ağaçların arasından hızla geçip yamacı tırmandım ve mağaraya girdim. Jim içeride kütük gibi uyuyordu. Hemen onu kaldırdım.
es: Después salté a la canoa y fui a nuestro sitio, una milla y media más abajo, todo lo rápido que pude. Desembarqué y avancé entre los árboles hasta el cerro y llegué a la cueva. Allí estaba Jim, dormido como un tronco en el suelo. Lo desperté y le dije:
vi_translation: I rowed hard to the place where we stayed, more than a mile downstream. Then I went ashore, leaped over the log, climbed up the mound, and rushed into the cave. Jim was lying there, fast asleep on the ground. I shook him awake and said:
tr_translation: Then I got back into the canoe and rowed about a mile and a half downstream to our main location. I landed, quickly passed through the trees, climbed the slope, and entered the cave. Jim was sleeping like a log inside. I immediately woke him up.
es_translation: Then I jumped into the canoe and went to our spot, a mile and a half downstream, as fast as I could. I disembarked and moved through the trees to the hill and reached the cave. There was Jim, sleeping like a log on the ground. I woke him up and said to him:

en: “Git up and hump yourself, Jim! There ain’t a minute to lose. They’re after us!”
vi: - Dậy đi, chết rồi Jim ơi. Không được chậm trễ một phút nào. Họ đang lùng bắt chúng mình đấy!
tr: “Çabuk kalk ve toparlan, Jim! Kaybedecek bir dakikamız bile yok. Peşimizdeler!
es: —¡Levántate y prepárate, Jim! No hay ni un minuto que perder. ¡Nos están buscando!
vi_translation: - Wake up, Jim, we're doomed. We can't afford to be late by even a minute. They're hunting us down!
tr_translation: “Get up quickly and pack, Jim! We don't have a minute to lose. They're after us!”
es_translation: —Get up and get ready, Jim! There isn't a minute to lose. They're looking for us!

en: Jim never asked no questions, he never said a word; but the way he worked for the next half an hour showed about how he was scared. By that time everything we had in the world was on our raft, and she was ready to be shoved out from the willow cove where she was hid. We put out the camp fire at the cavern the first thing, and didn’t show a candle outside after that.
vi: Jim chẳng hỏi han gì cũng chẳng nói năng nhưng cứ nhìn cái điệu hắn hấp tấp khoảng nửa giờ sau đó cũng biết hắn đang sợ lắm. Lúc chiếc bè đã sẵn sàng để ra khỏi cái bụi liễu, nơi chúng tôi vẫn giấu ở đó. Việc đầu tiên là chúng tôi tắt rụi đống lửa trong hang, và sau đó cũng không thắp một cây nến nào lên cả.
tr: Jim hiçbir şey sormadı, hatta tek kelime etmedi; sonraki yarım saat içindeki tavırları ne kadar korktuğunu göstermeye yetiyordu. Artık sahip olduğumuz her şey salımızın üstündeydi ve onu sakladığımız söğüt perdesinin arkasından çıkarmaya hazırdık. Mağaradaki ateşi daha en baştan söndürmüştük ve bir daha dışarıda mum bile yakmadık.
es: Jim no hizo ninguna pregunta ni dijo una palabra; pero por la forma en que trabajó la media hora siguiente se veía que estaba asustadísimo. Para entonces teníamos en la balsa todo lo que poseíamos en el mundo y estábamos listos para sacarla de entre los sauces donde estaba escondida. Lo primero que hicimos fue apagar la hoguera de la cueva, y después ya no encendimos ni una vela.
vi_translation: Jim didn't ask anything nor did he say anything, but just by looking at his hasty manner for about half an hour, one could tell he was very scared. When the raft was ready to leave the willow thicket, where we had been hiding it. The first thing we did was extinguish the fire in the cave, and after that, we didn't light any candles either.
tr_translation: Jim didn't ask anything, he didn't even say a word; his behavior over the next half hour was enough to show how scared he was. Now, everything we owned was on our raft, and we were ready to take it out from behind the willow curtain where we had hidden it. We had put out the fire in the cave from the very beginning and never lit even a candle outside again.
es_translation: Jim didn't ask any questions or say a word; but from the way he worked the next half hour, it was clear that he was terrified. By then, we had everything we owned in the raft and were ready to take it out from among the willows where it was hidden. The first thing we did was put out the fire in the cave, and after that, we didn't light even a candle.

en: I took the canoe out from the shore a little piece, and took a look; but if there was a boat around I couldn’t see it, for stars and shadows ain’t good to see by. Then we got out the raft and slipped along down in the shade, past the foot of the island dead still—never saying a word.
vi: Tôi lấy xuồng chèo ra khỏi bờ một quãng để thăm dò trước. Nhưng giá có một cái thuyền nào để ngay đó cũng không thấy gì được, vì trời tối đen, chỉ có ánh sáng sao, chẳng nhìn thầy gì. Rồi chúng tôi đẩy bè ra, cho bè lướt xuống dòng sông, trong bóng tối đi qua phía đầu đằng kia hòn đảo, im lặng như chết không ai hé miệng câu nào.
tr: Kanoyla adadan biraz açılıp neler olduğunu görmek istedim, ama orada bir kayık varsa bile ben göremiyordum; çünkü yıldız ışığında gölgeler içinde bir şeyleri ayırt etmek mümkün değildi. Sonra salı da çıkardık ve gölgelerin içinden doğru aşağı inmeye başladık, adanın ayağını geçtiğimiz sırada hiç kıpırdamıyor, tek kelime etmiyorduk.
es: Aparté la canoa de la orilla un poco y me puse a mirar; pero si por allí había un bote no podía verlo, porque las estrellas y las sombras no valen para ver mucho. Luego sacamos la balsa y bajamos entre las sombras, hasta el pie de la isla en total silencio, sin decir ni una palabra.
vi_translation: I took the boat out a bit from the shore to scout ahead. But even if there was a boat right there, nothing could be seen because it was pitch dark, with only starlight, nothing visible. Then we pushed the raft out, letting it glide down the river, through the darkness past the other end of the island, silent as death, no one uttering a word.
tr_translation: I wanted to sail a bit away from the island to see what was happening, but even if there was a boat there, I couldn't see it; because it was impossible to distinguish anything in the shadows under the starlight. Then we launched the raft and started descending through the shadows, not moving or uttering a word as we passed the foot of the island.
es_translation: I moved the canoe away from the shore a little and started to look; but if there was a boat around there, I couldn't see it, because the stars and shadows aren't good for seeing much. Then we took out the raft and went down among the shadows, to the foot of the island in total silence, without saying a word.

en: CHAPTER XII.
vi: Chương XII
tr: On İkinci Bölüm
es: Capítulo 12
vi_translation: Chapter XII
tr_translation: Chapter Two
es_translation: Chapter 12

en: It must a been close on to one o’clock when we got below the island at last, and the raft did seem to go mighty slow. If a boat was to come along we was going to take to the canoe and break for the Illinois shore; and it was well a boat didn’t come, for we hadn’t ever thought to put the gun in the canoe, or a fishing-line, or anything to eat. We was in ruther too much of a sweat to think of so many things. It warn’t good judgment to put everything on the raft.
vi: Có lẽ cũng phải đến gần một giờ đêm thì chúng tôi mới tới phía dưới hòn đảo. Mà hình như bè của chúng tôi đi chậm vô cùng. Nếu như có chiếc thuyền hay tàu nào đi tới thì chúng tôi đến phải sang xuồng mà bỏ chạy lên bờ Illinois ngay. Nhưng thật may, chẳng có thuyền bè nào đi tới, và chúng tôi cũng không nghĩ đến bỏ khẩu súng vào trong xuồng, hoặc cần câu hay đồ ăn gì cả. Lúc đó chúng tội vội quá, cuống lên, không nghĩ thấu hết mọi thứ. Vả lại tất cả cái gì cũng bỏ hết lên bè thì không lợi.
tr: Nihayet adanın aşağısına vardığımızda saat bir vardı herhalde. Sal da nasıl yavaş gidiyordu sormayın. Bir kayık görürsek hemen kanoya atlayıp Illinois kıyısına kaçacaktık. İyi ki ortalıkta kayık mayık görünmedi, çünkü tüfeği, oltaları ya da yiyecekleri kanoya yerleştirmeyi akıl edememiştik. Bu kadar çok şeyi düşünemeyecek kadar kan ter içinde kalmıştık zira. Her şeyi sala yüklemek hiç akıl kârı değildi.
es: DEBÍA DE SER casi la una cuando por fin pasamos el final de la isla y la balsa parecía avanzar muy lenta. Si se acercaba un bote, el plan era meternos en la canoa y avanzar hacia la orilla de Illinois, y menos mal que no llegó ninguno, porque no se nos había ocurrido poner la escopeta en la canoa, ni un sedal para pescar, ni nada que comer. Teníamos demasiada prisa para pensar en tantas cosas. No había sido muy inteligente ponerlo todo en la balsa.
vi_translation: It was probably close to one in the morning when we finally reached the area below the island. It seemed like our raft was moving incredibly slowly. If any boat or ship had come by, we would have had to jump into the canoe and make a run for the Illinois shore immediately. But luckily, no boats came by, and we didn't think to put the gun, the fishing rod, or any food into the canoe either. At that moment, we were in such a rush, panicking, and didn't think everything through. Besides, putting everything onto the raft wouldn't have been practical.
tr_translation: It was probably around one o'clock by the time we reached the lower part of the island. Don't even ask how slowly the raft was moving. If we saw a boat, we were going to immediately jump into the canoe and escape to the Illinois shore. Fortunately, no boats were in sight, because we hadn't thought to place the rifle, fishing rods, or food in the canoe. We were too drenched in sweat to think of so many things. Loading everything onto the raft was not a wise move at all.
es_translation: IT MUST HAVE BEEN almost one o'clock when we finally passed the end of the island and the raft seemed to move very slowly. If a boat came near, the plan was to get into the canoe and head towards the Illinois shore, and it's a good thing none did, because it hadn't occurred to us to put the shotgun in the canoe, nor a fishing line, nor anything to eat. We were in too much of a hurry to think of so many things. It hadn't been very smart to put everything on the raft.

en: If the men went to the island I just expect they found the camp fire I built, and watched it all night for Jim to come. Anyways, they stayed away from us, and if my building the fire never fooled them it warn’t no fault of mine. I played it as low down on them as I could.
vi: Nếu như hai người kia họ tìm đến hòn đảo thì tôi chắc thế nào thì cũng thấy chỗ lửa trại của chúng tôi sẽ rình ở đó suốt đêm chờ cho Jim đến. Dù sao họ cũng còn xa hơn chỗ chúng tôi, và nếu như đám lửa của chúng tôi đánh lừa được họ thì đó cũng không phải lỗi tại tôi. Nhưng càng chơi xỏ được họ đến đâu thì cứ chơi.
tr: Adamlar adaya gittilerse yaktığım ateşi bulacaklarını ve pusu kurup gece boyunca Jim’in geri dönmesini bekleyeceklerini düşünüyordum. Zaten artık bizden uzakta kalmışlardı ve yaktığım ateş onları aldatmazsa suç benim değildi. Bunun için elimden geldiğince iyi bir plan yapmıştım.
es: Si los hombres iban a la isla, supongo que encontrarían la hoguera que había hecho yo y que esperarían toda la noche a que llegara Jim. En todo caso no se nos acercaron, y si aquella hoguera no los engañó, no era culpa mía. Yo había hecho todo lo posible por despistarlos.
vi_translation: If those two people come to the island, I'm sure they will see our campfire and wait there all night for Jim to come. Anyway, they are still farther from our place, and if our fire deceives them, it's not my fault. But the more we can trick them, the better.
tr_translation: I thought that if the men went to the island, they would find the fire I had lit and lie in ambush, waiting for Jim to return throughout the night. Anyway, they were already far from us, and if the fire I had lit did not deceive them, it was not my fault. For this, I had made as good a plan as I could.
es_translation: If the men went to the island, I suppose they would find the bonfire I had made and would wait all night for Jim to arrive. In any case, they did not come near us, and if that bonfire did not deceive them, it was not my fault. I had done everything possible to mislead them.

en: When the first streak of day began to show we tied up to a tow-head in a big bend on the Illinois side, and hacked off cottonwood branches with the hatchet, and covered up the raft with them so she looked like there had been a cave-in in the bank there. A tow-head is a sandbar that has cottonwoods on it as thick as harrow-teeth.
vi: Khi tia sáng đầu tiên của ban ngày ló ra, chúng tôi buộc bè vào một cái khe ở gần bãi lớn phía Illinois; lấy rìu chặt một ít cành cây bông phủ lên để làm ra vẻ như ở ven sông này từ lâu đã có một chỗ lõm vào như vậy. Phía đầu là một cái bờ cát. cây bông mọc râm rạp tua tủa như răng bừa.
tr: Sabahın ilk ışıkları görünmeye başlarken Illinois tarafındaki büyük bir dönemece gelince gözümüze çarpan ağaçlık bir kıyıya salı çektik. Tarak dişleri gibi sık kavak ağaçlarının olduğu kıyıdan kestiğimiz dallarla salı güzelce örttük. İşimizi bitirdiğimizde kavakların arasında doğal bir çöküntü varmış gibi oldu, sal hiç görünmüyordu.
es: Cuando se empezó a ver la primera luz del día amarramos a una barra de arena que había en una gran curva del lado de Illinois, cortamos ramas de alamillo con el hacha y tapamos la balsa con ellas para que pareciese que había habido un corrimiento de tierras por aquella orilla. En esas barras de arena hay alamillos tan apretados como los dientes de un rastrillo.
vi_translation: When the first light of day appeared, we tied the raft to a crevice near a large beach on the Illinois side; using an axe, we cut some cottonwood branches to cover it, making it look as if there had long been a recess at this part of the riverbank. At the front was a sandbar, with dense cottonwood trees growing thickly like the teeth of a comb.
tr_translation: As the first light of dawn began to appear, we pulled the raft to a wooded shore that caught our eye as we came to a large bend on the Illinois side. We covered the raft nicely with branches we cut from the shore, which was lined with densely packed poplar trees like the teeth of a comb. When we finished our work, it looked as if there was a natural depression among the poplars; the raft was completely invisible.
