But suddenly I realized the water was pulling me towards the left bank, meaning I was going the wrong way, so I turned around and swam with the current.
tr_translation: I called out to Jim at least ten times, but there was no response. While struggling in the water, I grabbed hold of a plank that came into my hand and, holding it in front of me, kicked my feet to swim towards the shore. But then I realized that the current was pushing me towards the left shore, which meant I had reached one of the junctions, so I changed my course and went to the left.
es_translation: I called Jim half a dozen times, but without receiving a response; so I grabbed a plank that came my way while I was pedaling in the water and headed towards land, holding on to it tightly. But I managed to see that the current was carrying towards the left bank, which meant that I was in the middle of a cross current, so I changed course and followed that way.

en: It was one of these long, slanting, two-mile crossings; so I was a good long time in getting over. I made a safe landing, and clumb up the bank. I couldn’t see but a little ways, but I went poking along over rough ground for a quarter of a mile or more, and then I run across a big old-fashioned double log-house before I noticed it. I was going to rush by and get away, but a lot of dogs jumped out and went to howling and barking at me, and I knowed better than to move another peg.
vi: Qua sông dài đến hai dặm, xa lắcm, phải lâu lắm mới qua được. Tôi vào đến bờ sông, yên ổn, rồi trèo lên bãi. Trước mặt chỉ thấy có một con đường nhỏ, nhưng tôi cứ lò dò đi trên đám đất gồ ghề một quãng đến non nửa dặm, đi ngang một toà nhà xây kiểu cổ, có hai nếp, từ lúc nào mà không hay. Tôi vừa định vượt lên chạy qua đó thì một đàn chó ở đâu chay ra cứ nhè tôi mà sửa ầm lên. Tôi biết là lại sắp nguy nữa rồi đây.
tr: Uzun, meyilli, iki millik kavşak noktalarından biriydi burası; kıyıya varmam bu yüzden epey uzun sürdü. Sağ salim karaya ayak bastım ve kıyıdan yukarı tırmanmaya başladım. Önümü neredeyse hiç göremiyordum; engebeli arazide çeyrek mil kadar el yordamıyla ilerledim ve nihayet kendimi kocaman, eski moda iki kanatlı bir ahşap evin önünde buldum. Hemen yolumu değiştirip uzaklaşacaktım, ama bir sürü köpek havlayarak gelip çevremi sarınca en akıllıcasının yerimden hiç kıpırdamamak olduğunu anladım.
es: Era uno de aquellos cruces largos, y regulares, de dos millas; así que tardé mucho en recorrerlo. Llegué bien a tierra y trepé por la orilla. Sólo podía ver a muy poca distancia, pero fui tanteando por un terreno pedregoso un cuarto de milla o más, y después me tropecé con una de esas casonas anticuadas de troncos que ni había visto. Iba a pasar corriendo lejos de allí, pero salió una jauría de perros que se puso a aullar y a ladrarme y comprendí que era mejor no moverme.
vi_translation: The river was about two miles wide, very far, and it took a long time to cross. I reached the riverbank safely, then climbed up onto the shore. In front of me, I saw only a small path, but I kept trudging along the rough ground for nearly half a mile, passing an old-style building with two wings, without even noticing when I had done so. I was just about to run past when a pack of dogs came out of nowhere and started barking loudly at me. I knew I was in danger again.
tr_translation: This was a long, sloping, two-mile junction point; that's why it took me quite a long time to reach the shore. I safely set foot on land and started climbing up from the shore. I could hardly see ahead; I advanced about a quarter mile by feeling my way through the rugged terrain and finally found myself in front of a large, old-fashioned, two-winged wooden house. I was about to change my path and move away immediately, but when a bunch of dogs came barking and surrounded me, I realized that the smartest thing to do was not to move at all.
es_translation: It was one of those long, regular crossings of two miles; so it took me a long time to get through it. I made it to land safely and climbed up the shore. I could only see a very short distance, but I groped my way over rocky ground for a quarter of a mile or more, and then I stumbled upon one of those old-fashioned log houses that I had never seen before. I was about to run far away from there, but a pack of dogs came out and started howling and barking at me, and I realized it was better not to move.

en: CHAPTER XVII.
vi: Chương XVII
tr: On Yedinci Bölüm
es: Capítulo 17
vi_translation: Chapter XVII
tr_translation: Chapter Seventeen
es_translation: Chapter 17

en: In about a minute somebody spoke out of a window without putting his head out, and says:
vi: Chừng một phút sau có tiếng người trong cửa sổ mà không thò đầu ra ngoài nói:
tr: Yarım dakika geçmeden birisi başını çıkarmaksızın bir pencereden seslendi:
es: AL CABO DE un minuto alguien dijo por la ventana, sin sacar la cabeza:
vi_translation: About a minute later, there was a voice from the window without anyone sticking their head out:
tr_translation: Before half a minute had passed, someone called out from a window without showing their head:
es_translation: AFTER A minute someone said through the window, without sticking their head out:

en: “Be done, boys! Who’s there?”
vi: - Làm cái gì thế? Ai đấy?
tr: “Tamam artık çocuklar! Kim var orada?
es: —¡Basta, chicos! ¿Quién va?
vi_translation: - What are you doing? Who's there?
tr_translation: “Alright, that's enough children! Who is there?”
es_translation: —Enough, kids! Who's going?

en: “Who’s me?”
vi: - Cháu là ai?
tr: “Sen kimsin?
es: —¿Quién es yo?
vi_translation: - Who are you?
tr_translation: “Who are you?”
es_translation: —Who am I?

en: “George Jackson, sir.”
vi: - Thưa ông, cháu là George Jackson
tr: “George Jackson, bayım.
es: —George Jackson, caballero.
vi_translation: - Sir, I am George Jackson
tr_translation: “Mr. George Jackson.””
es_translation: —George Jackson, gentleman.

en: “What do you want?”
vi: - Muốn gì?
tr: “Ne istiyorsun?
es: —¿Qué quieres?
vi_translation: - What do you want?
tr_translation: “What do you want?”
es_translation: —What do you want?

en: “I don’t want nothing, sir. I only want to go along by, but the dogs won’t let me.”
vi: - Cháu chẳng muốn gì cả, ông ạ. Cháu chỉ muốn đi qua, nhưng mấy con chó này không để cháu đi.
tr: “Hiçbir şey istemiyorum, bayım. Sadece yoluma gitmek istiyorum, ama köpekler bırakmıyor.
es: —No quiero nada, caballero. No hacía más que pasar, pero los perros no me dejan.
vi_translation: - I don't want anything, sir. I just want to pass through, but these dogs won't let me.
tr_translation: "I don't want anything, sir. I just want to go on my way, but the dogs won't let me."
es_translation: —I don't want anything, sir. I was just passing by, but the dogs won't let me.

en: “What are you prowling around here this time of night for—hey?”
vi: - Đêm hôm thế này, mò mẫm ở đây làm gì thế?
tr: “Gecenin bir vaktinde evimin civarında niye sinsi sinsi geziyorsun bakalım?
es: —Y, ¿qué haces merodeando por aquí a estas horas de la noche, eh?
vi_translation: - What are you doing here, fumbling around in the middle of the night?
tr_translation: “Why are you sneaking around my house in the middle of the night?””
es_translation: —And what are you doing lurking around here at this hour of the night, huh?

en: “I warn’t prowling around, sir, I fell overboard off of the steamboat.”
vi: - Thưa ông, cháu không có mò mẫm gì đâu. Cháu ở trên tàu thủy vừa bị ngã xuống sông đây mà.
tr: “Gezmiyordum, bayım; bir buharlı geminin güvertesinden suya düştüm.
es: —No estaba merodeando, caballero; me he caído del barco de vapor.
vi_translation: - Sir, I wasn't fumbling around at all. I was on the ship and just fell into the river.
tr_translation: “I wasn't walking, sir; I fell into the water from the deck of a steamship.”
es_translation: —I wasn't lurking, sir; I fell off the steamboat.

en: “Oh, you did, did you? Strike a light there, somebody. What did you say your name was?”
vi: - Ô, thật thế ư? Có ai thắp cái đèn lên tí nào. Anh bảo tên anh là gì nhỉ?
tr: “Suya mı düştün? Bir ışık yakın. Adın neydi senin?
es: —¿De verdad? ¡No me digas! Que alguien encienda una luz, ¿cómo has dicho que te llamabas?
vi_translation: - Oh, really? Can someone light the lamp a bit. What did you say your name was?
tr_translation: “Did you fall into the water? Turn on a light. What was your name?”
es_translation: —Really? Don't tell me! Can someone turn on a light, what did you say your name was?

en: “George Jackson, sir. I’m only a boy.”
vi: - George Jackson, ông ạ. Cháu chỉ là một cậu bé thôi.
tr: “George Jackson, bayım. Ben daha çocuğum.
es: —George Jackson, caballero. Soy un muchacho.
vi_translation: - George Jackson, sir. I'm just a boy.
tr_translation: "Mr. George Jackson." "I am just a child.""
es_translation: —George Jackson, gentleman. I am a boy.

en: “Look here, if you’re telling the truth you needn’t be afraid—nobody’ll hurt you. But don’t try to budge; stand right where you are. Rouse out Bob and Tom, some of you, and fetch the guns. George Jackson, is there anybody with you?”
vi: - Này, cứ nói thật đi, không việc gì mà sợ. Không ai đánh đâu. Nhưng mà đừng có nhúc nhích. ở đâu đứng yên đấy. Bod, Tom, có đứa nào dậy đem cái súng ra đây. George Jackson có ai đi cùng với mày nữa không?
tr: “Doğruyu söylüyorsan korkmana gerek yok… Kimsenin sana zararı dokunmaz. Ama yerinden kımıldayayım deme sakın, olduğun yerde kal. Biriniz Bob ve Tom’u kaldırsın ve biriniz de tüfekleri getirsin. Yanında kimse var mı, George Jackson?
es: —Mira, si dices la verdad, no tienes por qué tener miedo: nadie va a hacerte nada. Pero no intentes moverte; quédate donde estás. Que alguien despierte a Bob y a Tom y que traigan las armas. George Jackson, ¿hay alguien contigo?
vi_translation: - Hey, just tell the truth, there's nothing to be afraid of. No one will hit you. But don't move. Stay right where you are. Bod, Tom, someone get up and bring the gun here. George Jackson, is there anyone else with you?
tr_translation: “If you are telling the truth, you have nothing to fear… No one will harm you. But don’t even think about moving from your spot, stay where you are. One of you lift Bob and Tom, and one of you bring the rifles. Is there anyone with you, George Jackson?”
es_translation: —Look, if you tell the truth, you have nothing to fear: no one is going to do anything to you. But don't try to move; stay where you are. Someone wake up Bob and Tom and bring the weapons. George Jackson, is there anyone with you?

en: “No, sir, nobody.”
vi: - Không ạ, không có ai cả
tr: “Hayır, bayım, kimse yok.
es: —No, caballero, nadie.
vi_translation: - No, there is no one.
tr_translation: “No, sir, there is no one.”
es_translation: —No, sir, no one.

en: I heard the people stirring around in the house now, and see a light. The man sung out:
vi: Tôi nghe tiếng người lục sục trong nhà, rồi thấy có ánh sáng bật lên. Tiếng người khi nãy nói:
tr: Evin içinde insanların hareketlendiğini duydum, bir ışık yandı. Adamın telaşlı sesi duyuldu:
es: Ahora se oía a gente que se movía por la casa y vi una luz. El hombre gritó:
vi_translation: I heard the sound of someone rummaging in the house, then saw a light turn on. The person from earlier said:
tr_translation: I heard people moving inside the house, a light turned on. The man's anxious voice was heard:
es_translation: Now I could hear people moving around the house and I saw a light. The man shouted:

en: “Snatch that light away, Betsy, you old fool—ain’t you got any sense? Put it on the floor behind the front door. Bob, if you and Tom are ready, take your places.”
vi: - Cho lui cái đèn ra xa kia, Betsy, sao mà ngốc thế, không biết gì cả. Để cái đèn ở trên sàn, ngay sau cửa ra vào ấy. Bod, Tom chúng mày đã sẵn sàng cả chưa, ngồi vào chỗ.
tr: “Şu ışığı uzaklaştır çabuk, Betsy, seni budala… Sende hiç mi akıl kalmadı? Ön kapının arkasında yere bırak. Bob, sen ve Tom hazırsanız yerlerinizi alın.
es: —Aparta esa luz, Betsy, vieja idiota... ¿no tienes sentido común? Ponla en el suelo detrás de la puerta principal. Bob, si tú y Tom estáis listos, a vuestros puestos.
vi_translation: - Move the lamp farther away, Betsy, how stupid, you don't know anything. Put the lamp on the floor, right behind the door. Bod, Tom, are you both ready? Sit down.
tr_translation: “Move that light away quickly, Betsy, you fool... Have you lost all your sense? Leave it on the ground behind the front door. Bob, you and Tom take your positions if you're ready.”
es_translation: —Move that light, Betsy, you old fool... don't you have any common sense? Put it on the floor behind the front door. Bob, if you and Tom are ready, to your positions.

en: “All ready.”
vi: - Sẵn sàng cả
tr: “Hepimiz hazırız.
es: —Listos.
vi_translation: - Ready all
tr_translation: “We are all ready.”
es_translation: —Ready.

en: “Now, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdsons?”
vi: - Nào, George Jackson, mày có biết họ nhà Shepherdsons không?
tr: “Söyle bakalım, George Jackson, Shepherdson’ları tanıyor musun?
es: —Y ahora, George Jackson, ¿sabes quiénes son los Shepherdson?
vi_translation: - So, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdson family?
tr_translation: “Tell me, George Jackson, do you know the Shepherdsons?”
es_translation: —And now, George Jackson, do you know who the Shepherdsons are?

en: “No, sir; I never heard of them.”
vi: - Không, ông ạ, tôi chẳng nghe nói đến cái tên đó bao giờ
tr: “Hayır; bayım. Hiç duymadım.
es: —No, señor, nunca he oído hablar de ellos.
vi_translation: - No, sir, I have never heard of that name before
tr_translation: “No; sir. I've never heard of it.”
es_translation: —No, sir, I have never heard of them.

en: “Well, that may be so, and it mayn’t. Now, all ready. Step forward, George Jackson. And mind, don’t you hurry—come mighty slow. If there’s anybody with you, let him keep back—if he shows himself he’ll be shot. Come along now. Come slow; push the door open yourself—just enough to squeeze in, d’ you hear?”
vi: - Được, có thể là mày chưa nghe nói đến, cũng có thể là nghe nói đến rồi. Thôi được, sẵn sàng cả rồi đấy. Bước lên, George Jackson. Coi chừng, không được hấp tấp, bước thật chậm. Nếu có ai đi cùng với mày thì phải để nó đứng lại, nó mà bước lên sẽ bị hắn chết. Nào tiến lên, chậm chứ. Tự tay đẩy cánh cửa ra, vừa để lách vào thôi, nghe không?
tr: “Pekâlâ, belki doğru söylüyorsun, belki de söylemiyorsun. Evet, herkes hazır. Yaklaş, George Jackson. Ama sakın hızlı hareket etme… Çok yavaş gel. Yanında biri varsa geride kalsın, kendini gösterirse vurulur. Haydi gel bakalım. Yavaş ol; kapıyı dikkatli aç… Ama sadece kendin geçebilecek kadar aç, duydun mu beni?
es: —Bueno, quizá digas la verdad y quizás mientas. Ahora, todos listos. Da un paso adelante, George Jackson. Y cuidadito, sin prisas... muy despacio. Si hay alguien contigo, que se quede ahí; si lo vemos, le pegamos un tiro. Ahora, adelante. Ven despacio; abre la puerta tú mismo. .. justo lo suficiente para entrar, ¿me oyes?
vi_translation: - Alright, maybe you haven't heard of it, or maybe you have. Okay, everything is ready. Step up, George Jackson. Be careful, don't rush, step very slowly. If someone is with you, make them stay back, if they step up, they will die. Now move forward, slowly. Push the door open yourself, just enough to slip through, understand?
tr_translation: “Alright, maybe you're telling the truth, maybe you're not. Yes, everyone is ready. Come closer, George Jackson. But don't move quickly… Come very slowly. If there's someone with you, they should stay back; if they show themselves, they'll be shot. Come on then. Be slow; open the door carefully… But only open it enough for you to pass through, do you hear me?”
es_translation: —Well, maybe you're telling the truth and maybe you're lying. Now, everyone get ready. Take a step forward, George Jackson. And be careful, no rush... very slowly. If there's someone with you, they should stay there; if we see them, we'll shoot them. Now, go ahead. Come slowly; open the door yourself. ... just enough to get in, do you hear me?

en: I didn’t hurry; I couldn’t if I’d a wanted to. I took one slow step at a time and there warn’t a sound, only I thought I could hear my heart. The dogs were as still as the humans, but they followed a little behind me. When I got to the three log doorsteps I heard them unlocking and unbarring and unbolting. I put my hand on the door and pushed it a little and a little more till somebody said, “There, that’s enough—put your head in.” I done it, but I judged they would take it off.
vi: Tôi không hấp tấp bước lên, mà có muốn cũng không được. Mỗi lần chỉ bước vào một bước chậm và không có tiếng đông nào, chỉ nghe thấy tim tôi đập. Lũ chó cũng im lặng như bọn người, chúng nó theo sau cách tôi một tí. Bước đến bực cửa, tôi nghe tiếng mở khoá, nhấc cái thang chắn cửa ra và rút then cài. Tôi đặt tay lên cửa, nhẹ đẩy một tí, một tí một. Rồi có tiếng nói: - Thế thôi, được rồi, thò đầu vào. Tôi đưa đầu vào, nhưng trong bụng vẫn lo, sợ họ chặt mất đầu.
tr: Hiç acele etmedim, zaten istesem de edemezdim. Tek tek adım atarken kendi kalbimin çarpması dışında hiçbir ses duymadım. Köpekler de insanlar kadar sessizleşmişti ve hemen arkamdan beni takip ediyorlardı. Kütükten üç basamaklı merdivene vardığımda içeride kilitlerin açıldığını ve sürgülerin çekildiğini işittim. Sonra elimle kapıyı ağır ağır itmeye başladım. “Tamam, bu kadar yeter,” dedi içeriden birisi, “kafanı içeri uzat.” Dediğini yaptım, ama herhalde artık kellemi uçururlar diye düşünüyordum.
es: No corrí; no podría aunque hubiera querido. Fui dando un paso lento tras otro y no se oía un ruido, sólo que a mí me pareció que oía los latidos de mi corazón. Los perros estaban igual de callados que las personas, pero me pisaban los talones. Cuando llegué a los tres escalones de troncos, oí que quitaban el cerrojo y la barra de la puerta. Puse la mano en la puerta, empujé un poco y después un poco más hasta que alguien dijo: «Vale, ya basta; enséñanos la cabeza». Lo hice, pero pensando que me la iban a arrancar.
vi_translation: I did not hastily step up, even if I wanted to, I couldn't. Each time, I only took one slow step without any noise, only hearing my heart beating. The dogs were as silent as the people, they followed me a little behind. Reaching the threshold, I heard the sound of unlocking, lifting the door bar, and pulling the latch. I placed my hand on the door, gently pushed a little, little by little. Then there was a voice: - That's it, alright, stick your head in. I put my head in, but I was still worried inside, afraid they might cut off my head.
tr_translation: I never hurried, and even if I wanted to, I couldn't have. As I took each step, I heard nothing but the beating of my own heart. The dogs had become as quiet as the people and were following me right behind. When I reached the three-step ladder made of logs, I heard the locks opening and the bolts being drawn inside. Then I started to slowly push the door with my hand. “Okay, that's enough,” said someone from inside, “stick your head in.” I did as he said, but I was thinking they would probably behead me now.
es_translation: I didn't run; I couldn't even if I had wanted to. I took one slow step after another and there wasn't a sound, only that it seemed to me that I could hear the beating of my heart. The dogs were as quiet as the people, but they were on my heels. When I reached the three log steps, I heard them removing the bolt and the bar from the door. I put my hand on the door, pushed a little and then a little more until someone said: "Okay, that's enough; show us your head." I did it, but thinking they were going to tear it off.

en: The candle was on the floor, and there they all was, looking at me, and me at them, for about a quarter of a minute: Three big men with guns pointed at me, which made me wince, I tell you; the oldest, gray and about sixty, the other two thirty or more—all of them fine and handsome—and the sweetest old gray-headed lady, and back of her two young women which I couldn’t see right well. The old gentleman says:
vi: Ngọn nến để trên sàn nhà, và họ đã đứng cả quanh đó. Họ nhìn tôi, tôi cũng nhìn họ đến gần nửa phút: ba người to lớn cầm súng trong tay lăm lăm chĩa vào tôi, làm tôi rợn cả người, thật đấy. Người nhiều tuổi nhất, tóc đã hơi bạc, chạc độ sáu mươ; người thứ hai quãnh ba mươi hay hơn, cả hai đều trông đẹp, chững chặc. Và một người đàn bà đứng tổi, tóc hoa râm, khuôn mặt nhỏ nhắn. Đứng sau người đàn bà là hai thiếu phụ còn trẻ mà tôi nhìn không được rõ lắm. Người đàn ông cao tuổi nói:
tr: Yerdeki mumun ışığında hepsini gördüm, çeyrek dakika boyunca onlar bana baktılar; ben de onlara baktım. Silahlarını bana doğrultmuş üç irikıyım adam gerçekten ürkütücüydü; en yaşlısı altmışlarında görünüyordu ve kır saçlıydı, diğer ikisi otuzlarında ya da biraz daha büyüktü –hepsi de sağlıklı ve yakışıklıydı– ayrıca tatlı tatlı bakan kır saçlı bir kadın ve geride pek iyi göremediğim iki genç kız vardı.
es: La vela estaba en el suelo, y allí estaban todos, mirándome, y yo a ellos, y nos quedamos así un cuarto de minuto: tres hombrones apuntándome con sus armas, lo cual os aseguro que me dio escalofríos; el mayor era canoso y tendría unos sesenta años, y los otros dos treinta o más (todos ellos muy finos y muy guapos) y una señora anciana de pelo gris y con un aspecto de lo más bondadoso, que tenía detrás dos mujeres jóvenes a las que no logré ver bien. El señor mayor dijo:
vi_translation: The candle was placed on the floor, and they were all standing around it. They looked at me, and I looked at them for nearly half a minute: three large men holding guns pointed at me, making me shiver, truly. The oldest person, with slightly gray hair, was about sixty; the second one was around thirty or a bit older, both looking handsome and composed. And a woman stood there, with graying hair and a small face. Standing behind the woman were two young women whom I couldn't see very clearly. The elderly man spoke:
tr_translation: In the light of the candle on the ground, I saw them all; for a quarter of a minute, they looked at me, and I looked at them. The three hulking men who had their guns pointed at me were truly intimidating; the oldest one looked to be in his sixties and had gray hair, the other two were in their thirties or a bit older – all of them were healthy and handsome – there was also a gray-haired woman with a sweet gaze and two young girls whom I couldn't see very well in the back.
es_translation: The candle was on the floor, and there they all were, looking at me, and I at them, and we stayed like that for a quarter of a minute: three big men pointing their weapons at me, which I assure you gave me chills; the oldest was gray-haired and about sixty years old, and the other two were thirty or older (all of them very refined and very handsome) and an elderly lady with gray hair and the kindest appearance, who had behind her two young women whom I couldn't see well. The older gentleman said:

en: “There; I reckon it’s all right. Come in.”
vi: - Thế, được rồi. Bước vào đi
tr: “Tamam, sorun yok. İçeri giç” dedi yaşlı adam.
es: —Vale; supongo que está bien. Entra.
vi_translation: - Okay, fine. Come in
tr_translation: "Alright, no problem. Come inside," said the old man.
es_translation: —Okay; I suppose it's fine. Come in.

en: As soon as I was in the old gentleman he locked the door and barred it and bolted it, and told the young men to come in with their guns, and they all went in a big parlor that had a new rag carpet on the floor, and got together in a corner that was out of the range of the front windows—there warn’t none on the side. They held the candle, and took a good look at me, and all said, “Why, he ain’t a Shepherdson—no, there ain’t any Shepherdson about him.” Then the old man said he hoped I wouldn’t mind being searched for arms, because he didn’t mean no harm by it—it was only to make sure. So he didn’t pry into my pockets, but only felt outside with his hands, and said it was all right. He told me to make myself easy and at home, and tell all about myself; but the old lady says:
vi: Tôi vừa bước vào thì người đó đã khoá tịt ngay cửa lại, cái then chặn cả thang ngang, rồi bảo người đàn ông trẻ mang súng đến. Cả bọn bước vào phòng bên có trải một cái thảm mới, rồi chụm lại một góc gần cửa sổ thông rả đường, không còn ai đứng lại đó nữa. Rồi họ cầm cây nên lên, nhìn tôi cẩn thân và nói: - ồ, nó không phải là Shepherdsons. Nó chẳng có vẻ gì là Shepherdsons cả. Rồi người nhiều tuổi bảo tôi đừng ngại để cho họ lục soát xem có vũ khí gì không đã - vì không phải là có ý gì hại tôi đâu, mà chỉ là để cho chắc chắn đó thôi. Lão ta không thọc tay vào túi tôi mà chỉ lần lần ở bên ngoài thôi, rồi bảo: được rồi. Lão bảo tôi bây giờ cứ tự nhiên như ở nhà, với lại nói đủ các thứ về tội nữa. Nhưng người đàn bà đứng tuổi nói:
tr: Ben içeri girer girmez yaşlı beyefendi kapıyı kilitledi ve sürgüledi, sonra da gençlere tüfekleriyle birlikte yaklaşmalarını söyledi. Zeminine yepyeni bir kilim serilmiş büyük salonda, ön pencerelerin menzili dışındaki –yan duvarda hiç pencere yoktu– köşede herkes toplandı. Mumu yaklaştırıp beni tepeden tırnağa incelediler. Sonra da hep bir ağızdan konuşmaya başladılar: “Yok, Shepherdson değil… Hayır; hiç Shepherdson’a benzemiyor.” Sonra yaşlı adam silahım var mı diye üstümün aranmasına ses çıkarmayacağımı umduğunu söyledi, kötü bir niyeti yoktu zira… Sadece emin olmak istiyordu. Bu yüzden elini ceplerime sokmadı, sadece dışarıdan eliyle yokladı ve tamam dedi. Artık rahatlamamı ve kendimi evimde saymamı söyledi; sonra da kendime dair her şeyi anlatmamı istedi, ama yaşlı kadın araya girdi:
es: En cuanto entré, el caballero anciano cerró la puerta y le echó el cerrojo y la barra, dijo a los jóvenes que entrasen con sus escopetas y todos fueron al gran salón que tenía una alfombra nueva de paño y se reunieron en un rincón apartado de las ventanas de la fachada: a los lados no había ni una. Agarraron la vela, me miraron bien y todos dijeron: «Pues no es un Shepherdson, no; no tiene nada de Shepherdson». Después el anciano dijo que esperaba que no me importase que me registrasen para ver si llevaba armas, porque no lo hacían con mala intención; era sólo para asegurarse. Así que no me metió las manos en los bolsillos, sino que únicamente me tocó por los lados con las manos y aseguró que estaba bien. Me dijo que me pusiera cómodo y me sintiera en mi propia casa y les hablase de mí, pero la señora vieja dijo:
vi_translation: As soon as I stepped in, that person immediately locked the door tightly, barring it with a horizontal latch, then told the young man to bring the gun. The whole group stepped into the next room, which had a new carpet laid out, then huddled in a corner near the window facing the street, and no one remained standing there anymore. Then they picked up the candle, looked at me carefully, and said: - Oh, it's not the Shepherdsons. It doesn't look like the Shepherdsons at all. Then the older man told me not to worry about letting them search for any weapons - not because they meant any harm to me, but just to be sure. He didn't put his hands in my pockets but just felt around the outside, then said: all right. He told me to make myself at home now, and talked about all sorts of things about sin too. But the middle-aged woman said:
tr_translation: As soon as I entered, the elderly gentleman locked and bolted the door, then told the young men to approach with their rifles. In the large room with a brand-new carpet laid on the floor, everyone gathered in the corner outside the range of the front windows – there were no windows on the side wall. They brought the candle closer and examined me from head to toe. Then they all started talking at once: "No, not a Shepherdson... No; doesn't look like a Shepherdson at all." Then the old man said he hoped I wouldn't mind being searched for weapons, as he had no ill intentions... He just wanted to be sure. So he didn't put his hand in my pockets, he just felt from the outside and said it was fine. He told me to relax and consider myself at home; then he asked me to tell everything about myself, but the old woman interrupted:
es_translation: As soon as I entered, the elderly gentleman closed the door and bolted and barred it, told the young men to come in with their shotguns, and everyone went to the large living room that had a new cloth carpet and gathered in a corner away from the front windows: there were none on the sides. They grabbed the candle, looked at me closely, and all said: "Well, he's not a Shepherdson, no; he doesn't have anything of a Shepherdson." Then the old man said he hoped I wouldn't mind if they searched me to see if I was carrying any weapons, because they didn't mean any harm; it was just to be sure. So he didn't put his hands in my pockets, but only touched my sides with his hands and assured that everything was fine. He told me to make myself comfortable and feel at home and to tell them about myself, but the old lady said:

en: “Why, bless you, Saul, the poor thing’s as wet as he can be; and don’t you reckon it may be he’s hungry?”
vi: - Chết chửa, này ông Saul, thằng bé ướt đẫm cả người thế này. Mà có lẽ nó cũng còn đói nữa chứ?
tr: “Tanrı aşkına, Saul, zavallının sırılsıklam olduğunu görmüyor musun? Belki karnı da açtır.
es: —Pero, hombre, Saúl, pobrecito; está calado hasta los huesos y, ¿no crees que quizá tenga hambre?
vi_translation: - Oh dear, Mr. Saul, the boy is soaking wet like this. And perhaps he's still hungry too?
tr_translation: "For God's sake, Saul, don't you see the poor thing is soaking wet? Maybe he's hungry too."
es_translation: —But, man, Saul, poor thing; he's soaked to the bone and, don't you think he might be hungry?

en: “True for you, Rachel—I forgot.”
vi: - ừ, phải đấy, Rachel ạ, tôi quên mất.
tr: “Haklısın, Rachel, unutmuşum.
es: —Tienes razón, Rachel; se me olvidaba.
vi_translation: - Yes, that's right, Rachel, I forgot.
tr_translation: “You are right, Rachel, I forgot.”
es_translation: —You're right, Rachel; I forgot.

en: So the old lady says:
vi: Người đàn bà nói:
tr: Bunun üzerine yaşlı hanımefendi şöyle dedi:
es: Así que la vieja dice:
vi_translation: The woman said:
tr_translation: Upon this, the elderly lady said:
es_translation: So the old woman says:

en: “Betsy” (this was a nigger woman), “you fly around and get him something to eat as quick as you can, poor thing; and one of you girls go and wake up Buck and tell him—oh, here he is himself. Buck, take this little stranger and get the wet clothes off from him and dress him up in some of yours that’s dry.”
vi: - Betsy (đây là một người đàn bà da đen), chạy đi kiếm cái gì cho nó ăn, khổ tội nghiệp cậu bé, còn một cô đi gọi Buck dậy, bảo nó, à thôi, nó đây rồi. Buck, đem cậu bé này đoi cởi quần áo ướt ra và lấy đồ nào khô của mày ra mặc vào cho nó.
tr: “Betsy (zenci kadına sesleniyordu), hemen koş, ona yiyecek bir şeyler getir, zavallıcık; kızlar, biriniz de gidip Buck’ı uyandırın ve deyin ki… Hah, kendisi geldi zaten. Buck, bu küçük yabancıyı götür; ıslak giysilerini çıkarttır ve kendi kuru giysilerinden ver.
es: —Betsy (era una negra), ve corriendo y trae algo de comer a toda prisa, pobrecito; y una de vosotras, las chicas, id a despertar a Buck y le decís... ah, aquí viene. Buck, llévate a este muchachito y quítale la ropa húmeda y dale algo tuyo que esté seco para que se lo ponga.
vi_translation: - Betsy (this is a black woman), ran to find something for him to eat, poor boy, while another girl went to wake Buck up, telling him, oh never mind, here he is. Buck, take this boy and change his wet clothes, and put some of your dry clothes on him.
tr_translation: “Betsy (he was addressing the black woman), run quickly and bring him something to eat, poor thing; girls, one of you go and wake Buck and tell him that…” “Ah, here he comes already.” “Buck, take this little stranger; take off his wet clothes and give him some of your dry ones.””
es_translation: —Betsy (she was a black woman), run and bring something to eat quickly, poor thing; and one of you girls, go wake up Buck and tell him... ah, here he comes. Buck, take this little boy and remove his wet clothes and give him something of yours that is dry to wear.

en: Buck looked about as old as me—thirteen or fourteen or along there, though he was a little bigger than me. He hadn’t on anything but a shirt, and he was very frowzy-headed. He came in gaping and digging one fist into his eyes, and he was dragging a gun along with the other one. He says:
vi: Trong Buck cũng trặc tuổi tôi, mười ba hay mười bốn gì đó, tuy hắn hơi to lớn hơn tôi một chút. Nó chỉ mặc mỗi cái áo sơ mi, và đầu tóc thì rất bẩn. Nó bước đến. miệng ngáp và lấy ngón tay dụi mắt, còn tay kia kéo lê khẩu súng. Nó hỏi:
tr: Buck benim yaşlarımda görünüyordu – ya on üç ya on dörttü, ama benden biraz daha iriydi. Üzerinde sadece bir mintanla gelmişti ve hâlâ uyanamamış gibi bir hali vardı. Bir yandan esniyor; bir yandan da yumruğuyla gözlerini ovuşturuyordu. Diğer elinde bir tüfek vardı.
es: Buck parecía de la misma edad que yo más o menos: trece o catorce años, aunque era un poco más alto. No llevaba más que una camisa, y tenía el pelo todo revuelto. Llegó bostezando y pasándose una mano por los ojos, con una escopeta en la otra. Respondió:
vi_translation: Buck was about my age, thirteen or fourteen, though he was a bit bigger than me. He was only wearing a shirt, and his hair was very dirty. He walked over, yawning and rubbing his eyes with one hand, while dragging a gun with the other. He asked:
tr_translation: Buck looked to be around my age – either thirteen or fourteen, but he was a bit bigger than me. He had come with just a shirt on and still seemed like he hadn't fully woken up. He was yawning on one hand; on the other, he was rubbing his eyes with his fist. In his other hand, he had a rifle.
es_translation: Buck seemed to be about the same age as me: thirteen or fourteen years old, although he was a bit taller. He was only wearing a shirt, and his hair was all messy. He arrived yawning and rubbing his eyes with one hand, holding a shotgun in the other. He replied:

en: “Ain’t they no Shepherdsons around?”
vi: - Không có bọn Shepherdsons ngoài đó chứ?
tr: “Shepherdson’lar değil miymiş?” diye sordu.
es: —¿No hay Shepherdson por aquí?
vi_translation: - There aren't any Shepherdsons out there, are there?
tr_translation: “Aren't they the Shepherdsons?” he asked.
es_translation: —Is there no Shepherdson around here?

en: They said, no, ’twas a false alarm.
vi: Cả đám người nói: - Không, báo động giả đấy thôi Nó nói:
tr: Hayır, yanlış alarm, dediler.
es: Dijeron que no, que era una falsa alarma.
vi_translation: The whole group said: - No, it's just a false alarm It said:
tr_translation: No, false alarm, they said.
es_translation: They said no, that it was a false alarm.

en: “Well,” he says, “if they’d a ben some, I reckon I’d a got one.”
vi: - Tưởng nếu có bọn ấy thì tôi đã vớ được một đứa
tr: “Gelselerdi en azından birini haklardım herhalde,” dedi.
es: —Bueno —dice—, si hubieran venido, seguro que me llevo a uno por delante.
vi_translation: - I thought if there were any of them, I would have caught one
tr_translation: "If they had come, I would have at least taken one of them down, I guess," he said.
es_translation: —Well —he says—, if they had come, I surely would have taken one down.

en: They all laughed, and Bob says:
vi: Cả bọn cười. Bod nói:
tr: Hepsi kahkahalarla güldüler.
es: Todos se echaron a reír, y Bob dice:
vi_translation: Everyone laughed. Bod said:
tr_translation: They all laughed out loud.
es_translation: Everyone burst out laughing, and Bob says:

en: “Why, Buck, they might have scalped us all, you’ve been so slow in coming.”
vi: - Này, Buck, nhưng mà mày đến chậm quá, có thểe chúng nó chụp hết cả bọn mình đấy.
tr: “Herhalde çoktan hepimizin kafa derisini yüzmüşlerdi Buck,” dedi Bob. “Öyle yavaş geliyorsun ki.
es: —Pero Buck, nos podrían haber quitado el cuero cabelludo a todos, con lo que has tardado en llegar.
vi_translation: - Hey, Buck, but you're too late, they might catch all of us.
tr_translation: “They probably would have scalped all of us by now, Buck,” said Bob. “You are coming so slowly.”
es_translation: —But Buck, they could have scalped all of us with how long it took you to get here.

en: “Well, nobody come after me, and it ain’t right I’m always kept down; I don’t get no show.”
vi: - Sau tối không còn ai nữa ư? Như thế không được. Bao giờ tôi cũng bị tụt lại thế này, chả được thấy gì cả.
tr: “Ama kimse beni kaldırmadı, bu haksızlık. Beni hep geride bırakıyorsunuz. Kendimi göstermeme fırsat vermiyorsunuz.
es: —Bueno, es que no me ha avisado nadie, y eso no está bien. Nunca me decís nada; no me dejáis hacer nada.
vi_translation: - After dark, there's no one left? That's not acceptable. I'm always left behind like this, never getting to see anything.
tr_translation: “But no one lifted me up, this is unfair. You always leave me behind. You don't give me a chance to show myself.”
es_translation: —Well, it's just that no one has informed me, and that's not right. You never tell me anything; you don't let me do anything.

en: “Never mind, Buck, my boy,” says the old man, “you’ll have show enough, all in good time, don’t you fret about that. Go ’long with you now, and do as your mother told you.”
vi: Yên trí, Buck con ơi - Lão kia nói. Rồi mày sẽ tha hồ, đừng lo. Thôi cư đi đi, làm theo mẹ mày bảo đi đã
tr: “Sıkma canını, Buck,” dedi yaşlı adam. “Zamanla kendini göstermek için bol bol fırsatın olacak. Bunun için üzülme. Haydi bakalım, annenin dediklerini yap şimdi.
es: —No importa, Buck, hijo mío —dice el viejo—, ya podrás hacer lo suficiente a su debido tiempo, no te preocupes por eso. Ahora vete a hacer lo que te ha dicho tu madre.
vi_translation: Don't worry, Buck my child - The old man said. Then you will be free, don't worry. Now go, do as your mother told you.
tr_translation: “Don't worry, Buck,” said the old man. “In time, you will have plenty of opportunities to prove yourself. Don't be upset about this. Come on now, do what your mother says.”
es_translation: —It doesn't matter, Buck, my son —says the old man—, you will be able to do enough in due time, don't worry about that. Now go do what your mother told you.

en: When we got up-stairs to his room he got me a coarse shirt and a roundabout and pants of his, and I put them on. While I was at it he asked me what my name was, but before I could tell him he started to tell me about a bluejay and a young rabbit he had catched in the woods day before yesterday, and he asked me where Moses was when the candle went out. I said I didn’t know; I hadn’t heard about it before, no way.
vi: Chúng tôi lên gác, vào buồng với thằng Buck, nó đưa mặc vào. Mặc xong, nó hỏi tên tôi là gì, tôi chưa nói thì nó đã chỉ cho tôi xem một con sáo sậu với một con thỏ nó vừa mới bắt được trong rừng hôm kia, rồi nói hỏi tôi rằng cái lúc tắt nến thì Moses ở đâu. Tôi bảo tôi không biết và cũng chưa nghe nói cái đó bao giờ.
tr: Buck’ın yukarıdaki odasına çıktığımızda bana kalın bir gömlek, kısa bir ceket ve pantolon verdi. Ben giyinirken adımı sordu, ama daha söylememe fırsat bırakmadan evvelsi gün ormanda tuttuğu mavi alakargayı ve yavru tavşanı anlatmaya koyuldu. Sonra da mum söndüğünde Musa’nın nerede olduğunu sordu. Bilmediğimi söyledim; daha önce bununla ilgili hiçbir şey duymamıştım gerçekten de.
es: Cuando subimos las escaleras hasta su cuarto me dio una camisa gruesa, una cazadora y unos pantalones, y me lo puse todo. Entre tanto me preguntó cómo me llamaba, pero antes de que se lo pudiera decir empezó a contarme que anteayer había cogido en el bosque un estornino y un conejito y me preguntó dónde estaba Moisés cuando se apagó la vela. Dije que no lo sabía; no lo había oído nunca, de verdad.
vi_translation: We went upstairs, into the room with Buck, he started to get dressed. After getting dressed, he asked me what my name was, before I could answer, he showed me a blackbird and a rabbit he had just caught in the forest the day before yesterday, then asked me where Moses was when the candle went out. I said I didn't know and had never heard of that before.
tr_translation: When we went up to Buck's room, he gave me a thick shirt, a short jacket, and pants. While I was getting dressed, he asked my name, but before I had a chance to tell him, he started talking about the blue jay and the baby rabbit he had caught in the forest the day before yesterday. Then, when the candle went out, he asked where Moses was. I said I didn't know; I had really never heard anything about it before.
es_translation: When we climbed the stairs to his room, he gave me a thick shirt, a jacket, and some pants, and I put everything on. Meanwhile, he asked me what my name was, but before I could tell him, he started to tell me that the day before yesterday he had caught a starling and a little rabbit in the forest and asked me where Moses was when the candle went out. I said I didn't know; I had never heard it before, really.

en: “Well, guess,” he says.
vi: Nó bảo: - Thế mày thử đoán xem
tr: “Tahmin et o zaman,” dedi.
es: —Bueno, pues supón —sugirió.
vi_translation: He said: - So, try to guess
tr_translation: "Then guess," he said.
es_translation: —Well, then suppose —he suggested.

en: “How’m I going to guess,” says I, “when I never heard tell of it before?”
vi: Tôi trả lời: - Tao làm thế nào mà đoán được, vì tao đã nghe nói bao giờ đâu
tr: “Nasıl tahmin edeyim yahu?” dedim. “Bundan bahsedildiğini hayatımda ilk kez duyuyorum.
es: —¿Cómo voy a suponer —respondí— cuando nunca me lo ha dicho nadie antes?
vi_translation: I answered: - How could I have guessed, since I had never heard of it before
tr_translation: “How should I guess, man?” I said. “This is the first time in my life I'm hearing about this.”
es_translation: —How am I supposed to guess —I replied— when no one has ever told me before?

en: “But you can guess, can’t you? It’s just as easy.”
vi: - Nhưng mày có thể đoán được chứ, dễ lắm Tôi hỏi:
tr: “Ama bir şeyler atabilirsin, değil mi? Çok kolay be.
es: —Pero puedes suponer, ¿no? Es igual de fácil.
vi_translation: - But you can guess, it's very easy I asked:
tr_translation: “But you can throw something, right? It's very easy.”
es_translation: —But you can guess, can't you? It's just as easy.

en: “Which candle?” I says.
vi: - Cây nến nào? Tao không biết nó ở đâu cả. ở đâu?
tr: “Hangi mum?” dedim.
es: —¿Qué vela? —pregunté.
vi_translation: - Which candle?
tr_translation: “Which candle?” I said.
es_translation: —What candle? —I asked.

en: “Why, any candle,” he says.
vi: - Cây nến nào? Tao không biết nó ở đâu cả. ở đâu?
tr: “Fark etmez ki, herhangi bir mum işte.
es: —Pues cualquier vela —contestó.
vi_translation: - Which candle?
tr_translation: “It doesn't matter, just any candle.”
es_translation: —Well, any candle —he replied.

en: “I don’t know where he was,” says I; “where was he?”
vi: - Cây nến nào? Tao không biết nó ở đâu cả. ở đâu?
tr: “Ama nerede olduğunu bilmiyorum ki,” dedim; “neredeydi?
es: —No sé dónde estaba —respondí—; ¿dónde estaba?
vi_translation: I don't know where it is.
tr_translation: “But I don't know where it is,” I said; “where was it?”
es_translation: —I don't know where I was —I replied—; where was I?

en: “Why, he was in the dark! That’s where he was!”
vi: - Cây nến nào? Tao không biết nó ở đâu cả. ở đâu? - Ô hay, trong chỗ tôi ấy chứ ở đâu
tr: “Karanlıktaydı tabii ki! Karanlıktaydı işte!
es: —Hombre, ¡estaba en tinieblas! ¡Ahí es donde estaba!
vi_translation: Where? - Oh, it's in my place, where else
tr_translation: “Of course, it was in the dark! It was in the dark, indeed!”
es_translation: —Man, I was in darkness! That's where I was!

en: “Well, if you knowed where he was, what did you ask me for?”
vi: - à, nếu mày biết là ở đâu rồi thì còn phải hỏi tao làm gì nữa?
tr: “Nerede olduğunu biliyorsan bana niye sordun?
es: —Bueno, pues si ya sabías dónde estaba, ¿para qué me lo preguntas?
vi_translation: - Oh, if you already know where it is, then why do you still need to ask me?
tr_translation: “If you know where it is, why did you ask me?”
es_translation: —Well, if you already knew where it was, why are you asking me?

en: “Why, blame it, it’s a riddle, don’t you see? Say, how long are you going to stay here? You got to stay always. We can just have booming times—they don’t have no school now. Do you own a dog? I’ve got a dog—and he’ll go in the river and bring out chips that you throw in. Do you like to comb up Sundays, and all that kind of foolishness? You bet I don’t, but ma she makes me. Confound these ole britches! I reckon I’d better put ’em on, but I’d ruther not, it’s so warm. Are you all ready? All right. Come along, old hoss.”
vi: - Mẹ kiếp, đó là một câu đố, mày không thấy à? Này, mày định ở lại đây bao lâu? Mày phải ở đây mẵi nhé. Chúng mình tha hồ đi săn bắn, bây giờ không phải đi học nữa. Mày có con cho nào không? Tao có một con chó, đưa nó ra ngoài sông, nếu tao ném cái gì ra sông thì nó sẽ bơi ra nhặt về được. Mày có thích đi sục sạo ngày chủ nhật không? Và chạy lung tung chơi các thứ như vậy không? Chắc mày không thích hả, nhưng tao thích lắm. Mày mặc cả những cái này vào nữa đi. Có lẽ tao cũng mặc thêm vào nữa. Nhưng thôi, nóng quá. Xong chưa? Được rồi, thôi đi đi ông bạn. Bánh mì nguội, thịt bò cũng nguội.
tr: “Kafayı yedirtme adama ya, bilmece sordum sana, anlamadın mı? Burada ne kadar kalacaksın? Bence hiç gitme. Çok iyi vakit geçiririz be… Bu aralar okul da yok zaten. Köpeğin var mı? Benim bir tane var… Nehre attığın değnekleri atladığı gibi gidip getiriyor. Pazar günleri saçını taramaktan ve diğer budalaca şeyleri yapmaktan hoşlanır mısın? Eminim hoşlanmıyorsundur; ama annem bana zorla yaptırıyor. Gıcık oluyorum şu pantolona, mecbur giyiyorum, ama bana kalsa bu sıcakta giymezdim. Tamam, hazır mısın artık? Haydi gidelim abicim.
es: —Pero, hombre, es una adivinanza, ¿no entiendes? Oye, ¿cuánto tiempo vas a quedarte? Tienes que quedarte para siempre. Lo podemos pasar fenómeno... Ahora no hay escuela. ¿Tienes perro? Yo tengo un perro que sabe meterse en el río a traerte las cosas que le tiras. ¿Te gusta eso de peinarte los domingos y todas esas tonterías? Te aseguro que a mí no, pero madre me obliga. ¡Malditos pantalones! Supongo que tendré que ponérmelos, pero preferiría que no, con este calor. ¿Estás listo? Vale. Baja conmigo, compañero.
vi_translation: - Damn it, it's a riddle, don't you see? Hey, how long do you plan to stay here? You have to stay here forever. We can go hunting as much as we want, now we don't have to go to school anymore. Do you have any dogs? I have a dog, I take it to the river, if I throw something into the river, it will swim out and retrieve it. Do you like exploring on Sundays? And running around playing with things like that? You probably don't like it, but I love it. Put these on too. Maybe I'll put some more on too. But never mind, it's too hot. Are you done? Alright, let's go, my friend. The bread was cold, and the beef was also cold.
tr_translation: “Don't drive me crazy, man, I asked you a riddle, didn't you understand? How long are you going to stay here? I think you shouldn't leave at all. We would have a great time... There's no school these days anyway. Do you have a dog? I have one... It fetches the sticks you throw into the river just like that. Do you like combing your hair and doing other silly things on Sundays? I'm sure you don't; but my mom makes me do it. I hate these pants, I have to wear them, but if it were up to me, I wouldn't wear them in this heat. Okay, are you ready now? Let's go, bro.”
es_translation: —But man, it's a riddle, don't you understand? Hey, how long are you going to stay? You have to stay forever. We can have a great time... There's no school now. Do you have a dog? I have a dog that knows how to go into the river to fetch the things you throw. Do you like that stuff about combing your hair on Sundays and all those silly things? I assure you I don't, but mother makes me. Darn pants! I suppose I'll have to wear them, but I'd rather not, with this heat. Are you ready? Okay. Come down with me, buddy.

en: Cold corn-pone, cold corn-beef, butter and buttermilk—that is what they had for me down there, and there ain’t nothing better that ever I’ve come across yet. Buck and his ma and all of them smoked cob pipes, except the nigger woman, which was gone, and the two young women. They all smoked and talked, and I eat and talked. The young women had quilts around them, and their hair down their backs. They all asked me questions, and I told them how pap and me and all the family was living on a little farm down at the bottom of Arkansaw, and my sister Mary Ann run off and got married and never was heard of no more, and Bill went to hunt them and he warn’t heard of no more, and Tom and Mort died, and then there warn’t nobody but just me and pap left, and he was just trimmed down to nothing, on account of his troubles; so when he died I took what there was left, because the farm didn’t belong to us, and started up the river, deck passage, and fell overboard; and that was how I come to be here. So they said I could have a home there as long as I wanted it. Then it was most daylight and everybody went to bed, and I went to bed with Buck, and when I waked up in the morning, drat it all, I had forgot what my name was. So I laid there about an hour trying to think, and when Buck waked up I says:
vi: Rồi bơ, bánh sữa. Họ đã chuẩn bị sẵn cho tôi những thứ đó. Và như vậy còn tốt hơn những cái tôi đã được ăn từ trước đến nay nhiều lắm. Buck, và mẹ nó, và cả nhà đều hút thuốc bằng những cái tẩu con, trừ có người đàn bà da đen lúc nãy với hai thiếu phụ. Cả nhà vừa hút vừa nói chuyện. Tôi cũng vừa ăn vừa nói. Hai thiếu phụ ngồi giữa đống cuộn sợi, tóc xoã xuống sau lưng. Người nào cũng hỏi chuyện tôi. Tôi kể lại nào là bố tôi với gia đình sống ở một cái trang trại nhỏ ở tít đằng cuối vùng Arkansaw. Chi tôi là Mary Ann bỏ đi lấy chồng và không biết tin tức gì nữa. Rồi Bill lại đi tìm hai vợ chồng chị tôi cũng không tin gì về. Còn Tom và Mort thì chết rồi; về sau cả nhà chỉ còn có bố tôi với tôi, mà bố tôi thì rồi khó khăn sa sút chẳng còn gì; vì thế sau khí bố tôi chết, tôi nhặt nhạnh mấy thứ để lại mà đi. Vì cái trại đó không phải là của nhà chúng tôi nên mới bỏ ra ngoài sông đáp tàu thuỷ, chẳng may thế nào đi đường tôi bị rớt xuống sông thành ra mới mò tới đây. Họ bảo tôi cứ coi đây như ở nhà và muốn ở lại đến bao giờ cũng được. Lúc đó đã gần sáng, mọi người đi ngủ cả, tôi cũng đi ngủ với Buck, lúc tỉnh dậy đã muộn, và tôi quên khuất đi mất tên mình là gì, thế có chết không chứ. Tôi nằm đó đến một giờ đồng hồ, cố nghĩ lại xem. Lúc Buck thức dậy tôi hỏi:
tr: Soğuk mısır ekmeği, konserve sığır eti, tereyağı ve yağı alınmış süt – benim yemem için bunları çıkarmışlardı, sanki daha önce hiç bu kadar güzel yemek yememişim gibi geldi. Buck, annesi ve geri kalan herkes mısır koçanından pipo içiyordu; sadece ortalarda görünmeyen zenci kadın ve iki genç kadın içmiyordu. Hepsi birden tütün içip laflıyordu, ben de bir yandan yemeğimi yiyip bir yandan onlara cevap veriyordum. Genç kadınlar yorgana sarınmıştı ve açık saçları bellerine kadar iniyordu. Hepsi bana sorular sordu. Ben de onlara babamın, benim ve ailemin geri kalanının Arkansas’nın en güneyinde küçük bir çiftlikte yaşadığımızı anlattım. Ablam Mary Ann kaçarak evlenmişti ve ondan bir daha hiç haber alamamıştık; Bill onları aramaya gitmişti ve ondan da haber çıkmamıştı; Tom ve Mort ölmüştü ve nihayet benden ve babamdan başka hiç kimse kalmamıştı. Babam başına gelen belalardan ötürü bir deri bir kemik kalmıştı; o da ölünce, çiftlik bize ait olmadığından geri kalan eşyayla birlikte nehir yukarı yola çıkmıştım, ama işte geceleyin güverteden düşmüştüm. Oraya gelişimin hikâyesi böyleydi. İstediğim kadar onlarla birlikte kalıp orayı evim sayabileceğimi söylediler. Artık gün ışımak üzereydi, herkes odasına çekildi ve ben de Buck’ın yanında yattım; sabah uyandığımda, lanet olsun, bir baktım ki yeni adımı unutmuşum. Bir saat boyunca hatırlamak için uğraştım ve nihayet Buck uyandığında şöyle dedim:
es: Pan de borona frío, carne salada fría, mantequilla y leche con abundante nata: eso es lo que me tenían preparado abajo, y en mi vida he comido nada mejor. Buck y su madre y todos los demás fumaban pipas de maíz, salvo la negra, que se había ido, y las dos mujeres jóvenes. Todos fumaban y hablaban, y yo comía y hablaba. Las dos mujeres jóvenes estaban envueltas en colchas y llevaban la melena suelta. Todos me hacían preguntas, y les dije que padre y yo y toda la familia vivíamos en una granja pequeña allá al otro lado de Arkansas y que mi hermana Mary Ann se había escapado para casarse y no habíamos vuelto a saber de ella, y que Bill fue a buscarlos y tampoco habíamos vuelto a saber de él, y que Tom y Mort habían muerto y ya no quedaba nadie más que yo y padre, y que él se había ido consumiendo con tantos problemas, así que cuando se murió me llevé lo que quedaba, porque la granja no era nuestra, y empecé a remontar el río con pasaje de cubierta y me había caído por la borda y que por eso estaba allí. Entonces me dijeron que ahí tenía mi casa mientras yo quisiera. Después se hizo casi de día y todo el mundo se fue a acostar y yo me fui con Buck, y cuando me desperté por la mañana, maldita sea, se me había olvidado cómo me llamaba. Así que me quedé allí tumbado una hora tratando de pensarlo, y cuando Buck se despertó le pregunté:
vi_translation: Then there was butter and milk bread. They had prepared those things for me. And it was much better than what I had eaten before. Buck, his mother, and the whole family smoked with small pipes, except for the black woman from earlier and the two young women. The whole family smoked and talked. I ate and talked as well. The two young women sat among the spools of thread, their hair falling down their backs. Everyone asked me questions. I told them that my father and family lived on a small farm at the far end of Arkansas. My sister Mary Ann got married and we lost contact with her. Then Bill went to find my sister and her husband but never returned with any news. Tom and Mort had died; later, it was just my father and me, but my father fell into hard times and had nothing left; so after he died, I gathered what little was left and left. Since the farm wasn't ours, I went to the river to catch a boat, but somehow I fell into the river and ended up here. They told me to consider this place my home and stay as long as I wanted. By then it was nearly morning, everyone went to sleep, and I slept with Buck. When I woke up, it was late, and I had completely forgotten my own name, can you believe it? I lay there for an hour, trying to remember. When Buck woke up, I asked:
tr_translation: Cold cornbread, canned beef, butter, and skimmed milk – they had brought these out for me to eat, and it felt like I had never eaten such a wonderful meal before. Buck, his mother, and everyone else were smoking corn cob pipes; only the black woman and the two young women who were not around were not smoking. They were all smoking and chatting, and I was answering them while eating my meal. The young women were wrapped in blankets, and their loose hair fell down to their waists. They all asked me questions. I told them that my father, the rest of my family, and I lived on a small farm in the southernmost part of Arkansas. My sister Mary Ann had eloped, and we had never heard from her again; Bill had gone to look for them, and we hadn't heard from him either; Tom and Mort had died, and finally, there was no one left but my father and me. My father had become skin and bones due to all the troubles he had faced; when he died, since the farm did not belong to us, I had set off upriver with the remaining belongings, but I had fallen off the deck at night. That was the story of how I came here. They told me I could stay with them as long as I wanted and consider the place my home. It was almost dawn, everyone went to their rooms, and I lay down next to Buck; when I woke up in the morning, damn it, I realized I had forgotten my new name. I spent an hour trying to remember it, and finally, when Buck woke up, I said:
es_translation: Cold cornbread, cold salted meat, butter, and milk with plenty of cream: that's what they had prepared for me downstairs, and I've never eaten anything better in my life. Buck and his mother and everyone else were smoking corn cob pipes, except for the black woman, who had left, and the two young women. Everyone was smoking and talking, and I was eating and talking. The two young women were wrapped in quilts and had their hair down. Everyone was asking me questions, and I told them that father and I and the whole family lived on a small farm over on the other side of Arkansas and that my sister Mary Ann had run away to get married and we hadn't heard from her again, and that Bill went to look for them and we hadn't heard from him either, and that Tom and Mort had died and there was no one left but me and father, and that he had wasted away with so many troubles, so when he died I took what was left, because the farm wasn't ours, and I started up the river with deck passage and had fallen overboard and that's why I was there. Then they told me that I had a home there as long as I wanted. Then it was almost daylight and everyone went to bed and I went with Buck, and when I woke up in the morning, damn it, I had forgotten what my name was. So I lay there for an hour trying to think of it, and when Buck woke up I asked him:

en: “Can you spell, Buck?”
vi: - Buck, mày có đánh vần được không?
tr: “Buck, adının harflerini sıralayabilir misin?
es: —¿Estás bien de ortografía, Buck?
vi_translation: - Buck, can you spell?
tr_translation: “Buck, can you spell out the letters of your name?”
es_translation: —Are you good at spelling, Buck?

en: “Yes,” he says.
vi: - Được, nó đáp
tr: “Tabii ki sıralayabilirim,” dedi.
es: —Sí —respondió.
vi_translation: - Okay, it replied
tr_translation: “Of course, I can list them,” he said.
es_translation: —Yes —he replied.

en: “I bet you can’t spell my name,” says I.
vi: - Tao chắc mày không đánh vần nổi tên tao đâu, tôi nói thế. Nó trả lời:
tr: “Ama bahse girerim benim adımın harflerini sıralayamazsın,” dedim.
es: —Seguro que no sabes escribir cómo me llamo —le dije.
vi_translation: - I bet you can't even spell my name, I said. It replied:
tr_translation: “But I bet you can't spell out the letters of my name,” I said.
es_translation: —I'm sure you don't know how to write my name —I told him.

en: “I bet you what you dare I can,” says he.
vi: - Tao bảo cái gì mày dám làm thì tao cũng làm được
tr: “Ama bahse girerim benim adımın harflerini sıralayamazsın,” dedim.
es: —Te apuesto lo que quieras a que sí —contestó.
vi_translation: - I told you, whatever you dare to do, I can do it too
tr_translation: “But I bet you can't spell out the letters of my name,” I said.
es_translation: —I bet you anything that it will —he replied.

en: “G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n—there now,” he says.
vi: - G-e-o-r-g-e. J-a-c-k-s-o-n, đó mày xem
tr: “G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n… Yanlış mı?
es: —G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n, para que te enteres —dijo.
vi_translation: - G-e-o-r-g-e. J-a-c-k-s-o-n, see for yourself
tr_translation: “G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n…” “Is that wrong?””
es_translation: —G-e-o-r-g-e J-a-x-o-n, just so you know —he said.

en: “Well,” says I, “you done it, but I didn’t think you could. It ain’t no slouch of a name to spell—right off without studying.”
vi: - Khá lắm, đúng đấy. Tao cứ tưởng mày không đánh vần được. Cái tên ấy cũng không đến nỗi lủng củng khó đánh vần cho lắm, có thể đọc được ngay không cần phải nghĩ ngợi.
tr: “Pekâlâ, doğrusunu bildin, ama hiç tahmin etmemiştim. Öyle hiç çalışmadan bir seferde harfleri sıralanacak bir isim değil çünkü.
es: —Vale —respondí—, sí que has sabido, pero no me lo creía. No te creas que es un nombre fácil de escribir así, sin estudiárselo.
vi_translation: - Good, that's right. I thought you couldn't spell it. That name isn't too cumbersome to spell, you can read it right away without having to think about it.
tr_translation: “Alright, you got it right, but I never would have guessed. It's not a name that can be spelled out in one go without any effort.”
es_translation: —Okay —I replied—, you did know it, but I didn't believe it. Don't think it's an easy name to write just like that, without studying it.

en: I set it down, private, because somebody might want me to spell it next, and so I wanted to be handy with it and rattle it off like I was used to it.
vi: Tôi nhớ kỹ trong bụng, để nhỡ chốc nữa có ai bảo tôi đánh vần thì tôi cũng có thể nói ngay được nhanh chóng, ra vẻ như tôi đã quen với tên mình lắm.
tr: Yalnız kaldığımda oturup çalışmaya başladım, çünkü başka birisi de benden adımı yazmamı isteyebilirdi ve çok alışkınmışım gibi bir çırpıda yazmam gerekecekti.
es: Me lo apunté a escondidas, porque a lo mejor alguien quería que fuera yo quien lo escribiera, así que quería hacerlo de golpe, y soltarlo como si ya estuviera muy acostumbrado.
vi_translation: I remember it carefully in my mind, so that if someone asks me to spell it later, I can quickly say it, acting as if I am very familiar with my own name.
tr_translation: When I was alone, I sat down and started working because someone else might ask me to write my name, and I would need to write it quickly as if I were very accustomed to it.
es_translation: I wrote it down secretly, because maybe someone wanted me to be the one to write it, so I wanted to do it all at once, and present it as if I were already very used to it.

en: It was a mighty nice family, and a mighty nice house, too. I hadn’t seen no house out in the country before that was so nice and had so much style. It didn’t have an iron latch on the front door, nor a wooden one with a buckskin string, but a brass knob to turn, the same as houses in town. There warn’t no bed in the parlor, nor a sign of a bed; but heaps of parlors in towns has beds in them. There was a big fireplace that was bricked on the bottom, and the bricks was kept clean and red by pouring water on them and scrubbing them with another brick; sometimes they wash them over with red water-paint that they call Spanish-brown, same as they do in town. They had big brass dog-irons that could hold up a saw-log. There was a clock on the middle of the mantelpiece, with a picture of a town painted on the bottom half of the glass front, and a round place in the middle of it for the sun, and you could see the pendulum swinging behind it. It was beautiful to hear that clock tick; and sometimes when one of these peddlers had been along and scoured her up and got her in good shape, she would start in and strike a hundred and fifty before she got tuckered out. They wouldn’t took any money for her.
vi: Đây là một cái gia đình khá tốt bụng. Và cái nhà này cũng hết sức là xinh xắn nữa. Tôi chưa thấy cái nhà nào ở vùng này xinh đẹp và kiểu cách như nhà này. Trên cửa ra vào không có chốt bằng sắt hay bằng gỗ buộc vào miếng dây da hoẵng, nhưng lại có cái núm bằng đồng để quay, uy như những nhà ở thành phố. Trong phòng khách không kể giường ngủ cũng không để cái gì khác làm giường cả. Có rất nhiều phòng như thế ở ngoài tỉnh họ kê giường cả. Có một cái lồ sưởi to, ở dưới lót gạch, và gạch ở chúng quanh rất sạch sẽ, đỏ chót, vì là họ đổ nước lên đó rồi lấy gạch khác kỳ cọ đi. Có khi người ta lại sơn lên một nước sơn đỏ, thường gọi là màu nâu Tây Ban Nha, y như những căn nhà ngoài thành phố. Có những con chó to bằng đồng có thể đội được cả cột nhà. ở giữa bẹ lò sưởi có một cái đồng hồ, một bức tranh phong cảnh thành phố vẽ vào một nửa dưới miếng kính, rồi một cái khoang tròn ở giữa để làm mặt trời, sau miếng kính đồng hồ ấy có thể trông thấy quả lắc đưa đi đưa lại. Nghe cái đồng hồ đánh chuông hay lắm, thỉnh thoảng, một anh chàng lái rong nào đí đi qua, vào lau chùi nó và điều chỉnh nó cho đúng chỗ tức thì nó đánh liền hồi một trăm năm mười tiếng cho tới khi được tháo ra. Chủ nhà chả dễ gì bán nó với bất cứ một cái giá nào đâu.
tr: Gerçekten hoş bir aileydi, evleri de gerçekten güzeldi. Kırsal bölgede bu kadar güzel ve şık bir ev görmemiştim o güne dek. Ön kapısında demir mandal ya da deri kayışla açılan ahşap mandal yoktu, onun yerine kasabalardaki evlerde olduğu gibi pirinçten bir kol vardı, çevrilerek açılıyordu. Salonda hiç yatak yoktu, hatta yatağa benzer bir şey bile yoktu; halbuki kasabalardaki salonların hemen hepsinde yatak olurdu. En altına tuğla döşenmiş koca bir ocağı vardı, tuğlaların üzerine su döküp birbirine sürterek hep temiz ve kırmızı kalmalarını sağlıyorlardı; kimi zaman da tuğlaları kasabada yapıldığı gibi İspanyol-kahvesi denilen kırmızı bir boyaya sokup çıkarıyorlardı. Evdeki şöminede koca koca kütükleri kaldırabilecek büyüklükte pirinç aksam göze çarpıyordu. Şömine rafının ortasında bir saat ve saatin camının alt yarısında da bir kasaba resmi gördüm; saatin ortasındaki boşluk güneşi simgeliyordu ve hemen arkasında sallanan sarkacı görebiliyordunuz. Bu saatin tik-taklarını dinlemek çok güzeldi; kimi zaman gezgin tamircilerden biri içini temizleyip tekrar ayarladığında saat zembereği tamamen boşanmadan yüz elli kez çalabilirdi. Üstelik tamirciler saat için hiç para almazdı.
es: Era una familia muy simpática y la casa también era estupenda. Nunca había visto yo una casa tan buena y con tanto estilo. No tenía un pasador de hierro en la puerta principal, ni de madera con una cuerda de piel, sino un pomo de latón para darle la vuelta, igual que las casas de la ciudad. En el salón no había camas ni señales de ellas, aunque hay montones de salones en las ciudades donde se ven camas. Había una chimenea muy grande, revestida de ladrillos por abajo, que mantenían limpios a base de agua y de frotarlos con otro ladrillo; a veces los lavaban con una pintura de agua roja que llaman tierra de España, igual que en la ciudad. Tenían unos hierros de chimenea de bronce con los que se podía coger todo un tronco. En medio de la repisa había un reloj con la pintura de un pueblo en la parte de abajo de la tapa de cristal, y una apertura redonda en el medio para la esfera, y por detrás se veía el péndulo que oscilaba. Daba gusto oír el tictac de aquel reloj, y a veces cuando pasaba por allí un quincallero que lo limpiaba y lo ponía a punto comenzaba a sonar y daba ciento cincuenta campanadas antes de cansarse. No lo hubieran vendido por nada del mundo.
vi_translation: This is quite a kind family. And this house is also very charming. I have not seen any house in this area as beautiful and stylish as this one. On the front door, there is no iron or wooden latch tied with a deer leather strap, but instead, there is a brass knob to turn, just like the houses in the city. In the living room, besides the bed, there is nothing else used as a bed. There are many such rooms in the province where they place beds. There is a large fireplace, with tiles laid underneath, and the surrounding tiles are very clean and bright red because they pour water on them and scrub them with other tiles. Sometimes people paint a red coat, commonly called Spanish brown, just like the houses in the city. There are large brass dogs that can support entire house columns. In the middle of the fireplace mantel, there is a clock, a cityscape painting on the lower half of the glass, and a round hollow in the middle to represent the sun, through which you can see the pendulum swinging back and forth. The clock chimes beautifully, and occasionally, a traveling repairman passes by, comes in to clean it, and adjusts it correctly, making it chime continuously for one hundred and ten times until it is taken apart. The homeowner is not easy to sell it at any price.
tr_translation: They were truly a nice family, and their house was really beautiful. Until that day, I had never seen such a beautiful and elegant house in the countryside. There was no iron latch or wooden latch opened with a leather strap on the front door; instead, there was a brass handle like the ones in town houses, which you turned to open. There was no bed in the living room, not even anything resembling a bed; whereas almost all the living rooms in town had beds. There was a large hearth with bricks laid at the bottom, and they kept the bricks clean and red by pouring water on them and rubbing them together; sometimes they also dipped the bricks in a red paint called Spanish-coffee, as was done in town. The brass fittings in the house's fireplace were large enough to hold big logs. In the middle of the mantelpiece, I saw a clock, and below the glass of the clock's lower half, there was a picture of a town; the empty space in the middle of the clock symbolized the sun, and you could see the pendulum swinging right behind it. It was very nice to listen to the ticking of this clock; sometimes when one of the traveling repairmen cleaned and reset it, the clock could chime one hundred and fifty times before the spring fully unwound. Moreover, the repairmen never charged any money for the clock.
es_translation: It was a very nice family, and the house was also great. I had never seen such a good house with so much style. It didn't have an iron latch on the main door, nor a wooden one with a leather cord, but a brass knob to turn, just like the houses in the city. In the living room, there were no beds or signs of them, although there are plenty of living rooms in the cities where you can see beds. There was a very large fireplace, lined with bricks at the bottom, which they kept clean by using water and scrubbing them with another brick; sometimes they washed them with a red water paint called Spanish earth, just like in the city. They had some bronze fireplace irons with which you could grab an entire log. In the middle of the mantelpiece, there was a clock with a painting of a village on the bottom part of the glass cover, and a round opening in the middle for the dial, and behind it, you could see the pendulum swinging. It was a pleasure to hear the ticking of that clock, and sometimes when a tinker passed by and cleaned and tuned it, it would start ringing and give a hundred and fifty chimes before getting tired. They wouldn't have sold it for anything in the world.

en: Well, there was a big outlandish parrot on each side of the clock, made out of something like chalk, and painted up gaudy. By one of the parrots was a cat made of crockery, and a crockery dog by the other; and when you pressed down on them they squeaked, but didn’t open their mouths nor look different nor interested. They squeaked through underneath. There was a couple of big wild-turkey-wing fans spread out behind those things. On the table in the middle of the room was a kind of a lovely crockery basket that had apples and oranges and peaches and grapes piled up in it, which was much redder and yellower and prettier than real ones is, but they warn’t real because you could see where pieces had got chipped off and showed the white chalk, or whatever it was, underneath.
vi: Rồi hai bên đồng hồ lại có con vẹt trông rất lạ. làm bằng một thứ gì như phấn son, sơn màu sặc sỡ. Cạnh con vẹt bên này có một con mèo bằng sứ, còn bên kia có con chó bằng sứ; mỗi khi ấn vào đầu nó một cái thì nó kêu oé lên một tiếng, nhưng lại không há miệng ra, mà cũng chẳng tỏ ra tức giận hay vui mừng gì cả. Nó kêu ở dưới đít. Vì có hai cái quạt làm bằng lòng cánh con gà rừng lắp ở phía sau. Trên bàn để giữa phòng có một cái âu bằng sứ trông thấy rất đẹp, chất đầy những táo, cam, đào, nho, trông đỏ đỏ vàng vàng và đẹp hơn những quả thường; nhưng đó không phải hoa quả thật và có thể trông thấy những chỗ đã bong lần vỏ ngoài trơ cả đất trắng ở trong ra.
tr: Saatin her iki tarafında birer tane gösterişli papağan vardı; tebeşir gibi bir şeyden yapılmış ve cicili bicili renklere boyanmışlardı. Papağanlardan birinin yanında pişmiş topraktan bir kedi, diğerinin yanında yine topraktan bir köpek vardı; kedi ve köpeğin üstüne bastırırsanız ciyaklıyorlardı, ama ağızları açılmıyor, görünüşleri değişmiyor; tepki vermiyorlardı. Alt taraflarından ciyaklıyorlardı. Bu eşyaların arkasında yabani hindi tüyünden bir çift büyük yelpaze asılıydı. Odanın ortasındaki bir masanın üzerinde de yine pişmiş topraktan çok hoş bir sepet vardı; içine doldurulmuş elmalar, portakallar; şeftaliler ve üzümler gerçeklerinden çok daha kırmızı, sarı ve nefis görünüşlüydü, ama bazı yerleri soyulup altındaki beyaz tebeşir ya da artık her neyse o malzeme göründüğünden gerçek olmadıkları belliydi.
es: Y a cada lado del reloj había un loro muy raro hecho como de tiza y pintado de muchos colores. Al lado de uno de los loros había un gato de porcelana y al lado del otro un perro también de porcelana, y cuando se los apretaba chirriaban, pero no abrían la boca ni parecían distintos ni interesados. Detrás de ellos había dos abanicos de alas de pavo silvestre. En la mesa, en medio de la habitación, había una especie de cesto precioso de porcelana que tenía manzanas, naranjas, melocotones y uvas, todo amontonado, y mucho más rojo y amarillo y más bonito que la fruta real, pero no era de verdad porque se veía dónde habían saltado pedazos y por debajo la tiza blanca o lo que fuera.
vi_translation: Then on either side of the clock, there were very strange-looking parrots, made of something like makeup, painted in bright colors. Next to the parrot on one side, there is a porcelain cat, and on the other side, there is a porcelain dog; every time you press its head, it lets out a squeak, but it doesn't open its mouth, nor does it show any signs of anger or joy. It squeaks from its bottom. Because there are two fans made from pheasant wings installed at the back. On the table in the middle of the room, there is a very beautiful porcelain bowl, filled with apples, oranges, peaches, and grapes, looking red and yellow and more beautiful than usual fruits; but they are not real fruits and you can see spots where the outer layer has peeled off, exposing the white clay inside.
tr_translation: On each side of the clock, there was a showy parrot; made from something like chalk and painted in gaudy colors. Next to one of the parrots was a clay cat, and next to the other was a clay dog; if you pressed on the cat and dog, they would squeak, but their mouths wouldn't open, their appearance wouldn't change; they wouldn't react. They squeaked from their undersides. Behind these items, a pair of large fans made from wild turkey feathers were hanging. On a table in the middle of the room, there was also a very nice clay basket; filled with apples, oranges; peaches, and grapes that looked much redder, yellower, and more delicious than the real ones, but it was obvious they weren't real because in some places the white chalk or whatever the material was underneath was showing.
es_translation: And on each side of the clock there was a very strange parrot made as if from chalk and painted in many colors. Next to one of the parrots there was a porcelain cat and next to the other a porcelain dog, and when they were pressed they squeaked, but they did not open their mouths nor did they seem different or interested. Behind them there were two fans made of wild turkey feathers. On the table, in the middle of the room, there was a kind of beautiful porcelain basket that had apples, oranges, peaches, and grapes, all piled up, and much redder and yellower and prettier than real fruit, but it wasn't real because you could see where pieces had chipped off and underneath the white chalk or whatever it was.

en: This table had a cover made out of beautiful oilcloth, with a red and blue spread-eagle painted on it, and a painted border all around. It come all the way from Philadelphia, they said. There was some books, too, piled up perfectly exact, on each corner of the table. One was a big family Bible full of pictures. One was Pilgrim’s Progress, about a man that left his family, it didn’t say why. I read considerable in it now and then. The statements was interesting, but tough. Another was Friendship’s Offering, full of beautiful stuff and poetry; but I didn’t read the poetry. Another was Henry Clay’s Speeches, and another was Dr. Gunn’s Family Medicine, which told you all about what to do if a body was sick or dead. There was a hymn book, and a lot of other books. And there was nice split-bottom chairs, and perfectly sound, too—not bagged down in the middle and busted, like an old basket.
vi: Trên mặt bàn phủ một chiếc khăn trải bàn bằng vải dầu, đẹp, ở giữa khăn vẽ con chim ưng xanh đỏ, chung quanh sơn một đường viền. Họ bảo là chiếc khăn đó mang từ Philadelphia về. Cũng có một ít sách nữa, xếp cẩn thận ở mấy góc bàn. Một quyển là cuốn kinh thánh trong vẽ rất nhiều tranh ảnh. Một quyển là cuốn Những bước đường của Pilgrim nói về một người bỏ nhà đi mà không nói tại sao. Thỉnh thoảng tôi vẫn đọc cái truyện này. Nhưng lời nói trong đó khá hay, nhưng phải cái hơi cục cằn. Một quyển khác là cuốn Hy sinh vì bạn, trong đó có rất nhiều truyện hay, thơ hay, nhưng tôi không đọc thơ. Một cuốn là Những bài diễn văn của Henry Clay, rồi một cuốn nữa là Y học trong gia đình của bác sĩ Gunn, trong đó nói về tất cả những gì ta phải làm khi trong nhà có người ốm đau hoặc chết. Rồi lại có một quyển sách về những bài hát mừng Thánh, và một lô những sách khác nữa. Lại có những chiếc ghế con rất xinh, chân đóng choẵi ra, và ngồi rất vững, ở giữa mặt ghế không trũng mà cũng không sổ tụt như một cái rỗ cũ.
tr: Masada serili duran güzel muşamba örtünün üzerinde yine renkli bir çerçeve içine kanatlarını açmış kırmızı ve mavi bir kartal çizilmişti. Bu örtünün ta Philadelphia’dan geldiğini söylediler. Masanın her köşesine dikkatle istiflenmiş kitaplar da vardı. Bir tanesi içi resimlerle dolu, ailecek okunabilecek büyük bir Kutsal Kitap’tı. Bir başkası, belirtmediği bir sebepten ötürü evini ve ailesini terk eden bir adam hakkındaki “Hac Yolunda”ydı. Bu kitabı zaman zaman elime alıp epeyce okudum. Cümleler ilginç, ama anlaşılması zor türdendi. Çok güzel yazılar ve şiirlerle dolu “Dostluğun Getirdikleri” diye bir kitap da vardı; ama şiirleri okumadım. Henry Clay’in Nutukları adlı bir kitabın yanı sıra biri hasta olursa ya da ölürse yapılacak her şeyi anlatan dr Gunn’ın Aile Hekimliği adlı kitabı da vardı. Bir tane İlahi Kitabı ve daha bir sürü kitap vardı. Bir de çok güzel örme hasırdan koltuklarda oturuyorduk, hem de çok sağlamdı bunlar – ortası çökmüş, eski sepetler gibi altı çıkmış değillerdi.
es: Aquella mesa tenía un mantel de un hule precioso, con un águila roja y azul y una cenefa pintada todo alrededor. Decían que había llegado de Filadelfia. También había algunos libros, en montones muy ordenados a cada esquina de la mesa. Uno de ellos era una gran Biblia familiar llena de ilustraciones. Otro era el Progreso del peregrino, de un hombre que dejaba a su familia, pero no decía por qué. De vez en cuando me leía un montón de páginas. Lo que decía era interesante, pero difícil. Otro era la Ofrenda de la amistad, lleno de cosas muy bonitas y poesías, pero la poesía no me la leí. Otro eran los Discursos de Henry Clay y otro la Medicina en familia del doctor Gunn, donde decía todo lo que había que hacer si alguien se ponía malo o se moría. Había un libro de himnos y un montón de libros más. Y había unas sillas de rejilla muy bonitas, y además muy resistentes, no hundidas por el medio y rotas, como una cesta vieja.
vi_translation: On the table covered with an oilcloth tablecloth, beautiful, in the middle of the cloth is painted a blue and red eagle, with a border painted around it. They said that the cloth was brought back from Philadelphia. There were also a few books, carefully arranged in the corners of the table. One book was a Bible with many illustrations.
