tr_translation: "No, sir, I don't remember ever seeing you before."
es_translation: —No, sir; not that I know of.

en: So Tom turns to the nigger, which was looking wild and distressed, and says, kind of severe:
vi: Tom quay lại, anh da đen lúc này sợ hãi và thất vọng nó nghiêm giọng nói:
tr: Bunun üzerine Tom, şaşkınlık ve endişe içindeki zenciye dönerek gayet ciddi sordu:
es: Así que Tom se vuelve hacia el negro, que estaba todo apurado y confundido, y dice, muy severo:
vi_translation: Tom turned around, the black man now frightened and disappointed, spoke in a stern voice:
tr_translation: Thereupon, Tom turned to the black man, who was in a state of shock and worry, and asked very seriously:
es_translation: So Tom turns to the black man, who was all flustered and confused, and says, very sternly:

en: “What do you reckon’s the matter with you, anyway? What made you think somebody sung out?”
vi: - Tại sao anh lại nghĩ rằng có người gọi?
tr: “Senin neyin var acaba? Birinin seslendiğini de nereden çıkardın?
es: —Pero, ¿qué te pasa? ¿Por qué has pensado que alguien ha dicho algo?
vi_translation: - Why do you think someone called?
tr_translation: “What’s wrong with you? Where did you get the idea that someone was calling out?”
es_translation: —But, what's wrong with you? Why did you think someone said something?

en: Tom give him a dime, and said we wouldn’t tell nobody; and told him to buy some more thread to tie up his wool with; and then looks at Jim, and says:
vi: Tom cho hắn ta một hào, và bảo đừng sợ, hứa không nói cho ai biết. Lại bảo hắn mua thêm dây mà buộc túm quần áo nữa. Rồi nó quay lại phía Jim nói:
tr: Tom ona on sent verdi ve kimseye bir şey anlatmayacağımızı söyledi; saçlarına bağlamak için biraz daha ip almasını öğütledikten sonra Jim’e bakarak şöyle dedi:
es: Tom le dio diez centavos y le dijo que no se lo diríamos a nadie y que fuera a comprarse más hilo para atarse el pelo, y después mira a Jim y va y dice:
vi_translation: Tom gave him a penny and told him not to be afraid, promising not to tell anyone. He also told him to buy more rope to tie up the clothes. Then he turned to Jim and said:
tr_translation: Tom gave her ten cents and told her that we wouldn't tell anyone anything; after advising her to get some more string to tie her hair, he looked at Jim and said:
es_translation: Tom gave him ten cents and told him that we wouldn't tell anyone and that he should go buy more thread to tie his hair, and then he looks at Jim and goes and says:

en: “I wonder if Uncle Silas is going to hang this nigger. If I was to catch a nigger that was ungrateful enough to run away, I wouldn’t give him up, I’d hang him.” And whilst the nigger stepped to the door to look at the dime and bite it to see if it was good, he whispers to Jim and says:
vi: - Không biết chứ Silas có định treo cổ tên da đen này lên không. Nếu tao mà bắt được tên da đen nào vô ơn chạy trốn thì tao phải treo cổ lên chứ không tha. Và trong lúc anh da đen bước ra ngoài cửa để nhìn cho kỹ đồng hào, đưa lên rằng cắn xem có tốt không thì Tom nói thầm vào tai Jim:
tr: “Silas Enişte bu zenciyi asacak mı acaba? Ben kaçacak kadar vefasız bir zenci yakalasam asla affetmez, oracıkta asıverirdim.” Zenci on sente bakmak için dışarıdaki aydınlığa çıkıp, gerçek mi diye parayı ısırırken, Tom da eğilip Jim’e fısıldadı:
es: —Me pregunto si el tío Silas va a ahorcar a este negro. Si yo agarrase a un negro lo bastante ingrato para escaparse, no lo entregaría; lo ahorcaría yo. Y mientras el negro iba a la puerta a mirar la moneda de diez centavos y morderla para ver si era buena le susurra a Jim en voz baja:
vi_translation: - I don't know if Silas intends to hang this black man or not. If I caught any ungrateful black man running away, I would have to hang him, no mercy. And while the black man stepped outside the door to take a closer look at the half-dollar, raising it up to bite and see if it was good, Tom whispered into Jim's ear:
tr_translation: “Uncle Silas, do you think he will hang this black man?” “If I caught a black man who was unfaithful enough to run away, I would never forgive him, I would hang him right then and there.” While the black man stepped outside into the light to look at the ten cents and bit the coin to see if it was real, Tom leaned over and whispered to Jim:
es_translation: —I wonder if Uncle Silas is going to hang this black man. If I caught a black man ungrateful enough to escape, I wouldn't turn him in; I would hang him myself. And while the black man went to the door to look at the ten-cent coin and bite it to see if it was good, he whispered to Jim in a low voice:

en: “Don’t ever let on to know us. And if you hear any digging going on nights, it’s us; we’re going to set you free.”
vi: - Đừng lộ ra là biết chúng tôi. Đến đêm, nghe thấy tiếng đào đất thì đó là chúng tôi đào đấy. Chúng tôi sẽ đưa anh ra.
tr: “Bizi tanıdığını sakın belli etme. Geceleri kazma sesleri duyarsan biziz: Seni kurtaracağız.
es: —Que no se enteren de que nos conoces. Y si oyes cavar por las noches somos nosotros que vamos a ponerte en libertad.
vi_translation: - Don't reveal that you know us. At night, if you hear the sound of digging, it's us digging. We will get you out.
tr_translation: "Don't let anyone know that you recognize us. If you hear digging sounds at night, it's us: We will rescue you."
es_translation: —Don't let them find out that you know us. And if you hear digging at night, it's us coming to set you free.

en: Jim only had time to grab us by the hand and squeeze it; then the nigger come back, and we said we’d come again some time if the nigger wanted us to; and he said he would, more particular if it was dark, because the witches went for him mostly in the dark, and it was good to have folks around then.
vi: Jim chỉ kịp nắm lấy tay chúng tôi mà xiết chặt. Anh da đen kia quay lại, và chúng tôi bảo khi nào hắn cần thì sẽ đến nữa. Hắn nói là hắn mong như thế lắm vì cứ tối đến là bọn ma quái hay tìm đến hắn, cho nên có người ở bên cạnh thì càng đỡ sợ.
tr: Jim ancak ellerimizi yakalayıp sıkmaya vakit bulabildi, diğer zenci geri geldi ve biz de ona eğer isterse yine gelebileceğimizi söyledik; özellikle karanlık olduğunda gelmemizi istedi, çünkü cadılar çoğunlukla geceleri geliyordu ve birileri yanında dursa iyi olurdu.
es: Jim no tuvo tiempo más que para agarrarnos de las manos y apretárnoslas. Después volvió el negro y dijimos que volveríamos otra vez si él quería y dijo que sí, sobre todo si era de noche, porque las brujas le atacaban de noche, y entonces sí que le convenía tener gente a su lado.
vi_translation: Jim only had time to grab our hands and squeeze tightly. The black man turned around, and we told him that we would come whenever he needed us. He said he hoped so because ghosts often came to him at night, so having someone around would make him less scared.
tr_translation: Jim only had time to grab and squeeze our hands, the other black man came back and we told him that we could come again if he wanted; he especially wanted us to come when it was dark, because witches mostly came at night and it would be good to have someone with him.
es_translation: Jim had no time other than to grab our hands and squeeze them. Then the black man returned and we said we would come back again if he wanted, and he said yes, especially if it was at night, because the witches attacked him at night, and then it was really convenient for him to have people by his side.

en: CHAPTER XXXV.
vi: Chương XXXV
tr: Otuz Beşinci Bölüm
es: Capítulo 35
vi_translation: Chapter XXXV
tr_translation: Chapter Thirty-Five
es_translation: Chapter 35

en: It would be most an hour yet till breakfast, so we left and struck down into the woods; because Tom said we got to have some light to see how to dig by, and a lantern makes too much, and might get us into trouble; what we must have was a lot of them rotten chunks that’s called fox-fire, and just makes a soft kind of a glow when you lay them in a dark place. We fetched an armful and hid it in the weeds, and set down to rest, and Tom says, kind of dissatisfied:
vi: Gần một giờ nữa mới đến lúc ăn sáng, chúng tôi chạy vào rừng. Thằng Tom bảo phải có ánh sáng để đào đất, đèn thì lộ quá, nên chúng tôi phải đi gom những cành củi mục phát sáng mà người ta gọi là củi đom đóm. Chúng toi nhặt về một ôm giấu trong bãi cỏ rậm. Khi ngồi nghỉ, Tom nói, vẻ như không vừa lòng:
tr: Kahvaltıya daha bir saat filan vardı, bu yüzden oradan ayrılıp ormana girdik; çünkü Tom kazarken önümüzü görmek için biraz ışığa ihtiyacımız olacağını söylemişti, ama fener fazla gelir ve başımızı derde sokabilirdi; tilki ateşi denen çürümüş odunlardan bulmalıydık. Bu odunları karanlık bir yere koyduğun zaman hafif bir ışık yayıyorlardı. Bir kucak tilki ateşi toplayıp otların arasına sakladık, sonra da oturup biraz dinlendik. Tom hiç tatmin olmamış bir halde şöyle dedi:
es: FALTABA TODAVÍA casi una hora para desayunar, así que nos fuimos al bosque, porque Tom dijo que necesitábamos algo de luz para ver mientras cavábamos pero que un farol daba demasiada y nos podía meter en jaleos, así que necesitábamos reunir un montón de esa madera podrida fosforescente que llaman «fuego de zorro» y que no da más que una especie de resplandor suave cuando se coloca en un sitio oscuro. Sacamos un montón, la escondimos entre las hierbas y nos sentamos a descansar, cuando Tom va y dice, como descontento:
vi_translation: Almost an hour before breakfast time, we ran into the forest. Tom said we needed light to dig the earth, but using a lamp would be too conspicuous, so we had to gather glowing rotten branches that people call firefly wood. We collected an armful and hid it in the thick grass. While resting, Tom said, looking somewhat dissatisfied:
tr_translation: There was still about an hour until breakfast, so we left and went into the forest; because Tom had said that we would need some light to see ahead while digging, but a lantern would be too much and could get us into trouble; we needed to find some rotten wood called foxfire. When you put this wood in a dark place, it emitted a faint light. We gathered an armful of foxfire and hid it among the grass, then sat down to rest a bit. Tom, still unsatisfied, said:
es_translation: THERE WAS STILL almost an hour left before breakfast, so we went to the forest because Tom said we needed some light to see while we dug, but a lantern gave too much and could get us into trouble, so we needed to gather a bunch of that phosphorescent rotten wood they call "foxfire" that only gives off a kind of soft glow when placed in a dark spot. We gathered a lot, hid it among the grass, and sat down to rest, when Tom suddenly says, sounding displeased:

en: “What do we want of it? Hain’t we got to saw the leg of Jim’s bed off, so as to get the chain loose?”
vi: - Dùng cưa làm gì? - Cưa cái chân giường của Jim để mà tháo xích ra chứ.
tr: “Ne mi yapacağız? Zinciri çıkarmak için Jim’in yatağının bacağını kesmemiz gerekmiyor mu?
es: —¿Que para qué necesitamos un serrucho? ¿No tenemos que aserrar la pata de la cama de Jim, para quitar la cadena?
vi_translation: - What are you using the saw for? - Saw off the leg of Jim's bed to remove the chain.
tr_translation: “What are we going to do? Don't we need to cut the leg of Jim's bed to remove the chain?”
es_translation: —Why do we need a saw? Don't we have to saw off the leg of Jim's bed to remove the chain?

en: “Why, you just said a body could lift up the bedstead and slip the chain off.”
vi: - Thế mày vừa nói là có thể nâng cái giường lên thì rút xích ra được ngay đây thôi?
tr: “Niye ki? Az önce karyolayı kaldırıp zinciri çıkarmanın yeterli olduğunu söylemiştin.
es: —Pero si has dicho que basta con levantar la cama y sacar la cadena...
vi_translation: - So you just said that if we lift the bed, we can pull the chain out right away?
tr_translation: “Why? You just said that lifting the bed and removing the chain would be enough.”
es_translation: —But you said that it's enough to lift the bed and pull the chain...

en: “What do we want of a moat when we’re going to snake him out from under the cabin?”
vi: - Nhưng chúng mình định cho nó luồn ra ở chỗ chân tường buồng giam ấy cơ mà, cần gì phải đào đường hào nữa?
tr: “İyi ama madem onu kulübenin altından çıkartacağız, hendek ne işe yarayacak?” diye sordum.
es: —¿Para qué queremos un foso cuando vamos a sacarlo por debajo de la cabaña?
vi_translation: - But we were planning to let it slip out at the foot of the prison cell wall, weren't we? Why do we need to dig a trench?
tr_translation: "Well, but if we're going to get him out from under the shed, what use is the trench?"
es_translation: —Why do we need a pit when we're going to take it out from under the cabin?

en: But he never heard me. He had forgot me and everything else. He had his chin in his hand, thinking. Pretty soon he sighs and shakes his head; then sighs again, and says:
vi: Nó không nghe tôi nói gì. Nó đã quên rằng có tôi ngồi đó, và quên hết cả. Nó tì tay vào cằm suy nghĩ. Lát sau, nó thở dài lắc đầu. Rồi lại thở dài nói:
tr: “İyi ama madem onu kulübenin altından çıkartacağız, hendek ne işe yarayacak?” diye sordum. Ama beni duymadı bile. Beni ve geriye kalan her şeyi unutmuştu. Çenesini avcunun içine almış düşünüyordu. Biraz sonra içini çekti, başını iki yana salladı, sonra tekrar içini çekerek şöyle dedi:
es: Pero no me oyó. Se había olvidado de mí y de todo lo demás. Tenía la barbilla apoyada en la mano y pensaba. Al cabo de un momento da un suspiro y menea la cabeza; después vuelve a suspirar y dice:
vi_translation: It didn't hear me say anything. It had forgotten that I was sitting there, and forgotten everything. It rested its chin on its hand, thinking. After a while, it sighed and shook its head. Then it sighed again and said:
tr_translation: I asked. But she didn't even hear me. She had forgotten me and everything else. She was thinking with her chin resting in her palm. After a while, she sighed, shook her head from side to side, and then sighed again, saying:
es_translation: But he didn't hear me. He had forgotten about me and everything else. He had his chin resting on his hand and was thinking. After a moment, he sighs and shakes his head; then he sighs again and says:

en: “No, it wouldn’t do—there ain’t necessity enough for it.”
vi: - Không, không được, không cần lắm.
tr: “Yok yok, olmaz öyle… yeterince gerekli bir şey değil.
es: —No, eso no estaría bien; no es del todo necesario.
vi_translation: - No, it's not possible, it's not really necessary.
tr_translation: “No, no, that won't do... it's not necessary enough.”
es_translation: —No, that wouldn't be right; it's not entirely necessary.

en: “For what?” I says.
vi: - Mày bảo không cần cái gì?
tr: “Neymiş o?” dedim.
es: —¿El qué? —pregunté.
vi_translation: - What did you say you don't need?
tr_translation: "What is it?" I said.
es_translation: —What? —I asked.

en: “Why, to saw Jim’s leg off,” he says.
vi: - à, chuyện cưa cái chân thằng Jim đi ấy mà.
tr: “Jim’in bacağını kesmek, elbette,” dedi.
es: —Hombre, cortarle la pierna a Jim —me contestó.
vi_translation: - Ah, the matter of sawing off Jim's leg.
tr_translation: “Cutting off Jim's leg, of course,” he said.
es_translation: —Man, cut off Jim's leg —he answered me.

en: “Good land!” I says; “why, there ain’t no necessity for it. And what would you want to saw his leg off for, anyway?”
vi: - Trời! Sao lại thế? Thế mày định cưa chân Jim đi làm gì?
tr: “Yüce Tanrım!” dedim, “Kesinlikle hiç gerekli değil. Zaten onun bacağını kesmeyi niye istiyorsun ki?
es: —¡Caray! —dije—, no veo ninguna necesidad. Y, además, ¿para qué le quieres cortar la pierna?
vi_translation: - Oh my God! Why is that? So what are you planning to do by cutting off Jim's leg?
tr_translation: “My God!” I said, “It is definitely not necessary at all. Why do you even want to cut off his leg?”
es_translation: —Darn! —I said—, I don't see any need. And besides, why do you want to cut off his leg?

en: “Well, some of the best authorities has done it. They couldn’t get the chain off, so they just cut their hand off and shoved. And a leg would be better still. But we got to let that go. There ain’t necessity enough in this case; and, besides, Jim’s a nigger, and wouldn’t understand the reasons for it, and how it’s the custom in Europe; so we’ll let it go. But there’s one thing—he can have a rope ladder; we can tear up our sheets and make him a rope ladder easy enough. And we can send it to him in a pie; it’s mostly done that way. And I’ve et worse pies.”
vi: - Một số những người nổi tiếng làm thế đấy. Hpj không tháo được dây xích, thế là họ chặt băng ngay một cánh tay của họ đi. Thà còn một chân còn hơn. Nhưng có lẽ mình không nên làm thế. Trương hợp này cũng không cần lắm, vả lại Jim là một tên da đen, sẽ không hiểu nổi tại sao lại làm như vậy đâu. Nhưng mình có thể làm cho hắn chiếc thang dây. Chúng mìn có thể xé cái khăn trải giường ra làm cho hắn chiếc thang dây được. Và chúng mình có thể nhét thang dây vào một cái bánh đưa cho hắn.
tr: “En büyük ustalardan bazıları böyle yapmış da ondan. Zinciri çıkartamamışlar, o yüzden ellerini kesip kaçmışlar. Bacak kesmek daha da iyi olurdu. Ama bu seferlik onu atlayalım. Jim’in durumunda pek de gerekli değil, üstelik Jim bir zenci ve bunun sebeplerini, Avrupa’da niçin âdet olduğunu anlamayacaktır; o yüzden bu seferlik yapmayalım. Ama başka bir şey var… Bir ip merdiven olabilir; çarşaflarımızı yırtıp kolayca ona bir ip merdiven yapabiliriz. Bu merdiveni de ona böreğin içinde göndeririz, çoğunlukla öyle yapılıyor. Ben en kötü börekleri bile sırf…
es: —Bueno, es lo que hacen algunos de los autores más autorizados. No le pueden arrancar la cadena, así que le cortan la mano y tiran. Y una pierna sería todavía mejor. Pero nosotros tendremos que renunciar a eso. En este caso no hay suficiente necesidad, y además Jim es negro y no comprendería los motivos ni la costumbre europea, así que lo dejaremos pasar. Pero, en cambio, otra cosa sí: podemos hacer tiras las sábanas y confeccionarle una escala de cuerda muy fácil. Y se la podemos enviar dentro de un pastel; casi siempre se hace así. He comido pasteles peores.
vi_translation: - Some famous people do that. They can't remove the chains, so they just cut off one of their arms. Better to have one leg left than none. But maybe we shouldn't do that. This case doesn't really require it, and besides, Jim is a black man, he wouldn't understand why we would do such a thing. But we can make him a rope ladder. We could tear the bed sheet into strips and make him a rope ladder. And we could hide the rope ladder inside a cake and give it to him.
tr_translation: “Some of the greatest masters did it that way. They couldn't remove the chain, so they cut off their hands and escaped. Cutting off a leg would be even better. But let's skip that for now. In Jim's case, it's not really necessary, plus Jim is a black man and won't understand why it's customary in Europe; so let's not do it this time. But there's something else... A rope ladder could work; we can tear up our sheets and easily make a rope ladder for him. We can send this ladder to him inside a pie, that's usually how it's done. I've eaten the worst pies just...”
es_translation: —Well, that's what some of the most authoritative authors do. They can't tear off the chain, so they cut off the hand and pull. And a leg would be even better. But we will have to give up on that. In this case, there isn't enough need, and besides, Jim is black and wouldn't understand the motives or the European custom, so we'll let it go. But, on the other hand, we can do something else: we can tear the sheets into strips and make a very easy rope ladder for him. And we can send it to him inside a cake; it's almost always done that way. I've eaten worse cakes.

en: “He has got use for it. How you talk, you better say; you don’t know nothing about it. He’s got to have a rope ladder; they all do.”
vi: Mà phải có những chiếc bánh thật to. - Mày nói thế nào ấy. Jim làm gì mà cần một cái thang dây?
tr: “Onu kullanması şart. Asıl sen neler saçmalıyorsun, ben bu işlerden hiç anlamam desene baştan. İp merdiven olmazsa olmaz, bütün ustalar ip merdiven kullanır. “İyi ama ip merdivenle ne yapacak?
es: —Tiene que valerle de algo. Más bien qué cosas dices tú; no sabes nada de esto. Necesita una escala de cuerda; les pasa a todos.
vi_translation: And it has to be a really big cake. - What are you talking about? Why would Jim need a rope ladder?
tr_translation: “It is essential to use it. What nonsense are you talking about, you should have said from the beginning that you don't understand these things at all. A rope ladder is indispensable, all the masters use a rope ladder.” “Okay, but what will he do with the rope ladder?”
es_translation: —It has to be worth something to him. More like, what things you say; you don't know anything about this. He needs a rope ladder; it happens to everyone.

en: “What in the nation can he do with it?”
vi: - Làm gì à? Hắn có thể giấu vào trong giường ấy.
tr: “Ne mi yapacak?
es: —¿Qué diablos va a hacer con ella?
vi_translation: - Do what?
tr_translation: “What will he do?
es_translation: —What the hell is he going to do with her?

en: “Do with it? He can hide it in his bed, can’t he?” That’s what they all do; and he’s got to, too. Huck, you don’t ever seem to want to do anything that’s regular; you want to be starting something fresh all the time. S’pose he don’t do nothing with it? ain’t it there in his bed, for a clew, after he’s gone? and don’t you reckon they’ll want clews? Of course they will. And you wouldn’t leave them any? That would be a pretty howdy-do, wouldn’t it! I never heard of such a thing.”
vi: - Làm gì à? Hắn có thể giấu vào trong giường ấy. Ai cũng làm thế cả nên Jim cũng phải làm thế chứ. Huck, hình như mày không muốn làm cái gì cho nó đúng quy tắc cả, mày cứ muốn lúc nào cũng làm cái gì mới mẻ. Thế mày không nghĩ rằng họ cần dấu vết lại à Tôi nói: - Được, nếu như ai cũng làm vậy thì chúng mình cũng làm theo cho đúng với luật lệ.
tr: “Ne mi yapacak? Yatağının içine saklayabilir, öyle değil mi? Hepsi öyle yapar; onun da yapması şart. Huck, kurallara uygun hiçbir şeyi yapmak istemiyor gibisin, resmen her şeyi baştan keşfetmek niyetindesin. Diyelim ki onu hiçbir şey için kullanmadı… O gittikten sonra yatağın içinde ipucu olarak kalmayacak mı? İpucu isteyeceklerini hiç hesaba katmıyor musun? İsteyecekler elbette. Sen de onlara hiç ipucu bırakmayacak mısın? Hiç racona uyar mı böylesi? Hayatımda böyle bir şey duymadım valla.
es: —¿Hacer con ella? La puede esconder en la cama, ¿no? Es lo que hacen todos y tiene que hacerlo él también. Huck, parece como si nunca quisieras hacer las cosas bien; quieres inventártelo todo a cada vez. Supongamos que no hace nada con ella. ¿No la tiene ahí en la cama para dejar una pista cuando haya desaparecido? ¿Y no calculas que buscarán pistas? Pues claro que sí. Y, ¿no les piensas dejar ninguna? ¡Eso sí que estaría bien, te lo aseguro! Nunca he oído nada por el estilo.
vi_translation: - Do what? He could hide it in the bed. Everyone does that, so Jim has to do it too. Huck, it seems like you never want to do anything by the rules, you always want to do something new. So you don't think they need to leave any traces?? I said: - Alright, if everyone else is doing it, then we should follow suit to comply with the rules.
tr_translation: “What will he do? He can hide it inside his bed, can't he? They all do that; he has to do it too. Huck, it seems like you don't want to do anything according to the rules, you are intent on discovering everything from scratch. Let's say he didn't use it for anything… Won't it remain as a clue inside the bed after he leaves? Don't you ever consider that they will want a clue? Of course they will want it. And won't you leave them any clue? Does this fit the code at all? I've never heard of such a thing in my life, honestly.”
es_translation: —What to do with it? You can hide it in the bed, can't you? That's what everyone does, and he has to do it too. Huck, it seems like you never want to do things right; you want to make it up every time. Suppose he does nothing with it. Doesn't he have it there in the bed to leave a clue when it's gone? And don't you think they'll look for clues? Of course they will. And, don't you plan to leave them any? That would be great, I assure you! I've never heard anything like it.

en: “Well,” I says, “if it’s in the regulations, and he’s got to have it, all right, let him have it; because I don’t wish to go back on no regulations; but there’s one thing, Tom Sawyer—if we go to tearing up our sheets to make Jim a rope ladder, we’re going to get into trouble with Aunt Sally, just as sure as you’re born. Now, the way I look at it, a hickry-bark ladder don’t cost nothing, and don’t waste nothing, and is just as good to load up a pie with, and hide in a straw tick, as any rag ladder you can start; and as for Jim, he ain’t had no experience, and so he don’t care what kind of a—”
vi: Nhưng Tom Sawyer này, nếu mà chúng mình đem xé nhỏ khăn trải giường ra để làm cho Jim cái thang dây thì chúng mình sẽ có chuyện rắc rối với dì Saly đấy. Bây giờ tao thấy thế này, làm một cái thang bằng vỏ cây thì cũng giấu kín được. Còn Jim, hắn chưa có kinh nghiệm gì nên bất cứ cái gì với hắn cũng là tốt.
tr: “Madem kural böyle ve ip merdiveni olması gerek, tamam o zaman olsun; hiçbir kurala karşı gelmek istemem doğrusu; yalnız başka bir şey var, Tom Sawyer… Jim’e ip merdiven yapacağız diye çarşaflarımızı yırtarsak başımız Sally Teyze’yle büyük derde girer, bunu adım gibi biliyorum. Bana sorarsan ceviz ağacı kabuğundan bir merdiven hem maliyetsiz hem başka bir şeyi harcamaya gerek yok, üstelik ip merdivenler gibi bir böreğin içine de konup şiltenin samanları arasına da girer; ayrıca Jim’in nasıl olsa hiç tecrübesi yok bu işlerde, o yüzden nasıl bir merdiven kullandığımızı umursayacağını pek…
es: —Bueno —dije yo—, si eso es parte del reglamento y la necesita, pues le hacemos una, porque yo no quiero faltar a los reglamentos; pero te digo un cosa, Tom Sawyer, si nos ponemos a rasgar sábanas para hacerle a Jim una escala nos vamos a meter en líos con la tía Sally, de eso puedes estar seguro. A mí me parece que una escalera de corteza de nogal no cuesta nada y no hay que estropear nada, y se puede meter igual dentro de un pastel y esconder en un colchón de paja o igual de bien que cualquier escala de cuerda, y en cuanto a Jim, no tiene experiencia, así que a él no le importa qué tipo de...
vi_translation: But Tom Sawyer, if we tear the bed sheets into pieces to make a rope ladder for Jim, we'll get into trouble with Aunt Sally. Now I think this, making a ladder out of bark would also keep it hidden. As for Jim, he has no experience, so anything would be fine for him.
tr_translation: “Since the rule is like this and it has to be a rope ladder, fine, let it be; I really don't want to go against any rule; but there's something else, Tom Sawyer... If we tear our sheets to make a rope ladder for Jim, we'll get into big trouble with Aunt Sally, I know this for sure. If you ask me, a ladder made of walnut tree bark is both cost-free and doesn't require wasting anything else, plus it can be put inside a pie or among the straw of the mattress just like rope ladders; besides, Jim has no experience in these matters anyway, so I doubt he'll care what kind of ladder we use...”
es_translation: —Well —I said—, if that's part of the rules and he needs it, then we'll make one for him, because I don't want to break any rules; but I'm telling you one thing, Tom Sawyer, if we start tearing up sheets to make a ladder for Jim, we're going to get into trouble with Aunt Sally, you can be sure of that. It seems to me that a ladder made of walnut bark costs nothing and doesn't ruin anything, and it can be hidden just as well inside a cake and concealed in a straw mattress as any rope ladder, and as for Jim, he has no experience, so he doesn't care what kind of...

en: “Oh, shucks, Huck Finn, if I was as ignorant as you I’d keep still—that’s what I’d do. Who ever heard of a state prisoner escaping by a hickry-bark ladder? Why, it’s perfectly ridiculous.”
vi: - Huck Finn, nếu tao cũng dốt như mày thì thà tao im đi còn hơn. Có ai nghe nói một người bị giam mà lại trốn đi bằng một cái thang vỏ cây bao giờ? Như thế thì lố bịch hết sức. - Thôi được, tùy mày.
tr: “Gene saçmaladın, Huck Finn, cahil cahil konuşup duruyorsun iki saattir… Hiçbir şey bilmiyorsan bari çeneni tutmayı bileydin. Bir mahkûmun ağaç kabuğundan merdivenle kaçtığı da nerede duyulmuş? Böyle gülünç şey olur mu hiç?
es: —Ay, caray, Huck Finn, si yo fuera tan ignorante como tú cerraría la boca, te lo aseguro. ¿Quién ha oído hablar de un prisionero de Estado que se escape con una escalera de corteza de nogal? Resulta totalmente ridículo.
vi_translation: - Huck Finn, if I were as dumb as you, I'd rather keep quiet. Has anyone ever heard of someone escaping from prison using a bark ladder? That's utterly ridiculous. - Fine, it's up to you.
tr_translation: “Gene saçmaladın, Huck Finn, cahil cahil konuşup duruyorsun iki saattir… Hiçbir şey bilmiyorsan bari çeneni tutmayı bileydin. Bir mahkûmun ağaç kabuğundan merdivenle kaçtığı da nerede duyulmuş? Böyle gülünç şey olur mu hiç?”
es_translation: —Oh, gosh, Huck Finn, if I were as ignorant as you, I would keep my mouth shut, I assure you. Who has ever heard of a state prisoner escaping with a walnut bark ladder? It's completely ridiculous.

en: He said that would do. And that gave him another idea, and he says:
vi: Nó bảo thế cũng được. Nhưng rồi nó lại nẩy ra một ý nghĩ nữa:
tr: Buna itiraz etmedi. Hatta aklına bir fikir daha geldi:
es: Dijo que estaba bien, y eso le dio otra idea, y dijo:
vi_translation: It said that's fine too. But then it came up with another idea:
tr_translation: He did not object to this. In fact, another idea came to his mind:
es_translation: He said he was fine, and that gave him another idea, and he said:

en: “Borrow a shirt, too.”
vi: - Mượn một cái áo sơ mi nữa.
tr: “Bir de gömlek ödünç al.
es: —Toma prestada una camisa también.
vi_translation: - Borrow another shirt.
tr_translation: “Also, borrow a shirt.”
es_translation: —Borrow a shirt as well.

en: “What do we want of a shirt, Tom?”
vi: - Để làm gì, Tom?
tr: “İyi de gömleği ne yapacağız, Tom?
es: —¿Para qué queremos una camisa?
vi_translation: - What for, Tom?
tr_translation: “Well, what are we going to do with the shirt, Tom?”
es_translation: —Why do we want a shirt?

en: “Want it for Jim to keep a journal on.”
vi: - Để cho Jim viết nhật ký vào đó
tr: “Jim’in bir günlük tutması için.
es: —Para que Jim escriba un diario.
vi_translation: - Let Jim write his diary in there
tr_translation: “For Jim to keep a diary.”
es_translation: —So that Jim writes a diary.

en: “Journal your granny—Jim can’t write.”
vi: - Nhật ký cái khỉ gì, Jim có biết viết đâu.
tr: “Yuh artık… Jim’in okuma yazması yok ki.
es: —Diario, tu abuelita... Jim no sabe escribir.
vi_translation: - Diary my foot, Jim doesn't even know how to write.
tr_translation: "Come on now... Jim can't read or write."
es_translation: —Diary, your grandma... Jim doesn't know how to write.

en: “S’pose he can’t write—he can make marks on the shirt, can’t he, if we make him a pen out of an old pewter spoon or a piece of an old iron barrel-hoop?”
vi: - Không biết viết, nhưng hắn có thể nguệch ngoạc vài vạch cũng được. Chúng mình làm cho hắn một cái bút bằng thìa sắt hay bằng cái mảnh sắt đóng đai thùng.
tr: “Diyelim ki yazamıyor… gömleğin üzerine resimler ve işaretler de mi yapamaz? Ona demir kaşıktan ya da bir parça fıçı çemberinden kalem de yaparız.
es: —Supongamos que no sabe... Puede hacer palotes en la camisa ¿no? Sobre todo si le hacemos una pluma con una cuchara vieja de peltre o con el trozo de una duela de barril viejo.
vi_translation: - He doesn't know how to write, but he can scribble a few lines. We can make him a pen out of an iron spoon or a piece of iron from a barrel hoop.
tr_translation: “Let's say he can't write... can't he draw pictures and signs on the shirt either? We can make him a pen from an iron spoon or a piece of barrel hoop.”
es_translation: —Let's suppose he doesn't know... He can make marks on the shirt, can't he? Especially if we make a pen for him with an old pewter spoon or with a piece of an old barrel stave.

en: “Why, Tom, we can pull a feather out of a goose and make him a better one; and quicker, too.”
vi: - Mình dứt lông con ngỗng làm cho hắn một cái bút có hơn không? Lại nhanh nữa.
tr: “İyi ama bir kazın tüyünü yolup ona çok daha iyi bir kalem yapabiliriz, Tom, hem daha çabuk olur.
es: —Pero, Tom, le podemos arrancar una pluma a un ganso, y resulta mejor, y más rápido, además.
vi_translation: - Should I pluck a goose feather to make him a pen? It would be quick too.
tr_translation: "Well, but we can pluck a goose's feather and make a much better pen, Tom, and it would be quicker.""
es_translation: —But, Tom, we can pluck a feather from a goose, and it turns out better, and faster, too.

en: “Prisoners don’t have geese running around the donjon-keep to pull pens out of, you muggins. They always make their pens out of the hardest, toughest, troublesomest piece of old brass candlestick or something like that they can get their hands on; and it takes them weeks and weeks and months and months to file it out, too, because they’ve got to do it by rubbing it on the wall. They wouldn’t use a goose-quill if they had it. It ain’t regular.”
vi: Những người bị giam có trông thấy ngỗng đâu mà lấy được lông ngỗng làm bút, sao mày ngu thế? Họ bao giờ cũng phải lấy những đồ thật cứng, thật sù sì, như cái chân đồng của cây đèn nến hoặc một cái gì khác mà họ vớ được ở trong tháp giam để làm bút. Rồi phải mất đến hàng tuần, hàng tháng mới làm thành cái bút, vì phải đêm nó mài lên tường nhà giam. Mà có lông ngỗng họ cũng không dùng đâu. Vì như vậy nó không đúng quy tắc
tr: “Zindanda yatan mahkûmların kalem yapmak için tüyünü yolacağı kazları olmaz be enayi. Kalemlerini daima eski pirinç şamdanlardan ya da ellerinin altındaki başka sert, katı, zor bükülür şeylerden yaparlar; kalemi yapmaları da haftalar; hatta aylar sürebilir, çünkü ellerindekini kalem haline getirmek için duvara sürtmekten başka çareleri yoktur. Bulabilselerdi bile kaz tüyü kullanmazlardı onlar. Kurallara uymaz.
es: —Los prisioneros no tienen gansos corriendo por las mazmorras para ponerse a arrancarle plumas, so tonto. Siempre hacen las plumas con el trozo más duro, más difícil y más complicado de un viejo candelabro de cobre o algo a lo que le puedan echar mano, y les lleva semanas y semanas y meses y meses afilarlo, porque tienen que hacerlo frotándolo contra la pared. Ellos no utilizarían una pluma de ganso aunque la tuvieran. No está bien.
vi_translation: How could the imprisoned people see a goose to get goose feathers for making pens, how foolish are you? They always have to use something really hard, really rough, like the bronze leg of a candlestick or something else they can grab in the prison tower to make a pen. Then it takes weeks, even months to make a pen, because they have to grind it against the prison wall at night. Even if they had goose feathers, they wouldn't use them. Because that would not be according to the rules.
tr_translation: “Prisoners in jail don't have geese to pluck feathers from to make pens, you fool. They always make their pens from old brass candlesticks or other hard, rigid, and difficult-to-bend objects they have at hand; making a pen can take weeks, even months, because they have no choice but to rub what they have against the wall to turn it into a pen. Even if they could find goose feathers, they wouldn't use them. It doesn't follow the rules.”
es_translation: —Prisoners don't have geese running around the dungeons to pluck feathers from, you fool. They always make the quills from the hardest, most difficult, and most complicated piece of an old copper candlestick or something they can get their hands on, and it takes them weeks and weeks and months and months to sharpen it, because they have to do it by rubbing it against the wall. They wouldn't use a goose feather even if they had one. It's not right.

en: “Well, then, what’ll we make him the ink out of?”
vi: - Thế thì lấy gì làm mực?
tr: “Peki o zaman, mürekkebi nasıl yapacağız?
es: —Bueno, entonces, ¿con qué le hacemos la tinta?
vi_translation: - Then what will we use for ink?
tr_translation: “Well then, how are we going to make the ink?”
es_translation: —Well, then, what do we use to make the ink?

en: “Many makes it out of iron-rust and tears; but that’s the common sort and women; the best authorities uses their own blood. Jim can do that; and when he wants to send any little common ordinary mysterious message to let the world know where he’s captivated, he can write it on the bottom of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out of the window. The Iron Mask always done that, and it’s a blame’ good way, too.”
vi: - Nhiều người dùng gỉ sắt với nước mắt làm mực, nhưng đó là kiểu tầm thường và đàn bà lắm. Những tay danh tiếng thì dùng máu của mình làm mực. Jim có thể làm được thế. Và khi nào hắn muốn gửi một cái thư nhỏ, bình thường mà bí mật, để cho mọi người biết là hắn bị giam ở đâu, hắn có thể viết cái đó lên đáy một đĩa sắt, rồi ném qua cửa sổ. Bọn Mặt nạ sắt thường vẫn làm như vậy, thật là tuyệt.
tr: “Çoğu mahkûm demir pası ile gözyaşını karıştırır; ama bu alt tabakadan olanlara ve kadınlara has; bu işin erbapları kendi kanını kullanır. Jim bunu yapabilir ve dünyaya nerede esir tutulduğunu haber vermek için sıradan bir gizemli mesaj göndermek isterse, kalaylı bir tabağın arkasına çatalla kazıyıp pencereden atabilir. Demir Maske hep öyle yapar ve bana kalırsa acayip iyi bir yol.
es: —Muchos lo hacen con el orín del hierro y lágrimas, pero eso son los prisioneros más vulgares y las mujeres; los autores más autorizados utilizan su propia sangre. Jim puede hacerlo, y cuando quiera enviar cualquier mensaje misterioso de lo más corriente para que el mundo sepa dónde está cautivo, lo puede escribir en el fondo de un plato de estaño con un tenedor y tirarlo por la ventana. Es lo que hacía siempre la Máscara de Hierro, y además resulta estupendo.
vi_translation: - Many people use rust with tears as ink, but that's a common and very feminine style. Famous guys use their own blood as ink. Jim can do that. And whenever he wants to send a small, ordinary but secret letter to let people know where he's imprisoned, he can write it on the bottom of an iron plate, then throw it out the window. The Iron Mask gang often did that, it's really amazing.
tr_translation: “Most prisoners mix rust with their tears; but this is typical of the lower class and women; the experts use their own blood. If Jim can do this and wants to send a simple mysterious message to let the world know where he is being held, he can scratch it onto the back of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out the window. The Man in the Iron Mask always does it that way, and in my opinion, it’s a remarkably good method.”
es_translation: —Many do it with iron rust and tears, but those are the more common prisoners and women; the most authoritative authors use their own blood. Jim can do it, and when he wants to send any ordinary mysterious message so the world knows where he is captive, he can write it on the bottom of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out the window. That’s what the Man in the Iron Mask always did, and besides, it turns out great.

en: “Jim ain’t got no tin plates. They feed him in a pan.”
vi: - Jim làm gì có đĩa sắt? Họ cho hắn ăn bằng cái xoong.
tr: “Jim’in kalaylı tabağı yok. Ona yemeği tepside veriyorlar.
es: —Jim no tiene platos de estaño. Le dan de comer en una escudilla.
vi_translation: - How could Jim have a metal plate? They fed him using a pot.
tr_translation: “Jim doesn't have a tin plate. They serve him food on a tray.”
es_translation: —Jim doesn't have any tin plates. They feed him in a bowl.

en: “That ain’t nothing; we can get him some.”
vi: - Điều đó không quan trọng.
tr: “Bunun önemi yok, ona bir tabak götürürüz.
es: —Eso no importa, le podemos conseguir algunos.
vi_translation: - That doesn't matter.
tr_translation: “It doesn't matter, we'll take him a plate.”
es_translation: —That doesn't matter, we can get some for you.

en: “Can’t nobody read his plates.”
vi: Mình kiếm cho hắn vài cái đĩa. - Nhưng ai mà đọc được chữ của hắn?
tr: “Kimse onun tabağında yazanları okuyamaz
es: —Y nadie podrá leer lo que dice en el plato.
vi_translation: I'll get him a few plates. - But who can read his handwriting?
tr_translation: "No one can read what is written on his plate"
es_translation: —And no one will be able to read what it says on the plate.

en: “That ain’t got anything to do with it, Huck Finn. All he’s got to do is to write on the plate and throw it out. You don’t have to be able to read it. Why, half the time you can’t read anything a prisoner writes on a tin plate, or anywhere else.”
vi: - Chẳng sao. Hắn chỉ việc viết lên đĩa rồi ném ra ngoài thôi. Có cần gì phải đọc đâu. Hầu hết mọi người không thể đọc nổi một người bị giam viết những gì ở đĩa sắt.
tr: “Konumuzla hiç ilgisi yok, Huck Finn. Tek yapması gereken tabağın üzerine yazmak ve dışarı atmak. Bizim okuyabilmemiz gerekmez. Bir mahkûmun kalaylı tabağa ya da başka yere yazdıklarının yarısı okunamaz zaten.
es: —Eso no tiene nada que ver con el asunto, Huck Finn. Lo único que tiene que hacer él es escribir en el plato y tirarlo. No hay que leerlo. Pero si la mitad de las veces no se puede leer nada de lo que escriben los prisioneros de Estado en un plato de estaño, ni en ninguna otra parte.
vi_translation: - It's okay. He just needs to write on the disc and throw it out. There's no need to read it. Most people can't read what a prisoner writes on the iron disc.
tr_translation: “This has nothing to do with our topic, Huck Finn. All he has to do is write on the plate and throw it out. We don't need to be able to read it. Half of what a prisoner writes on a tin plate or elsewhere is unreadable anyway.”
es_translation: —That has nothing to do with the matter, Huck Finn. All he has to do is write on the plate and throw it. It doesn't need to be read. But half the time, you can't read anything that state prisoners write on a tin plate, or anywhere else.

en: “Why, blame it all, it ain’t the prisoner’s plates.”
vi: - Có phải đĩa của tù nhân đâu mà sợ phí.
tr: “Ya ne fark edecek ki, mahkûmun tabağı değil onlar.
es: —Pero, maldita sea, no son los platos del prisionero.
vi_translation: - It's not a prisoner's plate to worry about wasting.
tr_translation: “What difference does it make, they are not the prisoner's plates.”
es_translation: —But, damn it, they are not the prisoner's dishes.

en: “But it’s somebody’s plates, ain’t it?”
vi: - Thế là đĩa của người nào đó, phải không?
tr: “Ama birilerinin tabağı, öyle değil mi?
es: —Pero son de alguien, ¿no?
vi_translation: - So, it's someone's plate, right?
tr_translation: “But it's someone's plate, isn't it?”
es_translation: —But they belong to someone, don't they?

en: “Well, spos’n it is? What does the prisoner care whose—”
vi: - Thế là đĩa của người nào đó, phải không? - ừ, cứ cho là của ai đó, nhưng tù nhân cần gì phải quan tâm.
tr: “Diyelim ki öyle, ne olmuş? Tabağın kime ait olduğunu mahkûm niye dert…
es: —Bueno, supongamos que sí. ¿Qué más le da al prisionero?
vi_translation: - So, it's someone's plate, right? - Well, let's say it belongs to someone, but why should the prisoner care?
tr_translation: “Let's say it is so, so what? Why would the prisoner care about who the plate belongs to…”
es_translation: —Well, let's suppose so. What difference does it make to the prisoner?

en: He broke off there, because we heard the breakfast-horn blowing. So we cleared out for the house.
vi: Nó bỗng dừng lại không nói nữa, vì chúng tôi đã nghe thấy tiếng chuông gọi về ăn sáng. Chúng tôi chạy vội về nhà.
tr: Burada sustu, çünkü kahvaltı borusunun çaldığını duymuştuk. Böylece eve doğru yollandık.
es: Y entonces se interrumpió porque oímos que sonaba el cuerno del desayuno. Así que nos fuimos a la casa.
vi_translation: It suddenly stopped talking because we had heard the bell calling us for breakfast. We hurried back home.
tr_translation: He fell silent here, because we had heard the breakfast bell ring. Thus, we headed home.
es_translation: And then he stopped because we heard the breakfast horn sounding. So we went to the house.

en: Along during the morning I borrowed a sheet and a white shirt off of the clothes-line; and I found an old sack and put them in it, and we went down and got the fox-fire, and put that in too. I called it borrowing, because that was what pap always called it; but Tom said it warn’t borrowing, it was stealing. He said we was representing prisoners; and prisoners don’t care how they get a thing so they get it, and nobody don’t blame them for it, either. It ain’t no crime in a prisoner to steal the thing he needs to get away with, Tom said; it’s his right; and so, as long as we was representing a prisoner, we had a perfect right to steal anything on this place we had the least use for to get ourselves out of prison with. He said if we warn’t prisoners it would be a very different thing, and nobody but a mean, ornery person would steal when he warn’t a prisoner. So we allowed we would steal everything there was that come handy. And yet he made a mighty fuss, one day, after that, when I stole a watermelon out of the nigger-patch and eat it; and he made me go and give the niggers a dime without telling them what it was for. Tom said that what he meant was, we could steal anything we needed. Well, I says, I needed the watermelon. But he said I didn’t need it to get out of prison with; there’s where the difference was. He said if I’d a wanted it to hide a knife in, and smuggle it to Jim to kill the seneskal with, it would a been all right. So I let it go at that, though I couldn’t see no advantage in my representing a prisoner if I got to set down and chaw over a lot of gold-leaf distinctions like that every time I see a chance to hog a watermelon.
vi: Sáng hôm đó, tôi mượn một cái khăn trải giường với một cái áo sơ mi ở ngoài dây phơi, tìm một cái bị cũ nhét những thứ đó vào, rồi xuống nhà dưới đi lấy những cây củi mục rồi cho tất cả vào bị. Tôi gọi là mượn, vì bố tôi thường vẫn gọi thế. Nhưng thằng Tom nó bảo đó không phải là mượn, đó là ăn cắp. Nó nói rằng hai đứa là đại diện cho những người bị giam; mà những người bị giam thì bất cứ cách nào làm cho họ có đồ dùng cũng đều được cả, mà cũng không ai vì thế mà trách họ. Đối với một người bị giam mà lấy cắp những thứ mình cần dùng để có thể trốn ra đó thì không phải là tội ác, đó là quyền của họ, thằng Tom bảo thế. Vậy thì nếu chúng tôi là đại diện cho những người bị giam, chúng tôi hoàn toàn có quyền thay mặt người đó ăn cắp bất cứ đồ vật gì, ít nhất có thể dùng được để mà trốn ra khỏi nhà giam. Nó lại bảo rằng nếu như mình không phải là những người bị bắt giam thì cái đó lại là chuyện khác, và nếu ai không phải là người bị bắt giam mà lại ăn cắp thì chỉ là người rất xấu xa. Vì thế, chúng tôi cho rằng có thể ăn cắp mọi vật gì lấy được. Thế mà, có một hôm, tôi lấy cắp một quả dưa trong vườn của anh da đen đem ra ăn, thì nó mắng tôi ghê lắm, rồi nó trả cho những người da đen một hào mà không nói rằng cho tiền để làm gì. Tom bảo rằng chỉ ăn cắp những thứ gì cần dùng mà thôi. Tôi bảo rằng tôi cần một quả dưa. Nó lại bảo rằng không cần đến quả dưa để ra khỏi nhà giam. Nó bảo nếu như tôi giấu đi được một con dao, rồi đưa cho Jim để hắn giết tên quản gia thì như thế sẽ là rất tốt. Tôi cũng đành chịu như vậy, mặc dầu tôi thấy chẳng tội gì mà viển vông xa xôi, thà cứ chén ngay một quả dưa còn hơn.
tr: O sabah asılı çamaşırların arasından bir çarşaf ve gömlek ödünç aldım; eski bir çuval bulup ikisini de içine soktum, sonra tilki ateşini bulmaya gittik ve onu da çuvala koyduk. Ödünç almak diyordum, çünkü babam hep öyle diyordu; ama Tom bunun ödünç almak değil, çalmak olduğunu söyledi. Ona göre biz mahkûmları temsil ediyorduk; mahkûmlar bir şeyi nasıl ele geçirdiklerini umursamazlardı ve kimse de onları bunun için suçlamazdı. Bir mahkûmun kaçmak için ihtiyaç duyduklarını çalması suç değildir, dedi Tom; bu onun hakkıydı, o yüzden de bir mahkûmu temsil ettiğimiz sürece kendimizi hapisten kurtarmak için en az ihtiyaç duyduğumuz şeyleri bile çalmaya kesinlikle hakkımız vardı. Mahkûm olmasaydık her şey farklı olacaktı, mahkûm olmayan birisi çalıyorsa ancak ve ancak adi bir insan olabilirdi. Bunun üzerine, önümüze çıkan her şeyi çalabileceğimizi söyledik. Yine de sonraki günlerde zencilerin bostanından bir karpuz çalıp yediğimde bana çok kızdı. “Gidip zencilere on sent ver ve sebebini de söyleme,” dedi. Tom ancak ihtiyaç duyduğumuz şeyleri çalabileceğimizi söyledi bu sefer. “İyi ama o karpuza ihtiyacım vardı,” dedim. Fakat karpuza hapisten kaçmak için ihtiyacım olmadığını söyledi, aradaki fark buydu. Karpuzun içine bir bıçak saklayıp başgardiyanı öldürmesi için Jim’e gönderirsem sorun yoktu. Bunun üzerine boyun eğdim, ama her karpuz yürütme fırsatı yakaladığımda oturup böyle kılı kırk yaracak olduktan sonra bir mahkûmu temsil etmenin hiçbir avantajı kalmıyordu ki.
es: Aquella mañana tomé prestadas una sábana y una camisa blanca del tendedero y encontré un saco viejo para meterlas; bajamos a buscar el «fuego de zorro» y también lo metimos en el saco. Yo decía que aquello era tomar prestado, porque así lo llamaba siempre padre, pero Tom decía que no era tomar prestado sino robar. Dijo que estábamos representando a prisioneros y que a los prisioneros no les importa cómo consiguen las cosas con tal de conseguirlas y que a nadie le parece mal. No es ningún crimen que un prisionero robe lo que necesita para fugarse, dijo Tom; está en su derecho, y mientras estuviéramos representando a un prisionero teníamos perfecto derecho a robar cualquier cosa que hubiera por allí si nos valía para salir de la cárcel. Dijo que si no fuéramos prisioneros sería muy diferente, y que había que ser mezquino y ordinario para robar cuando no se era prisionero. Así que nos pusimos de acuerdo en robar todo lo que nos valiese de algo. Y sin embargo, un día, después de aquello, organizó un lío tremendo cuando yo robé una sandía del huerto de los negros y me la comí, y me hizo ir a darles a los negros diez centavos sin explicarles por qué. Tom dijo que lo que había querido decir es que podíamos robar cualquier cosa que necesitáramos. «Bueno», dije yo, «yo necesitaba la sandía». Pero él dijo que no la necesitaba para salir de la cárcel; ahí estaba la diferencia. Dijo que si hubiera querido esconder dentro un cuchillo y pasársela a Jim para matar con él al senescal, habría estado bien. Así que lo dejé, aunque no le veía la ventaja a representar el papel de prisionero si tenía que ponerme a pensar en cosas tan difíciles de distinguir cada vez que viera una oportunidad de llevarme una sandía.
vi_translation: That morning, I borrowed a bedsheet and a shirt from the clothesline, found an old bag, stuffed those things in it, then went downstairs to get some rotten firewood and put everything into the bag. I called it borrowing because my father usually called it that. But Tom said it wasn't borrowing, it was stealing. He said that the two of us were representing the imprisoned; and for the imprisoned, any way to get them supplies was acceptable, and no one would blame them for it. For a prisoner, taking what they need to escape is not a crime, it's their right, Tom said. So if we were representing the imprisoned, we had every right to steal anything on their behalf, at least anything that could be used to escape from prison. He also said that if we weren't prisoners, then it would be a different story, and if someone who wasn't a prisoner stole, they would just be a very bad person. Therefore, we thought we could steal anything we could get our hands on. Yet, one day, I stole a watermelon from the black man's garden to eat, and he scolded me harshly, then he gave the black people a dime without saying what it was for. Tom said that we should only steal things we needed. I said that I needed a watermelon. He said we didn't need a watermelon to escape from prison. He said if I could hide a knife and give it to Jim so he could kill the warden, that would be very good. I had to agree, although I thought it was pointless to be so far-fetched, and I'd rather just eat a watermelon.
tr_translation: That morning, I borrowed a sheet and a shirt from the hanging laundry; I found an old sack and put both inside, then we went to find the foxfire and put it in the sack as well. I said borrowed because my father always said so; but Tom said it wasn't borrowing, it was stealing. According to him, we were representing prisoners; prisoners didn't care how they got something and no one blamed them for it. Tom said it wasn't a crime for a prisoner to steal what he needed to escape; it was his right, so as long as we were representing a prisoner, we had every right to steal even the least of what we needed to free ourselves from prison. If we weren't prisoners, everything would be different, if someone who wasn't a prisoner stole, he could only be a common person. So, we said we could steal anything that came our way. Yet, when I stole and ate a watermelon from the negroes' garden in the following days, he got very angry with me. "Go give the negroes ten cents and don't tell them why," he said. This time, Tom said we could only steal what we needed. "But I needed that watermelon," I said. But he said I didn't need the watermelon to escape from prison, that was the difference. If I sent the watermelon with a knife inside to Jim to kill the head guard, there was no problem. So I gave in, but if I had to sit and split hairs like this every time I got a chance to swipe a watermelon, there was no advantage to representing a prisoner at all.
es_translation: That morning I borrowed a sheet and a white shirt from the clothesline and found an old sack to put them in; we went down to get the "fox fire" and put that in the sack too. I said that it was borrowing, because that's what father always called it, but Tom said it wasn't borrowing, it was stealing. He said we were pretending to be prisoners and that prisoners don't care how they get things as long as they get them and that no one minds. It's not a crime for a prisoner to steal what he needs to escape, Tom said; it's his right, and as long as we were pretending to be prisoners, we had every right to steal anything around if it helped us get out of jail. He said that if we weren't prisoners it would be very different, and that it was mean and low to steal when you weren't a prisoner. So we agreed to steal anything that would be useful to us. And yet, one day after that, he made a huge fuss when I stole a watermelon from the negroes' garden and ate it, and he made me go give the negroes ten cents without explaining why. Tom said that what he meant was that we could steal anything we needed. "Well," I said, "I needed the watermelon." But he said I didn't need it to get out of jail; that was the difference. He said that if I had wanted to hide a knife inside it and pass it to Jim to kill the guard with, that would have been fine. So I let it go, though I didn't see the point of pretending to be a prisoner if I had to think about such difficult distinctions every time I saw a chance to take a watermelon.

en: Well, as I was saying, we waited that morning till everybody was settled down to business, and nobody in sight around the yard; then Tom he carried the sack into the lean-to whilst I stood off a piece to keep watch. By-and-by he come out, and we went and set down on the woodpile to talk. He says:
vi: Thế rồi, buổi sáng hôm đó, chờ cho mọi người đã đi ra đồng hết, thằng Tom mới mang cái bị vào sau lều, trong khi đó tôi dừng lại để canh gác. Lát sau nó đi ra, hai đứa chúng tôi ngồi xuống đóng củi nói chuyện. Nó bảo:
tr: Neyse, dediğim gibi, o sabah herkes kendi işiyle meşgul olmaya başlayıncaya kadar bekledik, artık avluda kimse görünmüyordu; Tom çuvalı ardiyeye taşırken ben de biraz uzaktan gözcülük yaptım. Bir süre sonra tekrar dışarı çıktı, gidip bir odun yığınının üstüne oturup konuşmaya başladık.
es: Bueno, como iba diciendo, aquella mañana esperamos hasta que todo el mundo se fue a trabajar y no se veía a nadie en el patio. Después Tom llevó el saco al cobertizo mientras yo me quedaba unos pasos atrás para hacer la guardia. Al cabo de un rato salió y nos sentamos a hablar en el montón de leña. Va y dice:
vi_translation: Then, that morning, after waiting for everyone to go out to the fields, Tom took the sack to the back of the hut while I stayed behind to keep watch. A little later, he came out, and the two of us sat down on the logs to talk. He said:
tr_translation: Anyway, as I said, we waited until everyone started to get busy with their own work that morning, and by then no one was visible in the courtyard anymore; while Tom was carrying the sack to the storeroom, I kept watch from a bit of a distance. After a while, he came out again, and we went and sat on a pile of wood and started talking.
es_translation: Well, as I was saying, that morning we waited until everyone went to work and no one was seen in the yard. Then Tom took the sack to the shed while I stayed a few steps behind to keep watch. After a while, he came out and we sat down to talk on the woodpile. He goes and says:

en: “Everything’s all right now except tools; and that’s easy fixed.”
vi: - Mọi thứ xong cả rồi, chỉ thiếu dụng cụ thôi, nhưng việc này không khó lắm.
tr: “Artık her şey tamam,” dedi Tom, “ama bir tek aletler kaldı; onu da kolayca hallederiz.
es: —Ahora ya está todo en orden, salvo las herramientas, y eso es fácil.
vi_translation: - Everything is done, only the tools are missing, but this is not too difficult.
tr_translation: “Everything is ready now,” said Tom, “but only the tools are left; we can easily take care of that.”
es_translation: —Now everything is in order, except for the tools, and that's easy.

en: “Tools?” I says.
vi: - Dụng cụ gì? - Tôi hỏi.
tr: “Aletler mi?
es: —¿Herramientas? —pregunté.
vi_translation: - What tool?
tr_translation: “The tools?”
es_translation: —Tools? —I asked.

en: “Tools for what?”
vi: - Dụng cụ để đào chứ còn để làm gì nữa?
tr: “Ne için aletler?
es: —¿Herramientas para qué?
vi_translation: - Tools for digging, what else would they be for?
tr_translation: “What are the tools for?”
es_translation: —Tools for what?

en: “Why, to dig with. We ain’t a-going to gnaw him out, are we?”
vi: - Dụng cụ để đào chứ còn để làm gì nữa? Chúng mình không định đào vào trong ấy để lôi hắn ra ư?
tr: “Kazmak için tabii ki. Toprağı kemirerek çıkartmayacağız herhalde onu.
es: —Hombre, para cavar. No vamos a hacer un túnel con los dientes, ¿verdad?
vi_translation: - Tools for digging, what else would they be for? Aren't we planning to dig in there to pull him out?
tr_translation: “Of course, to dig. We won't be gnawing at the soil to get it out, I suppose.”
es_translation: —Man, to dig. We aren't going to make a tunnel with our teeth, right?

en: “Ain’t them old crippled picks and things in there good enough to dig a nigger out with?” I says.
vi: Chúng mình không định đào vào trong ấy để lôi hắn ra ư?
tr: “İçerideki eski kazmalar filan bir zenciyi çıkartmaya yetmez mi?
es: —¿No nos basta con esos picos y esas palas viejos para sacar a un negro?
vi_translation: Aren't we planning to dig in there to pull him out?
tr_translation: "Won't the old pickaxes inside be enough to get a black man out?""
es_translation: —Don't we have enough with those old picks and shovels to dig out a black man?

en: He turns on me, looking pitying enough to make a body cry, and says:
vi: Nó quay nhìn tôi với một vẻ như thương hại mà làm cho người ra đến phát khóc, rồi nói:
tr: Dönüp bana öyle acıyarak baktı ki o an ağlayabilirdim.
es: Se volvió hacia mí, con una cara de pena que daban ganas de llorar, y va y dice:
vi_translation: It turned to look at me with a pitying expression that could make one cry, then said:
tr_translation: He turned and looked at me with such pity that I could have cried at that moment.
es_translation: He turned towards me, with a face so sorrowful it made you want to cry, and then he says:

en: “Well, then,” I says, “if we don’t want the picks and shovels, what do we want?”
vi: - ừ, thế mình không cần cuốc xẻng thì cần cái gì?
tr: “Tamam, diyelim ki kazma ve kürek istemiyoruz, o zaman ne istiyoruz?
es: —Bueno, entonces —dije yo—, si no necesitamos picos y palas, ¿qué es lo que necesitamos?
vi_translation: - Well, if we don't need hoes and shovels, then what do we need?
tr_translation: “Alright, let's say we don't want pickaxes and shovels, then what do we want?”
es_translation: —Well, then —I said—, if we don't need picks and shovels, what do we need?

en: “A couple of case-knives.”
vi: - Vài con dao.
tr: “İki tane çakı.
es: —Un par de cuchillos de cocina.
vi_translation: - A few knives.
tr_translation: "Two pocketknives.""
es_translation: —A pair of kitchen knives.

en: “To dig the foundations out from under that cabin with?”
vi: - Dao mà đào được à
tr: “Kulübenin temellerini delip geçmek için mi?
es: —¿Para hacer un túnel por debajo de esa cabaña?
vi_translation: - Can you really dig it up??
tr_translation: "To pierce through the foundations of the cabin?"
es_translation: —To make a tunnel underneath that cabin?

en: “Confound it, it’s foolish, Tom.”
vi: - Tao thấy chuyện này khùng quá. - Tao có cần biết.
tr: “Hoppala! Ama bu çok aptalca, Tom.
es: —Maldita sea, Tom, eso es una bobada.
vi_translation: - I think this is crazy. - I need to know.
tr_translation: But this is very silly, Tom."
es_translation: —Damn it, Tom, that's nonsense.

en: “It don’t make no difference how foolish it is, it’s the right way—and it’s the regular way. And there ain’t no other way, that ever I heard of, and I’ve read all the books that gives any information about these things. They always dig out with a case-knife—and not through dirt, mind you; generly it’s through solid rock. And it takes them weeks and weeks and weeks, and for ever and ever. Why, look at one of them prisoners in the bottom dungeon of the Castle Deef, in the harbor of Marseilles, that dug himself out that way; how long was he at it, you reckon?”
vi: Theo tao, đó là cách làm đúng quy tắc. Chẳng có cách nào khác. Tao chưa nghe thấy nói có cách nào khác cả. Tao đã đọc đủ các sách nói về những chuyện này. Bao giờ họ cũng đào đất bằng dao, mà mày nên nhớ rằng không phải là đào đất đâu nhé, mà thường là đào qua đã nữa cơ. Mà như vậy mất không biết bao nhiêu là tuần lễ ấy. Đấy, mày có biết một tù nhân đào lâu đài Deep ở Marseille trong thời gian bao lâu không?
tr: “İster aptalca olsun, ister olmasın, doğrusu bu… kurallara uygun olanı da. Şu ana kadar başka bir yol da duymadım, hem de böyle konulardaki her türlü bilgiyi veren bütün kitapları okumama rağmen. Her zaman için çakıyla kazıyorlar… toprağı da değil ha; genelde kayayı deliyorlar çakıyla. Haftalarca uğraşıyorlar, neredeyse sonsuza dek sürüyor. Marsilya limanında Deef Şatosu’nun dibindeki zindanda yatan mahkûmlardan bir tanesi çakıyla kayayı delerek çıkmış; ne kadar sürmüş, bil bakalım?
es: —No importa que sea una bobada, es lo correcto y es como se hacen las cosas. No existe otra forma que yo sepa, y eso que he leído todos los libros que dan información sobre esas cosas. Siempre lo hacen con un cuchillo, y no cavando en la tierra, fijate; por lo general, es en la piedra. Les lleva semanas y semanas y semanas, y todo el tiempo sin parar y sin parar. No tienes más que fijarte en uno de esos prisioneros de los calabozos subterráneos del castillo Deef, en el puerto de Marsella, que fue así como hizo un túnel; ¿cuánto tiempo calculas que se pasó cavando?
vi_translation: In my opinion, that's the proper way to do it. There's no other way. I haven't heard of any other way. I've read all the books about these matters. They always dig with a knife, and you should remember that it's not just digging soil, but often digging through stone as well. And that takes countless weeks. Do you know how long it took a prisoner to dig the Deep Castle in Marseille?
tr_translation: “Whether it is foolish or not, this is the truth… the one that complies with the rules. So far, I haven't heard of any other way, despite reading all the books that provide all kinds of information on such matters. They always dig with a knife… not the soil; they usually drill the rock with a knife. They work for weeks, it almost takes forever. One of the prisoners lying in the dungeon at the bottom of Deef Castle in the port of Marseille escaped by drilling the rock with a knife; guess how long it took?”
es_translation: —It doesn't matter if it's nonsense, it's the right thing to do and it's how things are done. There is no other way that I know of, and I've read all the books that provide information about these things. They always do it with a knife, and not by digging in the ground, mind you; usually, it's in stone. It takes them weeks and weeks and weeks, and all the time without stopping and without stopping. You only have to look at one of those prisoners from the underground dungeons of Deef Castle, in the port of Marseille, who made a tunnel that way; how long do you think he spent digging?

en: “I don’t know.”
vi: - Tao không biết.
tr: “Bilmiyorum.
es: —No lo sé.
vi_translation: - I don't know.
tr_translation: "I don't know."
es_translation: —I don't know.

en: “Well, guess.”
vi: - Mày thử đoán xem.
tr: “Tahmin et o zaman.
es: —Bueno, pues echa un cálculo.
vi_translation: - Try to guess.
tr_translation: "Then guess.""
es_translation: —Well, then make a guess.

en: “I don’t know. A month and a half.”
vi: - Mày thử đoán xem. - Một tháng rưỡi là cùng.
tr: “Nereden bileyim. Bir buçuk ay mı?
es: —No lo sé. Un mes y medio.
vi_translation: - Try to guess. - A month and a half at most.
tr_translation: "How should I know. A month and a half?"
es_translation: —I don't know. A month and a half.

en: “Thirty-seven year—and he come out in China. That’s the kind. I wish the bottom of this fortress was solid rock.”
vi: - Ba mươi bảy năm, rồi ông ta chui ra đến tận Trung Quốc. Như thế đấy. Giá mà cái nền nhà này cũng bằng đá cứng thì hay biết mấy.
tr: “Otuz yedi yıl… taa Çin’den çıkmış. İşte bu işin kuralı budur. Keşke bu kalenin de tabanı kaya olsaydı.
es: —Treinta y siete años... Y salió en la China. Eso es lo que está bien. Ojála que el fondo de esa fortaleza fuera de piedra.
vi_translation: - Thirty-seven years, then he crawled all the way to China. Just like that. If only this foundation were made of hard stone, it would be so much better.
tr_translation: "Thirty-seven years... it came all the way from China. This is the rule of this matter. I wish the base of this castle was also rock."
es_translation: —Thirty-seven years... And it came out in China. That's what is right. I wish the foundation of that fortress were made of stone.

en: “Jim don’t know nobody in China.”
vi: - Jim có quen ai ở Trung Quốc đâu?
tr: “Jim’in Çin’de tanıdığı hiç kimse yok ki.
es: —Jim no conoce a nadie en la China.
vi_translation: - Jim doesn't know anyone in China, does he?
tr_translation: "Jim doesn't know anyone in China."
es_translation: —Jim doesn't know anyone in China.

en: “What’s that got to do with it? Neither did that other fellow. But you’re always a-wandering off on a side issue. Why can’t you stick to the main point?”
vi: - Điều ấy thì liên quan gì. Người kia cũng thế thôi. Nhưng mà mày đi xa vấn đề rồi, quay về với chuyện chính đi thôi.
tr: “İyi de bunun ne alakası var? O adamın da tanıdığı kimse yokmuş. Ama sen her seferinde önemsiz şeylere takılıyorsun. Niye asıl meseleden uzaklaşıyorsun ki?
es: —¿Qué tiene que ver eso? Tampoco aquel tipo. Pero siempre te vas por las ramas. ¿Por qué no hablas del asunto principal?
vi_translation: - What does that have to do with anything? The other person is the same. But you're straying from the point, let's get back to the main topic.
tr_translation: “But what does this have to do with anything? That man didn't know anyone either. But you always get hung up on trivial things. Why do you stray away from the main issue?”
es_translation: —What does that have to do with anything? Neither does that guy. But you always go off on tangents. Why don't you talk about the main issue?

en: “All right—I don’t care where he comes out, so he comes out; and Jim don’t, either, I reckon. But there’s one thing, anyway—Jim’s too old to be dug out with a case-knife. He won’t last.”
vi: - Thôi được, tao không cần biết là hắn ra đến chỗ nào, miễn là ra đến bên ngoài. Chỉ có điều, Jim hắn già yếu quá nên đào bằng dao mà chui ra thì không thể làm được. Hắn sẽ không sống được đến lúc đó đâu!
tr: “Tamam, peki… nereden çıktığının bir önemi yok, neticede çıkmış; Jim için de fark etmez herhalde. Yalnız şöyle bir sorun var… Jim çakıyla çıkarılamayacak kadar yaşlı. Ömrü yetmez.
es: —Bueno... A mí no me importa dónde salga, con tal de que salga; y calculo que a Jim tampoco. Pero de todas formas hay otra cosa: Jim es demasiado viejo para aguantar hasta que hagamos un túnel con un cuchillo. No durará tanto.
vi_translation: - Alright, I don't need to know where he gets to, as long as he gets outside. The only thing is, Jim is too old and weak to dig his way out with a knife. He won't live to see that day!
tr_translation: “Alright, well… it doesn't matter where it came from, it has emerged in the end; it probably doesn't matter for Jim either. However, there is one problem… Jim is too old to be removed with a knife. He doesn't have enough time left.”
es_translation: —Well... I don't care where he comes out, as long as he comes out; and I reckon Jim doesn't either. But anyway, there's another thing: Jim is too old to hold out until we make a tunnel with a knife. He won't last that long.

en: “Yes he will last, too. You don’t reckon it’s going to take thirty-seven years to dig out through a dirt foundation, do you?”
vi: - Có chứ, sống được. Chắc mày nghĩ rằng phải đến ba mươi bảy năm mới đào qua được cái móng đất này, có phải không?
tr: “Merak etme, ömrü yeter. Toprağı kazmanın otuz yedi yıl süreceğini sanmıyorsun herhalde.
es: —Pues sí que durará. No creerás que va a llevarnos treinta y siete años hacer un túnel en la tierra, ¿verdad?
vi_translation: - Yes, it's possible to live. You probably think it would take thirty-seven years to dig through this foundation, don't you?
tr_translation: “Don't worry, he has enough life left. You don't really think it will take thirty-seven years to dig the soil, do you?”
es_translation: —Well, it will last. You don't think it's going to take us thirty-seven years to make a tunnel in the ground, do you?

en: “How long will it take, Tom?”
vi: - Thế mất bao nhiêu lâu?
tr: “Peki ne kadar sürer, Tom?
es: —¿Cuánto tiempo nos llevará, Tom?
vi_translation: - So how long does it take?
tr_translation: “Well, how long will it take, Tom?”
es_translation: —How long will it take us, Tom?

en: “Well, we can’t resk being as long as we ought to, because it mayn’t take very long for Uncle Silas to hear from down there by New Orleans. He’ll hear Jim ain’t from there. Then his next move will be to advertise Jim, or something like that. So we can’t resk being as long digging him out as we ought to. By rights I reckon we ought to be a couple of years; but we can’t. Things being so uncertain, what I recommend is this: that we really dig right in, as quick as we can; and after that, we can let on, to ourselves, that we was at it thirty-seven years. Then we can snatch him out and rush him away the first time there’s an alarm. Yes, I reckon that’ll be the best way.”
vi: - Mình không thể để kéo dài quá lâu được, vì nếu để lâu quá thì chú Silas ở tận dưới New Orleans có thể nghe thấy là Jim không còn ở đấy nữa và sẽ làm ầm lên. Chính xác thì tụi mình phải cần đến mấy năm, nhưng chúng mình không thể làm thế được. Vì vậy, chúng mình đào thẳng ngay vào, đào thật nhanh, rồi sau chúng mình bỏ đó và cứ nghĩ rằng minh đã đào ba mươi bảy năm. Rồi chúng mình kéo hắn ra, khi có báo động là đẩy hắn đi ngay. Theo tao, đấy là cách tốt nhất.
tr: “Gerçi normalde süreceği kadar uzamasını bekleyemeyiz, çünkü Silas Enişte’nin New Orleans’tan haber alması çok uzun sürmez. Jim’in oradan olmadığını öğrenecektir. O zaman belki de Jim için gazetelere ilan verir ya da buna benzer bir şeyler yapar. Onu gerekli sürede çıkarma tehlikesini göze alamayız. Bana sorarsan birkaç yıl sürer herhalde, ama o kadar beklenmez işte. İşler bu kadar belirsiz olduğuna göre şunu öneriyorum: Elimizden geldiği kadar hızlı kazalım, sonra da istediğimiz zaman otuz yedi yılın sonlarına gelmişiz gibi yapabiliriz. Yani işlerin değiştiğini sezer sezmez hemen onu çıkaralım ve kaçıralım. Evet, bence en iyisi bu.
es: —Bueno, no podemos arriesgarnos a tardar todo lo que deberíamos, porque a lo mejor el tío Silas no tarda tanto en recibir noticias de Nueva Orleans. Se enterará de que Jim no es de allí. Entonces lo que hará será poner un anuncio sobre Jim, o algo parecido. Así que no podemos arriesgarnos a tardar tanto en el túnel como deberíamos. Para hacerlo bien, calculo que tendríamos que tardar un par de años; pero no podemos. Con las cosas tan en el aire, lo que yo recomiendo es que nos pongamos a cavar de verdad a toda la velocidad que podamos y después podemos decirnos que tardamos treinta y siete años. Luego podemos sacarlo y llevárnoslo corriendo en cuanto haya una alarma. Sí, calculo que eso es lo mejor.
vi_translation: - We can't let it drag on for too long, because if it takes too long, Uncle Silas down in New Orleans might hear that Jim is no longer there and make a fuss. Exactly, we would need several years, but we can't do that. So, we dig straight in, dig really fast, then we leave it and just think that we've been digging for thirty-seven years. Then we pull him out, and when there's an alarm, we push him away immediately. In my opinion, that's the best way.
tr_translation: “Of course, we can't expect it to last as long as it normally would, because it won't take long for Uncle Silas to get news from New Orleans. He will find out that Jim is not from there. Then maybe he will put ads in the newspapers for Jim or do something similar. We can't risk getting him out in the necessary time. If you ask me, it would probably take a few years, but we can't wait that long. Since things are so uncertain, I suggest this: Let's dig as fast as we can, and then we can pretend we've reached the end of thirty-seven years whenever we want. That is, as soon as we sense things are changing, let's get him out and escape immediately. Yes, I think this is the best.”
es_translation: —Well, we can't risk taking as long as we should, because maybe Uncle Silas won't take that long to receive news from New Orleans. He will find out that Jim is not from there. Then what he will do is put up a notice about Jim, or something like that. So we can't risk taking as long in the tunnel as we should. To do it right, I figure we would need to take a couple of years; but we can't. With things so up in the air, what I recommend is that we start digging for real as fast as we can and then we can tell ourselves that it took thirty-seven years. Then we can get him out and take him away quickly as soon as there's an alarm. Yes, I figure that's the best.

en: “Smouch three,” he says; “we want one to make a saw out of.”
vi: Nó bảo: - Lấy ba con về nhé, tao cần một con làm cưa.
tr: “Üç tane bul,” dedi, “bir tanesinden de testere yapacağız. “Tom, kurallara aykırı ve dinsizce değilse bir şey önereceğim,” dedim.
es: —Búscate tres —dice él—; nos hace falta uno para convertirlo en serrucho.
vi_translation: It said: - Take three back, I need one to make a saw.
tr_translation: “Find three,” he said, “we will make a saw from one of them.” “Tom, if it is not against the rules and ungodly, I will suggest something,” I said.
es_translation: —Find yourself three —he says—; we need one to turn it into a saw.

en: “Tom, if it ain’t unregular and irreligious to sejest it,” I says, “there’s an old rusty saw-blade around yonder sticking under the weather-boarding behind the smoke-house.”
vi: Tôi nói: - Tom này, nếu mày không cho tao là trái với quy tắc thi tao bảo mày là có một cái lưỡi cưa gỉ, giắt ở mái đằng sau nhà bếp kia kìa.
tr: “İsleme barakasının arkasındaki siper kaplamasının altında paslı bir testerenin ucunu görmüştüm.
es: —Tom, si no va contra el reglamento ni contra la religión que te lo sugiera —dije yo—, hay un serrucho viejo y oxidado medio tapado debajo de la tejavana que está detrás del ahumador de carne.
vi_translation: I said: - Tom, if you don't give it to me, it's against the rules, then I'll tell you there's a rusty saw blade stuck on the roof behind the kitchen.
tr_translation: “I had seen the tip of a rusty saw under the cover of the trench behind the smokehouse.”
es_translation: —Tom, if it doesn't go against the rules or against the religion that I suggest it to you —I said—, there is an old and rusty saw half-covered under the shed that is behind the meat smoker.

en: He looked kind of weary and discouraged-like, and says:
vi: Nó có vẻ chán ngán, thất vọng, trả lời tôi:
tr: Tom bıkkın ve hevesi kaçmış bir havayla şöyle dedi:
es: Me miró como cansado y desalentado y dijo:
vi_translation: It seemed bored and disappointed, and replied to me:
tr_translation: Tom said in a weary and disheartened tone:
es_translation: He looked at me as if tired and discouraged and said:

en: “It ain’t no use to try to learn you nothing, Huck. Run along and smouch the knives—three of them.” So I done it.
vi: - Tao chẳng còn biết dậy mày như thế nào nữa đây. Thôi chạy đi kiếm về đây ba con dao, nhớ là ba con đấy. Thế là tôi chạy đi.
tr: “Sana bir şey öğretmeye çalışmanın faydası yok, Huck. Çabuk git üç tane çakı getir… üç tane. Ben de dediği gibi yaptım.
es: —No se te puede enseñar nada, Huck. Ve a buscar los cuchillos, y que sean tres —y así lo hice.
vi_translation: - I don't know how to teach you anymore. Just go and bring back three knives, remember, three of them. So I ran away.
tr_translation: “There’s no use in trying to teach you anything, Huck. Quickly go and bring three knives… three of them.” I did as he said.
es_translation: —You can't be taught anything, Huck. Go get the knives, and make it three —and so I did.

en: CHAPTER XXXVI.
vi: Chương XXXVI
tr: Otuz Altıncı Bölüm
es: Capítulo 36
vi_translation: Chapter XXXVI
tr_translation: Chapter Thirty-Six
es_translation: Chapter 36

en: As soon as we reckoned everybody was asleep that night we went down the lightning-rod, and shut ourselves up in the lean-to, and got out our pile of fox-fire, and went to work. We cleared everything out of the way, about four or five foot along the middle of the bottom log. Tom said he was right behind Jim’s bed now, and we’d dig in under it, and when we got through there couldn’t nobody in the cabin ever know there was any hole there, because Jim’s counter-pin hung down most to the ground, and you’d have to raise it up and look under to see the hole. So we dug and dug with the case-knives till most midnight; and then we was dog-tired, and our hands was blistered, and yet you couldn’t see we’d done anything hardly. At last I says:
vi: Đêm đó, chúng tôi chờ mọi người đã đi ngủ, mới leo cột đèn tụt xuống, rồi chạy đến mái hiên, lấy đống lửa đom đóm ra, và bắt đầu vào việc. Chúng tôi dọn mọi thứ đồ đạc lỉnh kỉnh đi, để quang một chỗ khoảng hơn một thước ở giữa nền đất. Tom bảo chỗ đó là ngay ở phía sau giường nằm của Jim, và chúng tôi sẽ đào từ đó và trong buồng giam.
